description:
The 6th and Bryant location is a solid option for Pho in SoMa. I only wish they'd provide tendon as a protein option in their soups, like the Pho shops in the tenderloin or outer sunset. Listing tendon (牛筋) on the menu is how I judge whether they keep it real.

FYI: On many weekdays, you can also get delivery via bentoclubsf.com!
author: Anthony W.

description:
As a Northern Vietnamese, I couldn't wait to try out this place! 
So as many reviewers, I have to say the portions are really small and it doesn't fit the price at all!

My friend and I ordered Bun Cha, but I finished my plate within 3-4 scoops of food... and half of the plate was covered in herbs.. I wish they could separate the food and the herbs into 2 different plates, and be more generous with the noodle portion. 

So we ended up ordered Bun Thang to share, and the portion was really small. I feel kinda disappointed. I never have that little of the portion for that price even in Vietnam.

Final thoughts:

Food: 3.5/5
Portions: 1/5
Customer service: 5/5 

I might come back to try other dishes though.
author: Thùy Linh N.

description:
I'm always sad when I give a less than 4 star review but I can't help but to say I was a bit disappointed...I work pretty close to this location and didn't want to venture too far for lunch. I went in before the lunch rush and was seated immediately. Place was nice a clean and the service was friendly. Got the vermicelli and it came a bit different than what I'm used to- on a plate and not in a bowl and the portions were small as well. The toppings were good, the egg roll was tasty and crunchy and the pork was good too but man as soon as I scarfed down the food in 3 bites- I felt like I could've finished another whole order by myself. 

I got the check and that came rather quickly, paid $13 for lunch and to not be full. Did I order a kids size?? I'm still so hungry... I'd def check out any other viet place near here before coming back unless they up their portion size to make it be worth the price that you're paying.
author: Linde H.

description: The broth here is legit! It tastes authentic and light without excessive oil or MSG taste. I've tried the chicken as well as beef pho bowls and both were great! I prefer the beef broth though. The noodles are not typical thin pho noodles but these are very good as well and slippery haha prices are decent and service is great!
author: Jennifer Y.

description:
Big fan of Turtle tower and this is the one located on the corner of 6th and Bryant. 

Don't forget as I did to put your name on the waiting list as I got in. I got there before a couple people but because of my oversight a couple people got seated before me.

When I go to Turtle tower I know what I want , it's not the regular pho it's the Pho Ga (chicken pho). An older Asian lady was standing outside and wondering whether or not to go in and asked for my opinion. When I broke down the knowledge for her I could tell she was surprised this young latino fellar was down with the underground...I mean the pho lyfe.  When I actually verbalized this and said "surprised I know so much about pho" she got a good chuckle about it. 

Advice...get the PHO GA! The broth is awesome and I don't get Pho Ga very often but for this place it's the thing to get. For regular pho admittedly there  are better options but that's not why you go here. My best analogy would be that if you go to San Tung across town..you better get the Chicken Wings don't complain about the other dishes ...same thing with Turtle Tower , get the PHO GA. Your welcome and give me a follow if you like my reviews. 

4 stars for the Pho Ga...get it and Fuggetabout it!
author: Rod M.

description: I have been coming to TT for years, circa 2003. It never disappoints. I always get the pho ga. It is my favorite pho place in the world. It is the style of pho that I really like. I am familiar with all the staff and they are really great too.
author: C W.

description: Chicken pho is one of those comfort items that I always enjoy. LOVE the chicken pho here. Very authentic to Hanoi style pho and I have eaten in Hanoi recently. So, luckily this is local and I always go here whenever I am in the city. I always get extra jalapeños and add several scoops of Sriracha as the pho is even better spicy. The fried imperial rolls are delicious too. Just have to fork out $3.50 for one roll!
author: Kayli T.

description:
Extremely overpriced for the small portions.

Le bf and I visited this Soma location on a weekday evening for dinner. We ordered:
1. Small chicken pho ($9)
2. Small pho with rare beef ($9) (because they wouldn't substitute anything for anything else or else I would have got the pho with rare beef, well done beef and tripe)
3. Thai Tea ($4.25)
4. Fried Imperial Rolls with Vermicelli Noodle, Lettuce, Mint and Cilantro ($11.50)

We had some doubts before coming from reading what other people wrote on Yelp. Be warned, the other things they give you to accompany your pho are jalapeno slices and 1 wedge of lime each. Because people seemed to really like the chicken pho, that is what le bf got. He thought that is was pretty good when compared to other chicken pho that he has had. 

I normally get pho with rare beef and tripe. This place didn't have that combo. I tried to order the rare beef, well done beef and tripe and instead of well done beef, I wanted to get another portion of rare beef. I was sadly informed that they don't do any kind of substitutions. That is unfortunate. My pho came with 5 very small pieces of rare beef. I would have expected a bit more, even in SF. Overall, I've had richer broth, and the pho was just ok. It was edible, but nothing special. 

The Thai tea was laughably small for $4.25. It was just slightly larger than the small water glasses they provided. Total rip off. It tasted good, but had I known how large the cup was going to be, I wouldn't have ordered it. 

We also ordered the imperial rolls, which came out after both of us had finished our small bowls of pho. On the plate, we saw 3 tiny imperial rolls with 2 leaves of lettuce, some mint, cilantro, noodles, and dipping sauce. they didn't even give us enough lettuce leaves to eat our  If we ordered just one imperial roll, it was have been $3.25 each. If you were thinking about it, don't order it. The imperial rolls were about 3.5 inches long and very skinny, like if you tied 2 of your skinniest fingers together.

For more than $40 (including tax and tip), this was super, super expensive Vietnamese food. When we got into our Uber, the first thing le bf said was "that was super expensive". Even though we finished every single item, I was still hungry so we stopped by Taco Bell afterwards so that I could fill my tummy with the 3 taco combo. Needless to say, we will NOT be back. And we can't recommend this place unless you want to be willingly ripped off.
author: Carolyn Z.

description:
Unfortunately, I was very disappointed with this place. Despite the lackluster Yelp reviews, I decided to give this place a try since it was conveniently located and I had noticed it had a decent amount of traffic (maybe just coincidence) the couple of times I passed by it.

We ordered a banh mi sandwich and the sticky rice with steamed chicken and Chinese sausage.

The banh mi sandwich was very average -- nothing special. The meat did not have any flavor, the pickled vegetables were not particularly fresh, and the bread was nothing but an edible envelope for bland ingredients.

The sticky rice dish was even more disappointing. When a dish categorized as a "Special" is as poorly executed as this one was, I know I'm not going to take a chance on coming back and trying something else. Everything about the dish was poorly executed: cold pieces of steamed chicken you could tell weren't fresh and Chinese sausage carelessly sprinkled over a bed of room temperature sticky rice. I've eaten at so many Vietnamese restaurants, and I have never been somewhere where a rice dish isn't composed of at least rice, vegetables of some sort (cucumber, maybe tomato), nuoc mam sauce, and meat.

I walked away hungry and frustrated that I had spent twenty dollars on such a disappointing meal... I will not be returning again. Heed the bad reviews; sometimes ethnic restaurants will have subpar reviews despite decent food since they have poor service. This does not apply here!
author: Cindy Y.

description:
I've tried many pho in my time...but nothing like the chicken pho here.  The broth here is amazing and flavorful! The type of rice noodles they used for this also works out perfectly.  Definitely ons of the best chicken pho I've had.

The service was quick as it was fairly quiet during my visit.
author: Charlie T.

description: Absolutely lovely! I got the beef stewed in wine sauce noodle soup and loved its strong taste. The soup was very savory and the taste of wine was moderate. I especially loved the beef because it was so tender and immediately melted in my mouth. This dish is definitely for you if you love a fusion of different flavors. I would also highly recommend adding the lime in any of their soups to give the flavor a little kick.
author: Leslie C.

description: Their Chicken Pho Ga is amazing! The broth is super light and refreshing, the rice noodles are surprisingly chewy, and they give a decent amount of chicken giblets (also add the lime and jalapeños that they give you on the side into your pho! they give another dimension to the broth).
author: Alice C.

description:
I came here with 2 others just before noon and was able to beat the rush! We found free street parking just on Bryant St.  

Coming in we were greeted warmly and seated right away!

Here's what I had:

PHO GA - CHICKEN NOODLE SOUP - $10.75 (Large)
My sis and I decided to share a large bowl and it was the perfect amount for us both! I really really enjoyed the pho! The broth was so rich and flavorful.  The selection of shredded chicken was both dark and white, and had a good amount of chopped green onions! I enjoyed this very much!

VIETNAMESE COFFEE - $4.25
So happy this was prepared the traditional and correct way: over a small metal drip bar...that happens to have a faded Nike logo printed on it.  A tad pricey in my opinion but hey, I got exactly what I wanted!  It was sweet and rich and taste with a nice caffeine kick to it!

I really appreciated the stellar service here.  The staff was super friendly.  The restaurant was clean, well lit and I had a wonderful time!
author: Tu-Anh N.

description:
Got the k6 noodle soup. Soup was pretty flavorful, has some of the leftovers of meat soup that you are supposed to scoop out when serving. Pretty fatty broth in general. Had beef pieces and some pork ball sliced thinly pieces. Nothing else too special, was pretty cheap and service was decent.

Good casual place.
author: Victor D.

description:
This Turtle Tower deserves a full 5 stars from me because of these reasons:

1. The broth of the soup is consistently fresh, clear, tasty, and super hot.
2.  The noodle and meats ( either beef or chicken) are fresh and high quality.
3.  The bowl of soup is huge and I got filled up and completely satisfied to the max.
4.  The service is amazing and the waiters are fast and efficient.
5. The restaurant is clean.   Parking is reasonable.  And location is safe.
author: Ivory B.

description: The chicken pho tastes like regular chicken soup with noodles. It's fine but nothing special. Don't get the giblets--they smelled really bad and were not fresh.
author: Kaison T.

description:
Authentic, inexpensive Northern Vietnamese fare. I often frequent and prefer the original Tenderloin location, but the Soma location has its conveniences. I only had some appetizers here recently, so probably can't give the most accurate review.

Service and cleanliness of the place is a bit shoddy but honestly not expecting much. Menu consists of pho, rice & meat plates, etc and entrees generally cost about $9-10. 

Pho Ga/Chicken Noodle Soup is a pretty popular choice here, I got that the first time I came. In my opinion, the noodles at this location are too soft/mushy and feel as if they've been left in the broth too long. Broth is pretty satisfying though! Has a very clean and light taste.

The second time I came, I got the Spring Rolls and a side of Chicken Broth. 

Spring Rolls - The so-called "Fresh" Spring Rolls didn't live up to its name. The meat was also pretty sparsely distributed in the roll. Given that this isn't a  particularly challenging appetizer to execute, this definitely fell short.

Chicken Broth - Comes in a small bowl and makes for a great side! I noticed that it comes as a small side for the rice & meat plates which was nice. Flavorful, bit on the salty side. My
main criticism is that it came with way too much cilantro.. but then again I'm not sure if thats a Vietnamese culinary practice. 

My friend got the rice plate with fried chicken and commented that it was pretty good. From observation, veggies at this restaurant don't seem too fresh.

Cheap Viet eats, but I think next time the Tenderloin location will be my go-to.
author: Chelsea W.

description: I have driven by this place so many times and it always looks busy so decided to stop by. Not one single vegetarian option, I ordered the imperial rolls and asked for the beef to be left out and the shrimp, I have it to my man. He order the rice porridge and he said that it had light but good flavor. Not good enough for me to come back. CC accepted.
author: Magda G.

description: Hands down the best Pho in San Francisco. Broth is rich and silky. The stir fried noodle with vegetable and chicken or beef is a unique take on a traditional favorite.  Whenever it's raining, or I'm sick, or just back from a hot beach vacation and want a reminder of what I love about San Francisco, I come to Turtle Tower or get takeout. It's the best Pho in the West. Very busy at lunchtime so plan ahead or just get takeout.
author: Ben G.

description:
Ordered the Pho Ga to go and it was delicious! Very good broth, well developed - a little high in the fish sauce department though. Chicken was REAL, white meat with a mixture of dark. 

I enjoyed the texture and size of the noodle; these were thicker rice noodles, but not as wide as chow fun. Made two meals out of the large. I will be back; I often always pass this place on the way home from work.
author: Tangible H.

description: I ordered takeout on 3/24 and found a piece of glass in my soup. I was about to swallow and to my horror found it.... this was really scary and sad because it was actually delicious :(
author: Kayla A.

description: The noodles tasted very fresh. However, the broth was essentially tasteless and the amount of beef they charged for $10 was ridiculous. There was like two slices of beef. Coming from a Vietnamese background, this location basically sells an Americanized version of pho. I will say that the servers are very nice and respectful. The service is also really fast. If you are crunched on time, it is a good place to have a quick lunch at.
author: Linh N.

description:
Place - easy to find. You can easily find blue sign board. There are pretty many seats inside. Clean place. 

Taste - simple and delicious. Nothing special but I like it. I ordered pho, spring roll and imperial roll. Pho is simple and clean soup. I like thick noddle. Pretty many meat in it. Spring roll is great. There are vege, noddle, meat and shrimp. Good conbination with peanut butter sauce. Imperial roll is also great. Although it is small, but delicious. I also like vietnemese coffee. You can get real vietnemese coffe. It is really good for dessert, sweet and bitter.

Service and Price - Service was nice and price is reasonable!
author: Da Won L.

description: The best part about the chicken pho here is the broth.  It's simple clean and comforting.  The noodles were quite soggy and the chicken was very dry though.  Also had spring rolls which were pretty small and over fried.
author: Olivia T.

description: Light chicken based soup. Tender flat rice noodles. This place is Northern Vietnamese pho, you'll notice the chicken based soup and softer noodles.
author: Thomas C.

description:
Had turtle Tower twice in one week but this time at the soma location.

This place earned a 5 stars for their service!!! I seriously never give this high of a service star to any Asian restaurants but this place deserves it. Service was superb...management was welcoming, service was fast, no horrible attitudes from the servers....they were all actually nice and friendly!!! That's something you don't see often in an Asian restaurant.

I had the f9 which is pho ga but with a few special ingredients since it's a part of their secret menu. Fyi, secret menu items only comes in large bowls which is ginormous! So big, I couldn't finish mine. Broth is full of flavors...the extra Ingredients give it a kick and a new twist to pho which many might not be familiar with. 

Also they serve northern pho here so don't expect hoisan sauce or a plate of veggies on the side. There is siracha  though!

Also had cafe sua da, spring rolls and fried egg rolls. All were fantastic!!! 

Will be back "pho-sure" for regular pho ga because that's my all time favorite pho!!!
author: Caitlin P.

description:
My first time having northern Vietnamese pho. Met one of the owners and he was very accommodating and attentive. We had a large group and some people weren't there yet, but they still let us sit down to make sure we could get the big table.

My friends were all raving about the pho ga, but the owners mentioned someone should try the number 6 which has pieces of beef. I hate when everyone gets the same thing, so I decided to be different and get that. The beef pieces were really tender and flavorful, but I think I just wasn't used to the noodles. It's a different texture than I'm used to in pho and it was fried beforehand which I thought was kinda weird since it goes in a broth anyways.

It had a lot of extra goodies that were probably for added flavor but I didn't really eat.

It wasn't bad, but just wasn't what I was expecting or craving that day. I'd like to go back and try the pho ga so I can see what all my friends are raving about.

The owner was super nice and gave one of our friends a free meal for reviewing on yelp. It was also really nice of him to go over the menu with us in depth. Would definitely go back to try again!
author: Denise H.

description:
This was my first time trying turtle tower. I got #9 Pho Ga and was a bit disappointed at how little chicken and veggies there were in my bowl. 

ASK FOR EXTRA EVERYTHING

Broth - no complaints
Noodles - no complaints
author: Susan C.

description: I stopped by Friday to get a banh mi. The sandwich was small and didn't have much ingredients inside.  Most banh mi used a French bread. This place uses a baguette, which is much smaller.  I can't speak for the soup but don't buy the banh mi, it's a rip off
author: Frank A.

description:
Food:

F9 - secret menu!!!!! So this is a take on pho ga but not quite sure what it encompassed other then the pho and chicken.  Whatever it was...it was delicious!  I believe the noodles were pan fried.  Yum!

Service: very good waitstaff.  Friendly and attentive.

Ambiance: very casual and communal.

Overall:  yep I'll be back.
author: Spencer Q.

description:
Finally scratched something off my to-do list and finally tried the pho ga (chichen pho) at Turtle Tower.

Decided to order the #10 Pho Ga with chicken giblets. The size large isn't that big, probably the size of a small or regular elsewhere. The broth was extremely flavorful and aromatic. The noodles were okay, could have been a bit chewier, but were nicely cooked and not stuck together. The #10 has shredded chicken meat and skin which provides texture and fattiness to an otherwise very lean dish. The chicken giblets were fantastic, although I did not care for the toughness of the kidneys (but that's just the nature of eating the kidneys). 

This pho is from northern Vietnam which means it's not served with the plum sauce, sprouts, and basil that you might be used to.  You won't miss them much, as the chicken flavor is so pure and rich. 

Apparently the place has been recently remodeled and looks quite nice inside, although they have too many tables in a cramped setting, so much so that one of the tables needed to be left empty as no more customers could squeeze in around it.

I'll certainly be back for the pho ga, and maybe the steamed chicken with rice. 

Pro Tip: Please don't put your chili sauce / sriracha directly into the broth. You're disrupting a balance in flavor that took hours to achieve. Put your chili sauce into the small saucer provided, and use as needed!
author: David D.

description:
The best broth I ever had comes from turtle tower.  K6 off the secret menu is where it's at.  Also I hear rave reviews for the k9 which I will try on my next trip here.  
Also staff is super friendly and as i became a regular they became even nicer to me.   Maybe because of tipping them well.  I get a  viet sandwich with my meal so I can dip it in my soup which leaves me no space in my tummy for the leftover soup.  They always give me extra broth to go.  I appreciate them so much. This is the only pho restaurant I go to and recommend.  Enjoy!
author: Pat W.

description: I wanted to try this place,  first  when I saw that they make their Imperial Rolls with rice paper, which is the authentic recipe and method, second for their fresh wide flat noodles, and third for having pho ga, chicken noodle soup.  Having said this, the rolls were a bit over fried and the fresh noodles were over cooked.  But I did enjoy the home style broth and would go back and give it another try.
author: Beatrice L.

description: This place is a good Vietnamese restaurant, and affordable price. Staffs are moderate, and inside of the restaurant is clean.
author: Yumiko H.

description:
My first time eating here after having turtle tower bookmarked for the longest time. This wasn't my first choice location but... I was brought here by jury duty, so I might as well try it after the WONDERFUL LONG hours of waiting for my name to be called. 

Anyways, I read some reviews and saw people mention a secret menu for their chicken pho (pho ga), so I went for it. I think it was like F9 or something like that. Anyways, I had no expectations for what this will be like, so I was a little confused to see sliced ham(?) on top of the soup. I mixed it up and squeezed the lemon in. First spoonful of soup was very flavorful. It seems like they pan fry the noodles with some sauce before serving this. The noodles were a tad too soft for my liking. The chicken was plentiful and moist. My only gripe is their use of MSG in their soup. As I sit here writing this review halfway done with my meal, my throat is parched and thirsts for water to wash away the MSG. 

Overall, this place is good and better than some places for chicken pho, but I wouldn't come out of my way to eat here. Y'all who want to make chicken pho at home, try using Costco rotisserie chicken bones!

Also, there's this awkward window ledge area for solo eaters (me) and the stools are kind of too tall for me to set my feet down, but there's no other foot holder, so I'm pretty uncomfortable. 

Overall, just happy I was no chosen for jury duty.
author: Susanna C.

description:
I LOVE, LOVE TURTLE TOWER! 

PARKING: there's always parking... just have to pay $.. but there are some free parking

FOOD:
(1) Imperial Roll - for 1 roll... $2.25-ish! EKS!
(2) A bowl of chicken pho! Fresh noodles, lots of green onion, cilantro, and lots of chicken... maybe too much chicken fat.. but I'll eat it!

DRINKS:
Vietnamese coffee - mMm!
 
**MUST GET: Chicken PHO! 5 stars!
author: Mindy Y.

description:
It's not a place you'd take anyone to (anyone you're trying to woo or out of town guests). Most of people who eat here are alone or just grabbing a quick dinner after work.
That being said, they have pretty good northern Vietnamese pho. I always get the well done beef and rare beef pho. The broth is hearty and clear. It's a great hangover remedy, or at least that's what I crave after a night out in town. =]
They also have a good selection of interesting Asian drinks and Vietnamese coffee. I've tried most and all pretty good.
author: Tata X.

description:
Turtle Tower does a great job at capturing the essence of North Vietnamese fare. While it's difficult to emulate the low sitting tables/stools and general hustle and bustle of central Ha Noi Turtle Tower delivers with a delicious bowl of noodles. 

Staff is friendly and helpful. I prefer an extra side of jalapeños and was surprised to have it already provided. Broth was full of flavor with the perfect amount of garnish. Cilantro, green onion, lemongrass, star anise. I'm sure I'm missing a long list of other hidden ingredients.

I ordered the regular bowl and was definitely craving more. The amount of noodles was slightly less than what I'm used to. If you have a moderate appetite I would recommend the larger portion. Priced reasonable at $8-10 for a bowl. Am I still in San Francisco?! The extra kicker was receiving my bill and not being charged for my iced tea. Sometimes it's the small complimentary items that make the difference.
author: Ralph A.

description: This is the SoMa location of the Turtle Tower of Tenderloin. They are know for their chicken pho, and it is great. This location has always seemed a little less busy than the other 2, so usually no wait. Same great food. Fast service too.
author: Peter K.

description:
I've tried their other locations and I can say the same about this one. Their pho ga is one of the best i've had! They give you a plentiful amount of chicken and lots of onions - yum!

One of the downsides is that turtle tower always has a wait, but since they serve mostly noodles, the wait is not that bad.
author: Sherry L.

description:
While passing by San Francisco we spotted a Vietnamese restaurant so my partner and I were down to try it. Sadly we tried to avoid the Giants game restaurant area because it was jam packed with folks so this business was a calm get away from the hectic 'trying to find parking' streets.

I appreciate the attentiveness and friendliness of staff but unfortunately I love dipping my sandwiches into dips and they only provided fish  sauce and Sriracha sauce on the table and when asked the waiter was unable to communicate  in English but overall the language barrier was no problem. 

I ordered a pork, chicken, egg sandwich. I expected it to be a tad bit bigger for the price but I assumed it was the meats that made it pricy.
author: Jess S.

description:
Turtle Tower was my introduction to northern-style Vietnamese pho.  Previously, I didn't even know such a thing even existed.  And man was it delicious.  

I ordered the chicken with chicken giblets pho ga and nem cua fried imperial rolls with vermicelli noodles and lettuce.  Let me start by saying that the broth from the pho actually tasted like chicken.  The limited spice and fish sauce added to the broth was not too salty and overpowering that it did not take the essential chicken taste away.  The rice noodles were wide and soft.  I normally like my noodles al dente, but in this particularly case, it matched really well with the broth and meat.  Finally, the chicken was pulled and cut into small bite size pieces with a mixture of dark and white meat.  It was a good contrast between the soft and more flavorful dark meat verus the firm but subtle taste of the white meat.  The giblets added a fulfilling crunch to every bite. 

The nem cua was fried to perfection.  And in this particular case, I could actually taste the crab meat (There are a lot establishments elsewhere that would cheap out and increase the ratio of the pork filling). When eaten with the noodles and lettuce and dipped in the fish sauce, it's elevated to an whole new level.  Definitely recommend trying this dish here at least once.

What's keeping me from giving this 5 stars was that the portion size were too small.  I judge a restaurant by the culinary experience I received versus the amount I paid.  I have no problem giving a shabby "normal" place a perfect score if the value accurately reflects it.  In this case I left the restaurant not hungry but not fulfilled.  In addition I don't think claiming that the chickens were raised "free-ranged" can justify the increase in price.  The USDA states that free-range only means that the animal has access to outdoors.  It does not regulate the amount of time the chicken is outdoors, the size of the outdoor space, or its food source. 

In conclusion I definitely recommend this place to any pho lover.  I'm sure there are many non-Vietnamese people that would appreciate knowing there is a different style of pho out there.  Just don't expect to be stuffed of full when you finish your meal.
author: Chris W.

description:
Well.. I don't know what these other reviewers are saying, but this pho was BY FAR, the best bowl of pho I've ever had.  I've never had a bowl of noodles blow me away like this did.  A friend mentioned that this place is known for their chicken pho, but I decided to try #6.  The broth was flavorful, but because the vegetables and meat were stir-fried it gave the soup a "stir-fry" flavor as well that paired perfectly.  

I would definitely recommend and I would definitely come back into the city just for a bowl of their noodle soup.

Ambiance: 3/5
Food: 5/5
Service: 4/5
Overall Experience: 5/5
author: Elizabeth L.

description:
Had jury duty today so popped in for a to go order. 

Vietnamese  shrimp rolls
Vietnamese iced coffee

$11

Nice person at counter.  Very fast

Liked everything.  The hubby didn't like peanutty  dipping sauce 

The 8 muni is right by their front door so easy peasy
author: Foodlover B.

description: Delicious, authentic Vietnamese food for a very reasonable price. The staff and owner are all very friendly and efficient with fast service for high quality food. Perfect for a filling and tasty lunch but also works great for dinner! I had the pork soup and it tasted just like what I had in Hanoi!
author: Jeremy S.

description: I got a chance to stop by during my lunch break and ordered the Chicken leg special. It was tasty and I will definitely be back to their restaurant more often for lunch. I'm a fan!
author: Jess M.

description: Interesting take on pho. Noodles aren't the thin one's you're used to, they're much wider. Would def recommend. Soup is also really good but a little thin at times. I'm a regular
author: Chris X.

description:
So I had to try this place since I was in the area to see what the hype is all about.

I went around 3:30PM on a Monday so the place wasn't crowded, I was ready to be impressed. Well, the only thing I was really impressed with was how quick my food came out (There were only two other tables at the time).

I ordered the Pho Ga (chicken pho) large. Now here is where I was unhappy...I didn't think that I would leave the restaurant after paying almost $11 for a bowl of large STILL HUNGRY...! This is the first restaurant where they serve pho and don't offer Hoisin sauce. To be honest, I was really put off by this. The only options were fish sauce and hot sauce. The waitress asked me if I wanted a lemon with jalapeños instead. Well, that's not really the same as hoisin but I took it anyways. The jalapeños were a bit sad, just the edges, not even full pieces...so it honestly didn't make a difference in my food.

Service wise, the lady never even came back to offer me more water or give me my bill. I had to walk up to the counter, flag her down and ask if I could pay up front. I really don't think there is a good reason to come back. I'm a bit confused with all the high ratings saying they give a lot of food...my portion honestly looked like a size small but placed in a large sized bowl with a ton of broth to make up for it. Moving on...
author: Allison S.

description: My favorite pho place in San Francisco. The noodles here are the best and its overall super authentic. I like the chicken pho and imperial rolls a lot. I also love that they give you the option of ordering a whole plate of rare beef for $4. I'm surprised that's even legal to serve at a restaurant but I love adding extra rare beef to my pho at my own pace without worrying about it overcooking.
author: Jessica S.

description:
I was on a jury for nearly two months this past summer and Turtle Tower was a staple at the beginning of the trial. (Sidenote: did you know the court will provide free lunches from a restaurant across the street if you're on jury duty long enough? A fact I never needed to know first hand. Unfortunately this was not where the free lunches came from.)

Pros:
-Broth is good.
-The small size bowl of pho is a decent size if you're hungry. Seems most people I saw ordered this size.
-Fried chicken plate was tasty.

Cons:
-Might have a bit of a wait around 12-1:30 when most everyone has their lunch break at 850.
-Space. If you don't like being seated RIGHT NEXT to someone if you're a sole diner, don't come at peak lunch times. (I don't mind, but seriously some people need to mind their soup splatter as they slurp their noodles sometimes haha.)
author: Junelle T.

description:
This is probably my favorite place for pho in the city because of the clear broth, but they served us broken up pieces of noodles (I asked the waiter, and he said they had just gotten a new shipment of supposedly "handmade" noodles.) It seemed like what we got was the leftover pieces of the old bag! In addition to being broken, the amount of noodle was definitely subpar. The broth was also saltier than usual.

I echo one of the other reviewers' sentiments. It's fine that they don't have the regular southern style garnishes such as bean sprouts and basil, my husband actually prefers pho without. But could they not be so cheap? It'd be nice to at least be served a hearty bowl of soup with the basic amount and quality of noodles!!! It might be nice to have hoisin sauce and sriracha also.

So disappointed.
author: Vicky J.

description:
There are very few places I would brave torrential downpours or multiple MUNI transfers for, but Turtle Tower made the cut. My friends have long learned not to let me pick where to eat for weekend brunch because I will, without fail, default to TT - tendencies of a creature of habit. 

Nothing quite hits the spot after a night of dancing around in heels that the human feet were not evolutionarily adapted for than the Pho Ga, with chicken on the side paired with a serving of their lemon sauce. Every single time, the hot soothing broth and delectable noodles will trick me into believing that I do, indeed, absolutely need to finish the entire bowl until I've reached the bottom, sodium levels disregarded. It's become somewhat of a ritual for me by this point.

A general PSA for the 10% of the population who suffers the genetic misfortune of cilantro tasting like soap: if I were to take away the broth, chicken, and noodles, you would be left with essentially a cilantro salad. As I don't fall into this demographic, I fully embrace the herb heavy cilantro-to-soup ratio. 

2017: new year, new goals. Or in Turtle Tower's case, a new menu. Ask your server about the secret menu that's discreetly rolled out - I've been clued in that the secret F9 dish is an upgrade from my routine Pho Ga order (the noodles are pan fried first). Hat tip to Thé, one of the owners, whose comedic antics throughout my meal had me questioning whether my stomach hurt from laughing or from me attempting to consume a bowl that outsized my belly capacity.
author: Jenni H.

description:
The worst customer service ever I had. The lady didn't want us to come in because one of us had a skateboard. "A 22" mini skateboard"
 
She said that we should lock the bicycle with chain outside on the pole so she could let us in. What!? It was not a bicycle but a skateboard! Who had the lock for the skateboard and who actually leave this tiny skateboard outside?? We said it was just a skateboard so we can just put under our table. She said NO, there was no room for it. You don't have a room for 22"?

In the end, we didn't want to waste our time to argue with the lady explaining the differentiate between a bicycle and a 22" skateboard so we left. 

We will never came back again.
author: Monika W.

description:
One of my favorite pho places in town, I usually go to the one on Geary but this one opens later. Food quality wise they are pretty much the same. (A good thing!)

Note, they serve Northern style pho here, so the noodles are wider and softer. Not as chewy as the regular pho noodle.

Sometimes they have fresh soy milk here. Try asking for it next time you visit.
author: Joseph L.

description: This place was perfect for me today as I was short in time and had to be back in court with less than 30mins lunch.   Their service was fast, table over really reasonable!  I really have no complaints about the food as it's acceptable and not much different than any pho, however, it's the perfect place for warm soup while in court!
author: Tiffany Q.

description:
Absolutely nothing for vegetarians. Not even tofu. I'm allergic to eggs, I tried to get a Bahn Mi (eating with a group) and asked if they had a vegetarian option. Egg was all that was offered. Getting sit next to the bathroom means you're guaranteed to smell it too. So I'm stuck eating some basic stuff and smelling the bathroom. 

I've been to numerous Vietnamese joints where there was a huge array of vegetarian Bahn Mi that didn't have eggs, usually outnumbering the meat options. 

Never again
author: Duran S.

description: My go to pho spot when my husband and I area in the area and want pho. Most recently, I have ordered the pho with rare steak, and was quite impressed. What makes this place impressive you ask? They somehow charbroil their noodles before they put in the soup. Therefore, you have a somewhat different but quite tasty smokey flavor in your pho. Prices are SOMA prices for pho, but worth the trek if you can find parking.
author: Tracy C.

description:
Came here for lunch while serving for jury duty last week. I've heard good things about this place so I was kind of excited to try it. I was able to get seated before the big lunch crowd came.

I ordered a small bowl of the chicken pho and a side order of imperial roll. The first bite into the soup and I thought "Hm this is pretty good." The thicker cut noodles were cool. But as I continued to eat it I realized it's just whatever. It was decent. Would I go out of my way to come back though? No. 

Furthermore, the side order of imperial roll that I got was so tiny and partially burnt. It was just okay as well. Definitely not worth paying the $2.75 for, that's for sure.

Overall it was just okay. I think it's an alright place to get your pho fix while serving jury duty but if I had my choice I wouldn't come here otherwise. Sorry turtle tower, I had high hopes!

FYI: it's cash only!
author: Mellani L.

description: Ordered pho #4 large. The size of the bowl was def a large, but it's different from what I usually except in my pho experience. The broth was more watered down than I was expecting.  I guess that's a good thing if you're worried about sodium. Most of the ingredients were there: meats, briskets, tendons...but no bean sprouts and not much onions. On top of that no hoisin sauce. It reminded me of a more Americanized version of pho I had back in MD. If you're not too adventurous on trying foods outside the normal American fare this would be a good intro to pho.
author: Gordon L.

description:
Ordered the large #2 Pho Tai Rare Beef Pho this time, and it was just as delicious. The way they make their rare beef is prepped almost like a beef burger patty but easier to rip off with each bite. Wished there was more meat though. The soup has slightly more sodium than the #9 Chicken Pho, but it's still not too salty for a soup broth. I can't say if the #2 or the #9 is better since they're in their own categories, but with either dish, you really can't go wrong.

Also I got a banh mi to go (pate, ham, & pork). It's really dry and short in length, not worth the $5 price. You're better off finding a a good sandwich in the TL.
author: Kevin S.

description:
heathy light broth + easy to chew flat noodles + no lines like its TL counterpart + every dish under $10

I love Miss Saigon, also frequent Tin and 7 Mission. This is the "lightest" of the bunch. I usually come here after yoga (across from Ritual / Mint). 

The broth tastes the healthiest because it seems the most natural albeit less savory and you don't dilute it with sauce. The flat noodles are a pleasant change, they don't require much chewing. 

Pro tip: The beef stewed in wine is really rich / different, nice way to change it up if you also eat pho 2-3 times a week, but I usually stick with the 1 or 4 combos.
author: Roger L.

description:
What's the best food for hangovers, sick days, and rainy days? PHO! Today's lunch falls under rainy day weather and when I came at 15 minutes past noon, it was already packed with a line out the door that turned out was NOT people waiting for a bus. The wait wasn't too long but next time, I would come half an hour later just to skip the lunch rush.

It was my first time having Northern style pho and all my life, I've only had Southern style so I was a bit thrown off when observing everything. First off, 

-Northern style does not come with the beansprouts and basil plate that is usually in Southern style pho
-But you do get the jalapenos and limes
-There is no hoisin sauce
-But there is sriracha (in a jar container rather than in the bottle form)
-Noodles are flat and wider than Southern style pho
-Broth seems to be the focal point of the dish

I ordered the Pho Ga chicken noodle soup and it was delicious. The broth was cleansing and didn't taste like there was a bunch of MSG added. In fact, the broth elevated the taste of the noodles. The noodles absorbed much of the broth so I didn't even need to add any sriracha to make it taste better. There was a good amount of chicken to keep the balance well maintained and the Small size portion was perfect for me since I was able to finish the entire bowl and felt full but not overstuffed. 

Outside, the menu says Cash Only but I think they started to use Square now so they do take credit card. They have other items besides pho such as banh mi. Bowl sizes comes in just Small or Large and prices range from $6-9.
author: Diana C.

description:
Now... for months, I've actually avoided this particular Turtle Tower location. Service used to be abrupt, decor was bland and minimal, and they only accepted cash. Now, despite my prior unhappiness with this establishment, I had a huge hankering for pho on this chilly, rainy day. Being within the SoMa neighborhood, I thought I'd bite the bullet and give it another try. 

I am absolutely impressed by the newly remodeled interior. Modern colors lined with bright artwork, it felt like a whole new restaurant. I was quickly seated and began scanning the menu. Huh... I thought. Even with all the new decor, the prices are still extremely reasonable with a small bowl of pho ranging from $8, and a large bowl being approximately $9.50. Sweet!

Food came out quickly and even the service felt more upbeat. 

And oh yes, they now accept debit and credit cards! 

If you're looking for great Northern style pho, I think Turtle Tower would be a wonderful place for you to try. They certainly changed for the better.
author: Ann S.

description: There were two customers in the restaurant on a Wednesday night and they would not let a three year old use the restroom. That's the kind of joint this is, then no thanks.
author: Grace C.

description:
Excellent Vietnamese noodle soup. Turtle Tower serves northern style pho, so it might be different from what you're normally used to because the majority of Vietnamese pho restaurants here serve southern style pho. 

They're famous for their pho ga (chicken pho), but I personally LOVE the beef pho. Which beef pho? All of them. If you're adventurous, try them all out eventually. Otherwise you can never go wrong with the #1. 

There are three Turtle Tower restaurants in the city, and they are all 5 stars. It's ridiculous, that there's a discrepancy between them. Just goes to show that nobody knows anything, including yours truly.
author: Richard S.

description: I have lived a block away from this restaurant for years and seeing many people lineup for this restaurant. after  finally trying it out I was not impressed .
author: Greg H.

description: I rarely give one star but this place is really that bad. I got rice and pork and a banh mi and I trashed it. The pork was so so hard and overcooled. And the portions so small. The banh mi literally had no taste.
author: Tina L.

description:
~*~*~ 1200th review! ~*~*~

It is disappointing, really. I went to the original Turtle Tower location and really enjoyed their chicken pho, so I tried to rally my coworkers to come over here. 

The noodles were too soft, like the food was soaking in the broth for a while before they delivered it to our table - which made sense because we waited forrrrreverrrrrr for our food.

At the end of our meal, we were told their POS system stopped working. Their ATM didn't work either. Seemed like they had a network issue. We had to run to some place across the street to get cash. It was quite annoying that the staff didn't mention anything and they weren't very helpful either.

We have been back just to give them another chance, but they consistently run out of pate for their banh mi. We have never seen it in stock, which is quite a shame - if they don't have it, just don't put it on the menu.

I guess this location is a no go. I hope the other one I like hasn't gone downhill as well.
author: Alice C.

description:
Absolutely the worst experience I've ever had at any restaurant in my life! I'm a generous reviewer and from this experience I have no problem dishing a bad rating.

Today my lady and I visited Turtle Tower on 6th during lunch and had the pleasure *sarcasm* to be waited on by the biggest douchebag waiter/server I've ever dealt with. Viet guy with backwards baseball cap and jeans. Quite simply a jerk. Yeah you know who you are. And for the restaurant's sake I hope it was a heat of the moment thing and you don't do that again. 

Entering the restaurant just after the peak lunch crowd we were seated at a table for two by the door. Seeing that there were two tables by the window I asked if we could sit by the window to "people watch" and observe this part of the city I wasn't very familiar with. This guy says "sorry you have two people and those tables are for four. Thank you." I'm thinking... well okay that sucks but it is what it is. No worries. He was polite up to this point. 

After ordering from him I look around and see a large booth with only two people on the other side of the restaurant. A customer then walks in and sits down gesturing another server if he can sit at one of the empty tables by the window, a female worker, and she gives her approval and orders food soon thereafter. Well alrighty then. The same female server brings us water and I ask her if we can sit at the other table and she immediately approves. Great! Well is it really? I believe around this time is where the male server started to mentally snap. 


I started to enjoy the view from my new window seat. Finally I get to try this Turtle Tower location even with its almost decent 79 health score. After all it's better than the other two right?! I've been to the Larkin location once and Geary location several times in the past and enjoyed the Northern style Vietnamese noodle soup. I'm from San Jose so I'm well versed in Southern style for almost two decades, so I like mixing it up from time to time. 

Here comes the food! Wait what is this? The female worker brings us two bowls and neither looks like chicken, what my lady ordered, and the other has tripe. The male server heard us and steps in front of the poor female server with a menu and insists on what we ordered. 

I don't like tripe and I didn't order the dac biet (special). I keep it simple and always ALWAYS order Tai Chin (steak brisket) or chicken. I've done this a billion times yet this guy tells me this is what we ordered. Okay buddy so you're straight up telling me that we are liars in front of all the other customers with a straight face. 

My lady argues with him and he has the AUDACITY (I never use this word in real life!!!) to tell my lady what she said didn't matter and for me to speak. WTF??? I was only quiet at that point because I was blown away and annoyed beyond measure. I did my best to coherently explain to him (albeit in annoyed fashion) that we know what we ordered and what was brought to us wasn't it. I had enough and said "let's just go" and that's when the server dashed away. As we got up the (poor) female server. Was bringing the corrected order and said something along the line of "so you're not staying?" I felt bad for her. She was caught in the middle of all this and if I stayed at the original table none of this would have happened. Leaving in haste I replied to her "no, that guy is giving us attitude" and left. 

There was 7-8 customers there when we ran off. I hope other Yelpers were there to see what disservice was done to us. Perhaps they could give me reassurance or perhaps another perspective. I am a fair person and would love to hear all sides. Many thoughts go through my mind, but as a customer I feel I was truly given bad treatment. I mean was it wrong to request a table by the window when there were plenty? Was it wrong to ask again to another server? 

In any case this may be my first 1 star review for a restaurant and 2nd ever in my 10 years of Yelping. I really hope the last because my blood pressure is up the roof!!! Argh! Anyway keep it real folks and let the customer voices be heard!
author: David K.

description: It's pretty good place to get fun,but usually it's very busy at lunch time.sometimes it's pretty slow to get your food.still,it's worth to wait :)
author: Clancy Y.

description:
Turtle Tower serves northern vietnamese style pho!  I like to think of it as a clean, simple & no fuss.   It comes with the fresh noodles, cilantro, green onions, jalapenos, & a wedge of lemon.   You don't need hoisen sauce, basil, or extra veggies here.  It's still very soothing, delicious and perfect on a cold day.  They are known for the chicken pho- if you order this, ask for a side of the salt, pepper & lemon dipping sauce.   I prefer the Pho Chin- which is the well done flank & brisket beef noodle soup.

I've been having Turtle Tower delivered to my work via Caviar.  I even got most of my co-workers to order pho now so the office will sometime smell like a Vietnamese pho shop! Lol.

For fast delivery...Caviar brings the best restaurants straight to your door. Sign up to get $15 off your 1st @TryCaviar order using my link!   https://www.trycaviar.com/r/9tenrj

Happy eating!
author: Melanie N.

description: My friends and I come here all the time, if not every other day for pho. One of the best pho places in the area!
author: Long C.

description: Pretty good pho place that is on par with the Larkin location. Try to beat the local tech workers to lunch and you're gold.
author: Karl K.

description: All Turtle Tower locations in the city serve an honest bowl of northern Vietnamese pho featuring a tasty and clear chicken broth. My favorite option is the #3 giving me the richness of rare beef and brisket on top of my noodles, a yummy combination with their famous chicken broth.
author: Denny C.

description:
I kind of stopped coming to this location because the interior was pretty grimy and they didn't accept credit cards. But as of a couple months ago, they completely remodeled the place, take credit cards, and stopped wiping the tables with smelly rags! :)

The chicken pho is still superior to any pho ga in the city. The broth has a strong but clean chicken flavor. It's served very simple - with rice noodles, tender chicken, and some herbs and jalapenos. No distractions like hoisin or sriracha to deter from the chicken.

I also really like their rice vermicelli dish with imperial rolls served with herbs and nuoc cham. Super fresh and tasty. 

If you avoided coming here in the past because of the griminess - definitely come back and give it another shot!
author: Henry W.

description:
Dinner review. 

Chicken noodle soup - 3/5 - 7x7. 
Stewed beef in wine sauce - 2/5
Fried imperial roll - 2/5
Grilled pork - 2/5

Overall, "A-OK" for chicken noodle soup.
author: Mark O.

description:
I m having my dinner almost every week couple times.
Best soup in the town ever.
I hope the owner will read this , operation hours is till 9 pm I went @8.30 and stuff told me that they are closing . This is second time happening if there is one table around 8.30 they don't take. New table .
I like this restaurant I highly recommend especially chicken noodle soups I came long way and I was hungry and when I couldn't have sit I got little upset
author: Sezgin T.

description: Beef in red wine over rice for lunch was just gross. "Beef" was 80% fat. Not as in marbleized- just slabs of fat with a couple of shreds of meat clinging to each. Disgusting. And I am leaving just about as hungry as I came. Service is good, though.
author: Gail J.

description:
I know the popular dish here is just the chicken noodle soup, but y'all should really try #11.  It's the same soup and chicken but with another type of pork meat and egg shreds added to it!  

I had an awesome experience at this location.  Waiter seems like whatever but he's actually very informative and straight forward about his suggestions which I really appreciate.  Some waiters just say, everything is good, but we all know that's not the truth. This guy is honest with his recommendation.

Yes it's kinda pricy but this is the standard turtle tower experience we all know.  It get get busy during the meal times, expect to wait or come early before or after the rush!  I'd be back again if I'm close by.  Parking isn't easy in the city
author: Juila L.

description: We ordered Pho since that's what they're known for. I would give this place as 3 stars but since my husband and my brother liked the Pho here so I gave it a 4 stars. The Pho here is Pho Bac (Northern Pho) so it's definitely different than other Pho's I've been eating (we are from the South). Pho here has a very beefy aroma comparing to the herbs aroma at most other Pho places. This Pho doesn't come with basil leaves or bean sprouts. It's just beef broth, beef, and noodles. My husband and brother appreciated the simplicity of the Pho here but I rather the multi-flavored profile Pho with variety of beefy meats and tripe from the Midwest Pho.
author: Minh N.

description:
My boyfriend and I came in last week for an early dinner before our Wine and Cheese class at the SF Wine Center which was next door. This location of Turtle Tower is right off of the freeway in SOMA and in a very industrialized location. We came pretty early in the night and were the only ones there but as we left, most tables were taken.

I ordered the small #9 Pho Ga and A got a large #6 Pho Bo Ap Chao Nuoc. Our noodles arrived blazingly fast with the normal plate of bean sprouts, lime and jalapenos. My Pho Ga was exceptionally salty however the chicken was well-cooked and I imagine if you were sick, this would be a bowl of heaven. A small was the perfect size for me to finish but to be comfortably full. My boyfriend's food was also a bit salty but the beef was seasoned well and the grilled vegetables added a nice depth. He was able to finish his large as well.

For 2 people, this meal was quite cheap coming in around $20. Would I rush back? Probably not unless I was in the area where there aren't many other options. I do think that there are better bowls of Pho in the city but for this particular day, it worked just fine and hit the spot.
author: Carrie W.

description: I'm in SF w| 3 of my roommates. They're all hungover & we're from SD, so they wanted pho. We came here bc it was close by. 2 other tables along w| ours then all the sudden- the place FILLS up. One of my roommates ordered banh mi & the rest of us got pho. I guess north cali does it different. We got rice noodles in our pho, broth tasted like flavored water. No bean sprouts, no hoisin sauce, & no satay. Pho came out first & we all waited for the banh mi to start eating- we waited like 10-15 mins for the pho, which normally comes out within 5 in SD, & an additional 5-10 minutes for the banh mi. Tripe was pretty good. Thai tea was like two sips, I finished that thing so damn fast. It's so small & for 4.25? Not worth. Probably won't be back.
author: Vanessa B.

description:
I love it!  If you have to have jury duty, then at least you can go to good places for lunch like Turtle Tower on 6th and Bryant - perfect location!  Put your name down on the list though - just because you're standing in line and you didn't put your name down (doh!), doesn't mean you go first.  Food is served fast so people know to eat quickly to make room for more people to dine.  If you are by yourself and it's packed, they might seat you with one other person, but that's ok, you'll have company, plus you'll be so busy eating, you won't even have time to feel awkward.    

I always mean to try something else, but I always get the small pho ga (chicken noodle) with plenty of bean sprouts and cilantro. Mmm!  It's tasty, filling and super comforting to help you deal with the fact that you have jury duty or jury selection.  ;)  Oh and If you are falling asleep in the court room, get a Vietnamese iced coffee.  You might not be able to sit still, but you will be awake for sure! - just sweet enough and super tasty!  Enjoy!
author: Maile N.

description:
FOOD:
I got the chicken pho and it was good. The soup base is pretty bland but thats the way I like it. You get a lot of noodles in the small bowl and a lot of meat.. I couldn't even finish mine. 

SERVICE:
One guy took care of all 10 tables and I was a happy customer. Really good service.

WOULD I RECOMMEND IT? Maybe.
author: Kelley Y.

description:
Maybe it's just this location, but the pho here es no bueno compared to all the delicious pho I can get in San Jose. I've heard good things about the Turtle Tower in the tenderloin, but I would not come back to this location. 

The broth just doesn't have the right wow factor and the noodles are also not the right texture. It's just really sub par pho.
author: Mai Y.

description: Cannot believe turtle tower is of such an unfair rating. Their noodle is the best among all pho places in bay area. Made so soft and tasty.
author: Dylan L.

description:
As a Vietnamese student from Hanoi studying in San Francisco, I think this restaurant is 80% authentic of Hanoi cuisine. I would recommend tasting the "Combination of Rare Beef, Tripe, Well-done Beef Pho", because the broth and the noodles from the rare beef pho are flavorfully complemented. The beef was well done. However, I think there should be more herbs like culantro or basil for a perfect bowl of Pho.

A minus point is the "Beef Stewed in Wine Sauce Pho". The broth from  is too reddish and exotic (I think the restaurant put too much wine into the broth and little spice powder), which was a bit not too eye-catching. Normally the ideal color for this dish would be orange yellow.
author: Pemi N.

description: There were two of us and were seated at a 4 person table. An employee asked us if we wanted two other unknown patrons to sit with us at our table. We said no because the table was small. Then he angrily tells us he never should have seated us there if he knew we were going to say no. He raised his hands and shook his head causing a scene. F*uck u! I come here two or three times a month because I work nearby and you treat us like that! We will eat somewhere else next time.
author: Ant C.

description:
I have been coming here for years. Their broth is sooo good so I don't add anything except the diced jalapeños that are provided. 

Service is always accommodating, and they deal well with the hungry hordes that arrive, daily. Turtle Tower is a bright spot in the nabe.
author: Janet C.

description: Like so many before me, I have to recommend the (off menu) F9 (Special Chicken Pho). It was a huge, reasonably priced, incredibly flavorful broth, big chunks of tasty chicken, amazing spices, tasty noodles, and just a few veggies to add to the whole thing. Perfect on a rainy, chilly day like today. The Vietnamese coffee was also tasty, though a little small. Definitely coming back to get the F9 again, or possibly the P9 (which comes with extra protein)!!
author: Jeffrey S.

description:
I'm about to drop some news more shocking than a Trump presidency....THERE IS A SECRET MENU at turtle tower!!! 

Everyone knows the traditional beef or chicken noodle soups at TT but there are also off menu beef and chicken variations which have additional items to enrich the flavors. The secret beef item is the "K6" and the chicken is the "F9" which denote the variation since number 6 on the menu is beef and 9 is chicken. I tried the F9 which came with extra toppings such as sliced viet ham(I think), some other chicken meat and some bits of ginger. There was even more in the soup but I couldn't identify the frenzy of ingredients involved. What I do know is that it was absolutely delicious. The broth is richer and there's so much more meat that you get a piece with almost every bite. The broth is still clean and not oily despite all the extra flavors involved. I can't wait to try the beef variation.

The best thing about secrets is sharing them. Live a little and try these secret items, you won't be disappointed.
author: James K.

description:
4 for food. 3 for service. 3 for atmosphere. 

Turtle Tower is a great place if you want consistency and a homey meal. 

This was my first time eating real Pho in SF. It is North Vietnamese style pho. I had the well mentioned PHO GA (chicken) which was very clean and well seasoned. Chicken in the PHO GA was ok and same with the noodles (they get a little mushy toward the end). I'm usually sensitive to very salty things (I feel my eyes get puffy) and I ate the entire bowl and did not get that feeling. 

No need for hoisen sauce (nor is there any). If you like the kick just dip your noodles in the red chili sauce from time to time. 

We also tried the fresh SPRING ROLLS, which were OK, but I'd opt for a side of the DIA GA LUOC (steamed chicken with bones) or something related to their very clean and enjoyable broth.
author: Patrick M.

description: Usually theres always a crowd whenever i pass by here during lunch time so i was seated right away by the counter at the window when i finally decide to come here for lunch since i came by myself. But of course this place will always be busy doing lunch time especially that this place isnt big too. Usually i dont like to seat near to the restroom but had no choice. Anyways, Took them awhile to get my order after i got seated. I decided to get Pho Ga Long, large size for $10.50. Waited about 10-15 minutes to get my food.  As i was getting my food, the waiter accidentally spill out some the broth to the booth table and little bit on the floor. He left and came back to apologize for pouring out the broth while trying to wipe the wet spot....he was mentioning about how i was sitting since i was sitting between couple people which it make it harder for him to give my food. Anyways, that was nice of him to apologize. As for the food that i got, although i got large, the size looks more like a medium size bowl...i notice people who had small bowls are quite small. The food itself was alright/average. Nothing special. Okay amount of meat. I thought the noodle was a little saggy and more small pieces of noodle. I feel they may put a lot of msg or fish sauce in the broth since i could feel a little saltiness in my mouth as an after taste. And i thought the price is kinda pricy. Anyways it was still good enough to get me full and warm my body up during the raining day
author: Julie N.

description:
The food is kind of boring. I had some salad-wrapped spring rolls, which had a remarkably bland flavor, despite containing shrimp and pork. I also had a chicken-vegetable stir fry, which just tasted kind of weird. I guess there was some lemon in the gravy? Not my cup of tea.

Fair disclosure: I'm not usually really into Vietnamese food, so it's unsurprising that I wasn't too enthused by this restaurant. I am probably not the best judge of the quality here.
author: John L.

description:
The food is excellent and authentic. A Vietnamese friend took me there and I loved it! Food and service were amazing!

The restaurant lost points in cleanness and atmosphere but overall, it is definitely worth a try.
author: Rim K.

description: Yum yum!  My girl friend brought me here to have a casual lunch and I loved it!  She told me they are known for the chicken broth, so that's what I got. I am not into gizzards and the like, so i asked for extra liver in the bowl that i ordered, and they delivered!  I loved it, and I won't mind coming back. We did have to wait a bit for a table, but after we were seated everything went quickly.
author: Tracy L.

description:
A+ star chicken pho! Get the #10 large. Won't regret it. Except for maybe if you're not into chicken guts. Then get 9.

Really stepped up their game recently!
author: Minku L.

description: Probably the best northern style pho thai in San Francisco! Love it!!!
author: Dave M.

description: My favorite pho in the city. The noodles are homemade and melt in your mouth. I think this place gets better with each visit for some reason.
author: Jeanette V.

description: Disappointing. I ordered a beef pho, and imperial rolls. The broth of the pho was really good and tasty, however, they put four small pieces of meat in my soup and that's about it. They could have been a little bit more generous on the meat. The imperial rolls were ok. Not great but not bad either. I'm still a little bit confused and don't really know how to feel about this place. It's just average.
author: Constance P.

description: I don't quite understand the 3 stars for this incredible tasting noodle soup! I order the large chicken noodle soup for take out usually and it's the best broth, noodles and chicken. They use Free range btw. The price is more than reasonable and everything tastes refreshing! How much better can it get?! Highly recommend.
author: Jenna C.

description: There are NO vegetarian options on the menu. And not even any fish or prawn options. I finally convinced them to give me veggies and rice and it was celery with a few carrots. Is it that hard to do better?
author: robin c.

description: This place is amazing. The pho ga is the most flavorful chicken soup I may have ever had. Both the rice and the egg noodles are great! Prices are unbeatable.
author: Nick A.

description:
No bike parking.

Beef Leek Celery Noodle soup: 3 stars
Got it with the Pan-fried Noodles but they tasted burnt in the first mouthful. Kind of like beef hor fun thrown into noodle soup, but with tougher beef than the tender hor fun cuts. Satisfying but could be better.

Imperial Roll: 3.5 stars
Perfectly crispy but the fillings are too fine, minced meat and noodles all melting with the first bite. I prefer my rolls with more give, filling the mouth.

Fried Cuttlefish Patty: 2 stars
Tough, chewy.
author: Letitia L.

description: I went there first time craving pho and unfortunately was disappointed . The service was amazing though don't get me wrong but the food quality was not. The noodles seem soggy and it just didn't have the taste of pho.
author: Anna O.

description: Amazing food! I love their pho tai! It's clean and crisp!
author: KT D.

description: Stopped by prior to jury duty since it's right across the street. First time there, decided to try Bahn mi grilled chicken sandwich. I don't know if they forgot to put sauce, but the sandwich was dry and flavorless. Very small sandwich and dry bread. Carrots were not pickled with any flavor. The grilled chicken was good but overall very disappointing sandwich and I won't be back.
author: Kudos K.

description: Love me some North Vietnamese cuisine! We saw an open parking spot on a rainy night and decided to run in with the kiddo. They quickly saw that we had a car seat and sat us in the corner to give us space to tuck him away. The service here is really fast and extremely friendly. You get in, order, eat and pay. I typically get #5 (stir-fried beef with celery, carrot, onion, and leek noodle soup) and my husband loves their #6 which is almost the same as #5 but the noodles are pan fried. He likes the smokey flavor but I find it a tad too oily for my liking. It doesn't really matter though because both are really delicious. In fact, all of their soup noodles are wonderful and great on a rainy day. I also got a sandwich of pork, pate and fried egg. You get to choose three items. My sandwich was awesome and it bums me out that the Turtle Tower on Geary doesn't serve the sandwiches. Oh wells. At least I know I can get my fill here on 6th Street. I'm so glad they opened one here where I can get dinner on my way home.
author: Jen L.

description:
The bun cha hanoi is absolutely delicious - do yourself a favor and try something new! The banh mi however is not as exciting as other places in the city, e.g. saigon sandwich and what not. For what its worth, i thought the chicken banh mi was better than the pork, more moist and flavorful.

Also, I had quite a bit of problem attempting to call in an order tonight (12/10/16). Phone kept ringing and going to voicemail. Eventually just walked over and placed a togo order in person. The waiter claimed that the "cell phone doesn't get reception", but while I was waiting I heard what sounded like a landline ring several times w/o being answered by the staff. Not counting this against them, but it is definitely something that should be addressed.
author: William W.

description:
Before yesterday I was pretty convinced that you can never go wrong with any Pho place, well I was wrong..

I ordered the #1 and was not completely pleased with it to say the least. Broth had a funky odor- not a good one. Noodles were different but can't complain because it stated they were rice noodles. Anyways, I did not get to the bottom of that bowl of pho for the first time ever :-( Sad! Also the spring rolls were bland. I'm disappointed thinking of it now.

All in all- 2 stars because service was not bad and my coke was good.

I don't know about this place, but it wasn't my cup of Pho.
author: Kathleen S.

description: This is my favorite place to get pho! I love the broth and the meat that comes with the beef pho. It's so tender and falls apart.
author: Jolene L.

description:
The Pho here follows the Northern Vietnamese style (very rare in the Bay area, as the rest of the Pho options are all Southern style - slightly sweeter). Hoisin sauce and side veggies is a Southern style thing, so don't expect it here.

Defo should order Pho Ga, if you are adventurous, get the Pho Ga Long (with intestines). Yummy but the quality is not consistent - some days it's much salty, some days are perfect. 

I also tried the Stir fried Pho - super yum - no broth, will beef
 
The sticky rice is also an okay option if you are still hungry.

I come here coz they open for dinner (as opposed to the Tenderloin joint). Service is great, A+, polite and speedy.
author: Connie T.

description:
Okay okay, I know I come here waaayyy too often, and sometimes the food is better or worse than other times, but Turtle Tower is truly my favorite pho I have ever experienced. There is nothing I don't like about the ambiance, the noodles, the meat, the veggies. It's all good, just not really consistently so. 

Last time I went, I brought my friend who had never ever had pho (!!) and he liked it a lot. I recommended that he try the chicken noodle soup, which is what they're known for, or rare steak, but he wanted to try the same one I get, Pho Sot Vang. I don't usually recommend this to people who haven't had pho because it's so different, and because both of my roommates have pretty much knocked it, but what do they know about Vietnamese food!? Anyway he liked it, and though the service was slow, the food was on point.
author: Crystal C.

description:
New management is rocking it! 

New upgrade on the restaurant's look but still with the AMAZING food!

Keep it up!
author: Micael B.

description: We ordered Pho noodles and it came out luke warm as if it had  been sitting there for about 15 minutes before being brought out. Was not very impressed with the food however the server was nice.
author: R B.

description: Came here today and the service was ok but not the best. They don't refill your water cups or check up on you. The pho soup is kinda bland there's nothing really special about it and me and my friend paid $12 each for a small bowl of pho. (That's including tips). In my opinion you can get a big bowl of pho elsewhere that will get you full and taste more authentic. They don't even give you basil leaves or bean sprouts like any other place. YOU DEFINITELY WILL NOT BE FULL!
author: Ruby F.

description:
Not tasty at all. I don't want to explain how bad. The noodle ever doesn't taste when I was super hungry !
Get a cup noodle friends!
author: Jat L.

description:
Chicken soup giblets is yum but dont
Expect service or extra napkins. You get one napkin every time you ask for some. They never check on you or ask you anything. There is usually a wait. If you dont want to wait, just go a few doors down for the same soup but with better service and a little tastier.
author: Theresa M.

description:
I just ate here less than an hour ago and I haven't stopped raving to my housemates about how great the service was. If you value service like I do, you will like this place. The owner was so sweet and gave me extra clean broth to take with me when I took my leftovers to go. 

It was my first time so I listened to the yelp reviews and got the F9, which is from the secret menu. It's very unique and tasty, because the noodles were stir fried beforehand, it had a lot of flavor. However, if you don't like heavier greasiest broths then this one is probably not for you. 

Excited to come back and try the other dishes !
author: Amy S.

description:
Since moving to SF last year, I've seriously been searching for a good ol fashioned hole in the wall style legit pho restaurant near my place. THE search is OVER! I've been her for dinner twice now and I order pho #3 every time! The food is delicious, the meat is plenty and the noodles are fresh! I really can't say anything bad about their food.
My only complaints: wooden/disposable chopsticks are pretty lame for a sit-down style restaurant (don't roll your eyes!) and it can be hard to get the server to notice your table. But I mean, those hardly reasons not to try this place.

Will be back again and again!
author: Anisa M.

description: I love turtle tower.  I either get the chicken and giblet soup or the pork patties with vermicelli.  It northern Vietnam style cooking and it's the bomb.  And don't knock it even if it sound weird.  Try it before you judge it people.  It's a small place like their original location was but still the pho is the shizzz!
author: Mary B.

description:
The Pho Ga hits the spot - chicken broth and scallions are so comforting. Chicken strips dipped in sriracha add a little flavor. 

The fresh spring rolls were just ok.

I think the Tenderloin Turtle Tower is better overall.
author: Inga C.

description:
There's a line out the door by 11:40 am as the place is tiny (get your name on the clipboard dangling from the inner door handle), but service is pretty quick and the food is very satisfying. This Northern style pho stock is lighter and less salty than other, Southern pho restaurants. The wide rice noodles are excellent.

The menu goes far beyond pho, including some substantial rice plates and banh mi.

Much more research is warranted!
author: Mutant O.

description:
More like 3.5 stars...

I'm not a huge pho lover or maybe I've just never had amazing pho in my life, but Turtle Tower is solid! I ordered the chicken noodle soup and they have the best broth I've ever had! It didn't feel like it was doused in MSG or salt. It felt clean and I'm pleased that they were generous with the chicken. Bonus points for meaty pieces of chicken, also -- it wasn't just chunks of fat and skin! I also love how the bowl was filled with cilantro and veggies. I'll definitely be back. I'm sure this would be the perfect place for a hangover ;)
author: Janet H.

description: I tried their secret menu F9. I'm a big fan of pho and this pho ga is a must-to-try. What's special about this pho is that they pan-fry the noodles so they have the barbecue flavor. Note that the noodles are very soft (maybe they overcooked mine). The broth and the chicken were okay but the noodles are the jam. Overall it's very rich and savory but it could be a little greasier than average pho ga. It's served with lots of green onions and cilantro but no sprouts or basil. They have only one size, huge bowl for this menu and it's $12.5. People are very nice too:)
author: Diana Soyeon B.

description:
I think this place is very mixed. Some things you can get here well done, other dishes are just mediocre. Service is definitely subpar though, unless you get what you want.

The dishes definitely fall under the cheaper end of the spectrum. I think this place does their chicken pho really well - you have nice wide noodles, a good amount of meat (plus more with the giblets) and a very clear broth with a strong chicken flavor. Do keep in mind they don't have a lot of hoisin sauce or whatever other add-ons you might be used to - what you see is you get. 

On the other end, I don't think their beef pho is very good, many places definitely do it way better.

As for service, it's inconsistent because I keep getting different employees. While some people are alright, other people don't speak English as well and may get items on your order wrong or completely missing. Kind of terrible, but nothing you can really do to avoid it. At least I haven't been overcharged for anything yet.

In the past this place seemed infallible to me. But now I see it as a small joint with a couple good offerings but not without its flaws.
author: Dave N.

description:
Came here on a HowAboutWe date which included two bowls of pho, two coffees, and an order of eggrolls.

When we arrived, there was a crowd of people waiting to get in.  When I went to the front counter to give my name, the woman seemed irritated and was short with me - probably due to the afternoon rush.

After about a 10 minute wait, we sat down at our little table near the bathroom.  The interior is modest, if not slightly dingy.  

The same woman seemed to have a change in attitude and politely explained our choices.  We had a bowl of the traditional beef pho and the "chicken noodle soup" with eggrolls. She even poured our Vietnamese coffees for us (strong as hell, but good).
