Now, I'm Vietnamese American and am a little embarrassed to admit that this was my first time tasting Northern style.  The taste of the beef pho....surprised me. It was oily and had a grilled taste that overpowered the broth.  There was no hoisin or siracha. 

It wasn't bad, by any means, but just different than what I'm used to.  I found it to be lacking the complex and hearty flavors of Southern pho - it was simple and just okay. 

The chicken noodle soup was actually my preference over the beef pho, though it was also very basic.  The eggrolls were fine.  

Overall, just kind of a ho-hum experience.
author: Trish P.

description:
I ordered the Com Thit Nuong which includes meat, rice, and some sort of sauce.

For $11, I didn't think it was worth it because I was left still extremely hungry and it was a big serving.

However, I praise them for a tasty dinner. I must say, the unknown sauce gave it a huge boost of flavor and ended up pouring it everywhere on top of my rice and meat!
author: Aj C.

description:
The first thing I look for wherever I travel or live, is a good pho place with a great pairing of cafe sua da (vietnamese/french) coffee.  Then, theres the chance where you get two in one.  Turtle Tower is definitely both.  

My in-dining experience has been nothing short but magnanious. And so has my take out experience. The food was still hot and fresh even when I took it home eon a 15-20 minute ride through the city.  That's rare. 

They speak vietnamese, and coming from a vietnamese cultural background, I won't eat in a place where they don't speak the language. 

On a Saturday, Sunday or holiday, I would suggest getting there 20-30 minutes ahead of time to prevent too long of a wait.  Although, the other bonus is they take card, but cash is always a plus. 

Favorites:

1. Rare Beef 
2. The meatballs
3. Eggrolls
4. Vietnamese French Press Coffee
5. Rice plate with beef and bones
author: David D.

description: Turtle tower has fresh chicken. The noodles are soft and silky. Once you go in, you can smell the broth.  The broth is very refreshing but a little bit greasy. I recommend turtle tower if you want a good warm bowl of noodle soup to comfort your stomach.
author: Heidi Y.

description:
I ordered the pho ga with no skin and all white meat.  The server failed to deliver on my simple requests.  The pho at this location is given with less green onions and cilantro than their other locations.  Service is a bit on the slower side as well.  Only one server was working every table.  

Overall, Turtle Tower is still one of my favorite pho places.  We can only hope that they don't disappoint me the next time I visit.
author: Victor L.

description: My first time came here, waitress not only did not serve water but said water is sold separately in a bottle
author: Dr Rose S.

description: Came here a couple times while visiting SF more out of convenience. But to my surprise, the food was quite decent. Most notably, I really like their salad rolls. Coming from Vancouver where there are a million pho places throughout the city, I have to say Turtle Tower has the best salad rolls. I think it's the way they grill the meat beforehand. Delicious. The pho is also very homey. It doesn't taste like your conventional pho but soup is more pure. Now, I don't know if that's true or not since I'm told that MSG is a must in any pho soup but there was just a comforting feeling about it. If I lived in SF, I'd be here when in need of some comfort food.
author: Wesley W.

description: The imperial roll is INCREDIBLE. First time having Vietnamese food and WOWI KAZOWIE. SO GOOD!! Awesome service and the new remodel is amazing.... can't wait to try their secret menu next time.
author: Justin G.

description: $10 bucks for a small pho ? Noooooooooo!! I love this place, been coming here for years. Please change the price back please! I can't afford a $10 dollar small pho!
author: Huilin H.

description:
My coworkers come here pretty regularly for lunch. It's the only place in the city that I know of that's well known for their chicken pho, and it's always on point.

I highly recommend the chicken pho or the chicken pho with giblets if you like that kind of thing. They also have new "secret menu" versions that are really good. They add ham to it and something else, and it tastes a little saltier/richer than the regular versions.
author: Gary Y.

description:
I love what they did with the interior. New flooring, some new seating arrangement, decor...I was told that this will be how turtle tower looks like for the other locations too and there will be more turtle towers opening (yay)! Great service today, and they are really open to feedback. Food seems at the same level as before.
AND THEY TAKE CREDIT CARD NOW! :D
author: Emma Y.

description:
recently I've started getting into pho,  not sure what all the other  people here are talking about but I love this pho place.

Its one of the best I've had lately.

You can really taste the great moistness of the meat and the sauciness of the soup.

I love the sauces, they're all good.

The desserts are great too.

This is a great comfortable place for groups and I love the location.

Parking has always been good for me here.

The prices are really decent too.
author: Luke S.

description: Manager would not accommodate us because we are 2 people and he only has table for 4 people. He said you have to share table with 2 more people because he wants to generate more money for having 4 people in a table. We declined because we want privacy in our table. And then we waited and waited and again manager wants us to share table with other people. We just left. ZERO star.
author: Joe K.

description: Gosh, its been 4 years since I've been here?  How could that be.  Prices gone up.  Had my favorite chicken pho with lots of cilantro floating and slivers of good free range chicken.  I normally don't drink the soup, but the soup is so good for these sad cold summer days of sf.  There is free parking after 6 pm so this place is great for after work crowd.  Service is great with this young guy.  Can you imagine this place is run by the young guy and the Mexican cook in the kitchen?  Amazing.  This is Hanoi style and they emphasize on the menu that there is no bean sprouts or basil or mint leaves.  Chili pepper comes with it.  Afterwards, i feel so satisfied, better than Jewish chicken soup.
author: Helen L.

description:
If you are looking for a quick meal that is also mind-blowingly awesome, this is the place to be!  The first and only thing you should ever try here is the #9, pho ga aka chicken pho aka heaven in a bowl.  I cannot rave enough about the chicken pho!

Inside secret:  ask for some lemon pepper sauce to dip your chicken in.  The sauce is made of salt, pepper and lemon juice but if you dip the chicken in that sauce AND also dip it in sriracha, it will completely change the way you eat chicken pho!
author: Christy Y.

description: So good! Brought my family from Vietnam here, while they were visiting and they all approved! I called ahead for a party of 10, and Kevin got us in right away. Great customer service and the food came out promptly. Definitely coming back.
author: Steph T.

description: Hands down, best damn pho I've ever had. Great customer service, water is always filled to the top and the decor... very modern. Lunch time is crazy because of the local business surrounding the restaurant. Worth coming either way.
author: Dang D.

description: The chicken pho here is so good! Came here with my friends and the staff was really friendly. Despite previous reviews they let us use our credit card to pay. I'll be coming back here since it's right around the corner from my place!
author: Andrea H.

description:
The last time I had to go in for jury duty (which, thankfully, was a while ago...though I probably just jinxed myself), the silver lining was knowing I'd be walking over to Turtle Tower for lunch.  While I really don't mind performing my civic duty, clearly my nice, hot bowl of Pho Ga was the highlight of my day.  Well, that and not having to serve.  Which I probably just jinxed for next time as well...

Although I've yet to try all that the city has to offer, Turtle Tower's Pho Ga has been the best one I've come across so far.  Nice meat-to-noodle ratio, tender noodles, and a fairly flavorful broth that's not overly salty.  For whatever reason though, it didn't seem quite as good at this location (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/turtle-tower-restaurant-san-francisco-3?select=qPxHdydcJr9tM9QTa4xC_w#pWGE4eqATQsTawjfLTXHEA).  I don't know if the broth didn't have enough seasoning or if the balance was off, but it just wasn't as satisfying as normal.  Still decent, but not satisfying.

Given its close proximity to the courthouse, it should be noted that it gets mighty busy during peak lunch hours.  If you're here on your own, don't be surprised if you end up sharing a four-top with someone you don't know, and for service to be hurried so that they can turn the table over for the next party(s).

Despite the service, the Pho Ga broth is the main reason why this Turtle Tower location only gets three stars while the one on Geary got a four (haven't reviewed the one in the TL yet).  That said, even if the pho had been perfect, I don't know if I could ever give any Turtle Tower five stars.  Not when this tiny, mediocre-at-best imperial roll cost me $2.15 (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/turtle-tower-restaurant-san-francisco-3?select=qPxHdydcJr9tM9QTa4xC_w#r8u6AjD3URInAosLik8zxw).

Then again, I guess it's my fault for forgetting from my first time and ordering it again.  Whoops.
author: Mike L.

description:
I gave it 3 stars because the food was meh, but the service was good. Perhaps it's because I didn't order the right thing..

I've heard good things about Turtle Tower, but never really wanted to drive out to downtown for it. Being in the area due to jury duty, I decided to give it a shot instead of sleeping in my hot car during lunch..

Service was good, but the dish I ordered wasn't so great. Their menu for this location didn't have much options, as compared to the one I am seeing online at the moment. I wanted to try their probably-famous-pho, but it was such a hot day, I decided to opt for grilled pork over steamed rice ($7.75). The pork is the most important meal of the plate, and it was dry. I was quite disappointed. Their sauce for the dish didn't make it any better as expected. Their guava juice however comes in a can and honestly, I felt like that was the best thing I had. I should've given this place another chance, but it's been so hot lately, so maybe in the winter. 

Just a warning to all, try their probably-famous-pho! Don't get the grilled pork!! Also, they only accept cash here.
author: Mandy G.

description: Number 9 chicken noodle soup is really good but sometimes if I'm feeling intestines I get the number 10. Coffee is nice but takes awhile
author: Cm Tú Đ.

description:
Of all the Turtle Tower restaurants, I think this one is the least favorite of them all.

On a early Saturday morning lunch at around 11:30am, There were open tables but they were not cleaned up and still had bowls and dirty dishes left there.

It seems like they are a bit unorganized here when it comes to seating and cleaning tables.
author: Kenny L.

description:
My favorite is the Combination Rare Beef, Tripe and Well Done Beef Noodle Soup!  It is very tasty and the broth was full of flavor.  I've also tried the Chicken Noodle Soup, which was tasty as well.  I only wish that they would remove the skin from the chicken!  The pho noodles resemble more like "Haw Fun" and it is not served with bean sprouts!  I believe it's from a different part of Vietnam.  

Service is good and workers are friendly, but often a very long wait during lunch time. They have a sign in sheet at the door, but you know it may be awhile when you see folks congregating outside.
author: Steven L.

description:
I ate chicken pho and spring roll.
Regular size Pho is only ＄7!
It tastes good and very reasonable.
author: Kayoko K.

description:
Like the others say: best pho place around.....no comparison.

You want pho---you go here. ;)

We are testing pho on both sides of the bay....this place is a clear winner.
author: Laurence T.

description:
Turtle Tower is Northern Pho so it's a refreshing change from the more common Southern pho with thin noodles, bean sprouts, hoisin sauce, and basil. The noodles are wider and the broth is more simple. If you get one thing for lunch/dinner, you must get the Pho Ga! 

-- Food / Drink --
-------------------
Pho Ga ($7): The pho came with lemon and jalapeno slices. I always squeeze at least two lemon / lime slices into my broth to top it off. The broth was not too salty and the chicken was surprisingly not dry. I never order Pho Ga at other places because the chicken has always been so dry and shreddy that it's disgusting and inedible. Also, portion sizes here are humongous! The small is more like a medium-sized bowl. I ordered a small and could not finish all my noodles. And I eat a lot! One thing that I would have liked -- the broth could have been warmer. 

Fresh Spring Rolls ($5.50): Each order includes four mega spring rolls and comes with peanut sauce. One spring roll was more than enough for me. I liked the long pieces of green onion and how the roll had less mint than normal.  

Three Color Bean Dessert($3.15): Compared to the dessert chain Bambu, the three color bean dessert drink is more watered down and less sweet. The jelly was also soft but maybe it's because we got the last two drinks and they were sitting there the entire day. 
-------------------

I've heard mixed reviews about Turtle Tower but in the end, I liked the pho. I would come back to try the various beef pho's and also get another bowl of the pho ga! 

** It's cash only but there's an ATM inside. The restaurant was packed on a Thursday night but we only waited 10 minutes to get a four person table.
author: Ingrid C.

description: So happy to find a great pho place here in SoMa! Service was speedy and the pho was delicious! Expect some slight differences to the Southern Style Pho which is more common but this Northern style is equally if not more tasty! Meat and noodles were plentiful and the broth is garnished just right! Definitely planning on coming back!
author: Alex P.

description: Broth and noodles are pretty good. Their take on the Tai beef is a bit unusual; thick...not bad at all. Cilantro is already in the soup; not on the side...which is weird. No basil...chopped jalapeño peppers on the side...lemon  instead of lime. Still pretty good; but just a bit different. Just slightly lame; but acceptable...On the downside, the broth at this location is even more light-bordering-on-bland than the original...so if you like a bit of body' this ain't the pho for you.
author: Max O.

description: Perfect for a rainy lunch trip. It gets quite packed but the service is quick and the pho (I got beef) and the egg rolls are delicious. Definitely worth the line.
author: Pawanpreet G.

description:
I really hate giving bad reviews but this was place extremely annoying. I am definitely bummed because I heard good things about this place. First thus place does not serve hoisin sauce but I was aware of this so that was not a big deal. But if you need that in your pho, you have been warned. 

Right when we walked in they told us to sit down but did not give us menus. We ended up grabbing them from another table. The waiter finally came over and asked if we were ready. We told him no and instead of walking away he hoovered over us until we were ready.  After being rushed to order, we got the pork plate with extra meat and rare pho  noodle soup. I asked for extra meat on the side. I also asked for imperial rolls and water.

When I received my soup there was no extra meat. There were two small pieces of meat so I asked the waiter if I was going to get it. He said it was in my soup. I never found more then two pieces. What was annoying is that my friend also asked for extra meat on his plate and they gave me a plethora of extra meat. After we were finishing up our meals we finally got our tiny imperial rolls that were 2.50 each. I'm not even kidding that these rolls were bite size. 

After we finished our meal we asked for more water. They gave us water in child size cups and were getting annoyed that were asking for more water. When we finally got the bill we asked to spilt it between cash and card. They refused. So once again we were forced to pay all cash. 
The food was okay but the service was awful. I will not be going back.
author: Nia R.

description:
Mannnn, I don't know if it was that day or if it was me but I did not have a good expereince at Turtle Tower. 

My friend and her boyfriend love this place, so I decided to try it out with her. The server was super sweet and nice but the place was a little dirty. They sat us down, but there was noodles and soup all over the table and seat. (I don't mind, I understand he was busy) I ordered the chicken noodle soup, and we got it extremely fast. 

Something about the soup turned me off, it had a weird stench to it, to the point where it didn't smell clean. I ended up giving my roommate all my chicken and tried to go for the noodles and soup. I liked that the noodles were thick comparing it to the other pho, but it was reallllllyyyy soggy. 

I am hoping the next time I go, it will be a better taste! I want to love you, Turtle Tower, I really do... 

Tasty Tip: I don't have one...
author: Brittany P.

description: Had the number 5 with chicken and its plain out right amazing.  I can't say enough how tasty the soup was without it having it taste like msg.  Great lunch spot as they are quick and fast service.   They do have a few more locations in the city so you do have options.  A must try if you like Pho.
author: Jon L.

description:
Pros: best pho in the city hands down. I prefer pan fried need and veggies soup it gives the broth a crazy good meaty flavor.

Cons: non existent service. They should just cut the pretense and setup water to be self service. It would improve things a lot vs trying to flag down the apathetic staff.

So 5 for the food and 1 for the staff = 3. I eat here often so I'm willing to overlook the service but I don't tip them anymore.
author: Mike C.

description:
The surrounding area has no crowd or anything enticing besides this restaurant.  The location to have this restaurant there seems random, but if you want to dine in seclusion, this place is it!  

Their Chicken Noodle Soup Vietnamese Style tastes the same here.  

At least you can pay by credit card and not only cash.  It is the smallest Turtle Tower compared to the other two places in San Francisco.  Inconvenient that it is closed on Sundays.
author: Tiffany D.

description:
The boyfriend and I came here on New Year's Day to satisfy our pho craving. The place was packed but we didn't wait longer than 15 minutes or so. Both of us opted for the #4 which is a combination of rare beef, tripe, and well done beef.  We decided not to get rice plates or any other side dishes since the pho is what this place is known for. 

We've both only tried southern style pho so this was different. No hoisin, bean sprouts, or basil given as garnishes, and the noodles were much thicker. Just green onions, and a side of jalapeños and lime. 

After the first sip of soup, our eyes were as round as saucers because it was sooooooooo delicious. I can't explain it, but it just tasted so much "cleaner" without all the frills of the pho I'm used to. The thicker noodles complemented it so well too! 

That's why this place gets 5 stars because when I'm craving pho, I will no longer be craving southern style pho. It will definitely be northern style pho! Next visit I'll have to try their Pho Ga (chicken pho).
author: Jessica I.

description:
Very cutty place on the corner of 6th and Bryan. I come here because it is one of the few pho places around soma and when u craving pho u need your pho. This place is northern pho so it isn't your typical pho with the basil, bean sprout, and thin noodles. This place has thick noodles with a very distinct but satisfying soup taste. I get the pho dat biet, with the steak on the side and the steak is dank. 

Definitely recommend this place for lunch but reminder its cash only!!!
author: Joe Z.

description:
DON'T GO HERE!

Under any circumstances even if this was the last Vietnamese restaurant on earth.

Service: Horrible. We were served by a old Vietnamese man with a terrible attitude.

Waiting time: I literally saw the cooks just sit and fool around while me and my girlfriend were waiting for our order to be made.

Condiments: Has insects in them... not surprising when their inspection score is 79, Which most places in San Francisco are 90+.

Food: Horrendous. I've been to many Vietnamese restaurants in San Francisco and this one has the worse food I've ever eaten in my life. The chicken pho had only noodles and soup with nothing else. The chicken rice dish or #16, had charred vegetables and overcooked chicken meat that wasn't de-tendoned or de-boned. 

I would hardly consider this to be in any sense of the word a "restaurant" because the food is so terrible that between this and day old sushi from a gas station, I would gladly choose the latter.
author: Sam C.

description: Nothing hits the spot like a delicious bowl of northern Vietnamese style chicken noodle soup (pho ga)!  This time, I ordered off the "secret menu" and got the F9 pho ha which came with some extras (julienned pieces of the fancy pork, some pieces of the rice noodles pan fried with corn oil which created some more complex flavors in the bowl) and was delightful.  If you like pho ga, try the secret menu version for a yummy twist.
author: Diana W.

description:
I love the soup broth in this place. 
This place is extremely busy at lunch.
However, once you get a table, the food comes quick.
author: Al A.

description:
I've been wanting to try Turtle Tower for months, and it definitely lived up to the hype!! I've always preferred the taste of chicken broth to beef broth, and I loooooved the broth in the chicken pho. They pack so much flavor into it! I definitely did not do a good job of monitoring the soup to noodle ratio....I downed that broth haha. 

The noodles themselves are also really good - as other reviewers have said, they're much wider and softer than the noodles you find at most pho places. I think they taste different too, but I think it's probably that they soak up chicken broth v. beef broth. 

I went a few days ago, and I've been craving their chicken pho every single day since then. One of my new faves in the city :D and for less than $10 for a large (which I couldn't even finish cuz that thing is big).
author: Abby S.

description:
Love the #6 with chicken instead of beef-  weird that chicken is $1 extra but whatever. Plus $1 in the tip jar. I get home and they gave me beef  I'm starving and not walking back 7 blocks for them to correct their mistake...Imperials on the house next visit would be nice though!

- Check your to-go order before you leave.
- Don't tip till you check your to-go order.
author: eVa J.

description: Been coming here for a few years now, feel like it's time to write a review. Love the chicken pho with giblets from here. Service is speedy, space is clean and staff is friendly. Definitely recommend.
author: Xixi C.

description:
We stopped by here since it's close to Hotel Utah.  
We ordered thai ice tea and iced vietnamese coffee, and 2 dishes.  First the waitress forgot ice for the coffee.  
Then my food came out, but not my husband's.  We saw her serve food to other people who came after us.  Eventually the realized we only had one dish and they were looking at our order.  We had to go, so we cancelled it.  Only 6 tables to serve and they managed to mess up our order.  Not coming back for sure.
author: Hiromi M.

description:
Just started my day off at Turtle Tower restaurant in the SOMA district. First of all, first time at this location and the decor is similar to the other ones - it is very neat and has a really cozy ambiance. Second, sometimes it gets too busy (probably a good thing?) and so if you don't go at the right times, you might have to sign your name up to get seated. Third, food is decently priced. My significant other got a bahn mi (Viet sandwich) and paid around 4.75 - damn good price. I got a chicken broth pho with grilled veggies and no meat and got to say that it didn't disappoint!

The one thing though, it is a Northern style Viet phô so they use flat noodles and there are no bean sprouts or mint. However, you will get jalapenos and lime which makes up for it. Come in with an open heart and an empty stomach, you won't regret it.

Happy eating!
author: Jenn N.

description:
Turtle Tower is great for a fast cheap lunch.

You will have to wait your turn so be ready to stand in line.
What is nice is can order rice noodles or egg noodles.

Prefer the egg noodles just right with there broth.

Bring cash they do not take credit cards.

Simple, easy,  fast,  and casual

Food - 3
Service- 3
Price -Cheap 
Décor-2
Noise- Moderate
Casual attire 
Parking - Not easy
author: P C.

description: The very best!!! Chicken Pho nomnomnom~ rainy day, sick day, cold day, or just any day~ also just learned about the secret menu today. Can't wait to try the  F9 (variation of the regular chicken pho). And bonus: Thé, the owner is the BEST !! Super friendly, funny, nice guy =)
author: Sy K.

description:
I never got around to trying Turtle Tower while I still lived in SF, and even if I did, this location bordering the cuts of SOMA and the freeway most definitely would not have been the one for me to take a leisurely jaunt over to. However, I now date someone who lives in the Mission, and convenience combined with car access (convenience x2) has made this my go-to pho spot when I'm in town.

The problem? They're like, never open! Ok, I shall explain: they are NOT open on Sundays. That is stated... somewhere. I now know after showing up a couple of times on the Sabbath and being greeted with a sad "Sorry, we're closed" sign. Another time, we arrived just a couple minutes past 9pm, which is their closing time. As we left I waved forlornly at those customers who were finishing up their meals inside. Finally, one other time we came here at the ripe dinner time of 6pm, and they were closed for a private party. UGH. Perhaps this is just my bad luck, but this spot tends to be very picky with its hours! More so than I'd expect from a pho restaurant (which should be open whenever I want it to be, of course), but I guess it might have to do with its weird location. Anyway, thought I'd warn you.

Aside from all that, I'm definitely a fan of the pho ga (chicken pho). I find myself craving the wide pho noodles that characterize it... they're just so soothing to slurp. I haven't a problem with the broth, though abovementioned partner is Vietnamese and therefore an expert due to the millions of bowls of pho he has consumed over his lifetime... he says it's nothing special. I think it's worth trying, but perhaps you should NOT go out of your way and check out either the Richmond or Little Saigon locations first.

Other happenings of note:
* It's very clean for a pho restaurant.
* Once they seated two of us in a booth and after ordering moved us to a smaller table to accommodate a party of 4 waiting outside. We did it without fuss, but still, kinda weird.
author: Kate V.

description: Great pho. Quick service, even during the weekday lunch rush. If you're hungry get the large
author: Jaden M.

description:
Albeit the hair I've found in my spring roll, and the jalapeno being dried up, I still come back often to this Turtle Tower. 

Some people say that the quality differs between each location, I sort of see it, but I don't care! It's convenient, it's cheap, and it's good!!! 

I love the chicken pho here, the secret is to make the sauce. You use the small dish, and soak the jalapenos in vinegar and fish sauce. Then with every spoonful of noodles, take a little of that jalapeno or sauce as well, and it's just super tasty. 

I've also had the beef and leek stir fry soup noodles, that's good but not as clean and savory as the Pho ga (chicken pho). The beef pho is also good, depending on your mood. I don't see many people getting the banh mi or rice plates here. If it's your first time, definitely try the chicken pho with the fish sauce/vinegar! yum! 

pro tip: the soup is a GREAT hang over cure. and wonderful on a cold day. 
pro tip #2: you can order delivery from trycaviar.com (but i think it's $10 delivery charge)
author: Joanna S.

description: Highly recommend! Arguable the best chicken noodle soup in SF! Be sure to try the imperial roll as well, delicious. Owner came out and chatted with us, great guy and a great place!
author: Chris C.

description:
Nothing quite warms the soul than a hot soup and there's no better than some great pho.  I had heard many good things about this place but never had the chance to try it myself since it's typically located in not so great neighborhoods.  We decided to brave the storm and walk over anyway.

I ordered their large pho dac biet, which is pretty much the benchmark of pho dishes and the basis for my comparison.  It wasn't served with any of the basil, bean sprouts, and other stuff that you'd expect since this is the northern style cuisine, and there wasn't even any hoisin sauce.  I was ok with that since I really enjoyed the combination of flavors served.  The all important soup was definitely unique but I liked how bold the flavors were in it so it really didn't need much seasoning.  Overall, I really enjoyed it.

The service is just so-so here and I definitely wouldn't call it warm.  However, the food is good and that's all that matters really.  I didn't feel super stuffed after eating here which is unusual and it was exactly what I needed on a rainy day.  I'm looking forward to going back.

Food: 8/10

Service: 6/10

Price: $

Atmosphere: 6/10
author: Joe M.

description: Fast service and I always get the very comforting chicken pho which is perfect for a cold day or hangover cure. The sandwiches taste good and feels freshly made.
author: Lian F.

description: Awesome... Awesome service and the experience was just great. All the guys there were super nice and asked if the food was good and thanked me and were just all around cool people. You don't find that stuff that much anymore. I highly recommend this eatery. The food was also resplendent :)
author: Westin M.

description: Great spot, some of the best noodles you will find in the city. If you come here, definitely get the soup noodles with the STIR FRIED NOODLES. YEP, they fry the noodles BEFORE they put in the soup. It tastes like no other soup noodle you've ever had. And if lucky, you'll be graced with the company of the part-owner of this shop that brings great energy to your meal with funny chatter.
author: Vince L.

description: First timers! & treated like a regular :) We were greeted by Tay (sp.?) and let me say, customer service is a make or break it for me. He was super nice, and even told us about a secret menu, which I'm sure won't stay secret for very long. Husband tried it, and it was soooo good! A chicken in chicken broth with "secret ingredients". Sounds sketchy at first, but when you taste it... you would not regret ordering it. I got my usual pho tai, but I was educated a little about the different type of pho out there... I suppose I'm a little sheltered in this area of food. Thicker noodles than what I'm used to, and no hoisin sauce! Taste (5) Service (5) Clean (5) Will we come back? Hell yeah!
author: Megan M.

description: I love Turtle Tower! And this location makes for a nice respite from the intensity of Bryant street surrounds. Super clean restaurant with very helpful and friendly staff, and of course, delicious food. I had the small Pho Ga to warm me up on a cold winter night. Highly recommended!
author: Rebecca W.

description: Getting to go order. The guy who came in after me already finished his meal and I still didn't get my TO GO order. Food is boring, over price for its taste. You can easy get some better pho in Clemente Street and cheaper.
author: Qiaosi C.

description: Raised the price to $9.25 for the pho ga. No please, it's too expensive! Been coming here since 2012, I hope u will chance the price back! It's too expensive for a bowl of noodle! It's my favorite pho restaurant! Please don't take it away from us!
author: Stefan L.

description:
If I had it my way and lost all my picky friends, I'd be here every Sunday morning nursing a hangover slopping up every last drop of soup and vermicelli. Unfortunately, our taste buds don't always agree so I only bring the unsuspecting here and they leave pleasantly surprised. This is a great restaurant, although I'm not convinced this location is the best. But, it's my local one so I will support it. 

Food is a little salty, ask for less salt or water it down with some hot water. Don't complain; solve your own problems.
author: Ben H.

description:
This is a popular lunch spot for my co-workers, as well as everyone else in the area. It's located in VERY close proximity to our office, so it's always a very convenient lunch option as long as we go before or after the rush (which is usually 12-1 p.m.). If you come during the rush, expect a good 30 minute or so wait I would guess -- we just call in and let them know when we're coming haha 

The small pho ga is, I believe, about $6.95. It's a good price for the bowl you get, which comes with a good amount of chicken and plenty of noodles. The broth isn't as flavorful as Quan Ngon (my holy grail chicken pho on Noreiga), and not as consistent. One day it was more watery than the other, bleh. I do, however, like how they slice up the jalapenos super thin and give you a lot!

I ordered a rice dish to go once -- it was absolutely terrible. But you could say it was my fault for ordering a rice dish at a chicken pho place. Spring rolls are below average and the peanut sauce is whatever. Service is average -- I don't have anything to complain about, nor is it particularly memorable. Overall, a decent chicken pho restaurant.
author: Doris K.

description:
It's the tale of two Turtle Towers. It's the best of pho, it's the worst of pho. How can two Turtle Towers be this different in execution and still have the same menu? It's kinda when Patty Duke played identical twin cousins who were total opposites, then they played each other to fool others and knee-slapping hilarity ensues. No hilarity to be found here. Just a standard Vietnamese place in a location that isn't the most pedestrian-friendly at the relatively barren corner of 6th and Bryant. It feels downright suburban compared to the more densely populated Little Saigon location (see my review - http://www.yelp.com/biz/turtle-tower-restaurant-san-francisco#hrid:idtbVotN081VoyQb9aXurw). 

I ordered the same thing I order at the other location. Jamie W. and I shared the $4.95 Goi Cuon (Spring Rolls), which are impossible to fail with fresh prawns and basil leaves peeking through the near-transparent rice paper. It comes with with addictive peanut dipping sauce (see photo). We both ordered the same entree, the large $7.95 bowl of Pho Bo Dac Biet, which has strips of rare beef, tripe, flank and brisket (see photo). This is where it went wrong - the broth didn't taste right like it was watered down considerably. Pho with only marginally satisfying broth just shouldn't exist. That's when pho should be spelled with an 'F'. 

Another disappointment was the $7.05 Ga Luoc, a small plate of steamed chicken served with a ginger dipping sauce (see photo). There was an unwanted gamey (...or should I say farmy) flavor that made it almost inedible. When a dish as high-risk as steamed chicken tastes not quite right, you just stop eating it. There's no saving it. Bummer. Customers here are more of a melting pot with not only Asian families but lots of mechanics from the nearby car dealers eating lunch here. The rainbow blend is a plus, but it's too bad that they're coming to a place where the food can be subpar. 

FOOD - 3 stars...darn disappointing compared to the original Turtle Tower in Little Saigon, especially the pho broth 
AMBIANCE - 3 stars...feels like a mall court place 
SERVICE - 2.5 stars...appeared more focused on turnover 
TOTAL - 3 stars...worth strolling to the Tenderloin to get something more flavorful than what they have here
author: Ed U.

description: This is the best comfort food or hang over food ever, I can come to this place every day, except my wife would not be a happy camper... I usually get the chicken pho with giblets, iced Vietnamese coffee and egg rolls on a hungry day. The broth is like what a super Asian family would cook up at home, add the jalapeños with fish sauce, OMG, writing this makes me want to have another one.
author: Christopher N.

description:
I was excited to get pho and imperial rolls from turtle tower delivered to the office when I had to work late this past week

Summary:
- rare beef pho: the soup was warm but not piping hot by the time it was delivered, so it took a while for the beef to slowly cook. Love the wider noodles as opposed to the thin pho from other places. The soup was lighter than the usual pho, and not very flavorful. 

- fish cake side dish: expensive for a tiny portion. But tasty

- imperial rolls: crispy and very flavorful. I'm a fan. 

The pho was cheap but the rolls were a little pricy. Would have this again at the restaurant to try the pho piping hot!
author: Jocelyn L.

description:
This place it's nothing special when it comes down to the atmosphere, its cold and sterile at best,. Sometimes sticky tables cab be a sign of good food. For the price it's amazing. 
The pho is great. We had a few of the appetizers and they were perfect.Everything is so full of flavor and so fresh.

I feel like this place gets a lower rating than the others for intermediately bad service. I have never had bad service here. Like I said the atmosphere is not the best, as for the location, not so hot either. Expecting great service here is sort of like wanting to pay more, not what I want to do so I can deal with imperfect service to some degree.
author: Ben M.

description: Food comes out lightning quick and flavors are the same as the TL location. Quite a few parking spots open on the weekends so no need to stress. Young staff plays EDM during your meal...
author: Julie L.

description: This is a life changing experience. This turtle tower by far surpasses the others. I seriously was taken care of here. The pho here just hit the spot. One of the most enjoyable meals I've had in a long while.
author: Daniel L.

description:
Hubby and I came here for lunch before our meeting, there were plenty of parking spaces one block up.......

We waited for about 10-15 minutes to get seated, I guess we hit lunch time....

I used my groupon which was 2 bowls of soup and 2 drinks.....

We ordered 2 different phos, their broth is very good, not full of msg as others, you can tell because you don't get those thirsty bursts after......

Sure missed the hoisin sauce though, might have to bring my own next time.....hoisin sauce is full of msg.....hmmm

Very good if you are looking for that clean broth taste.....definitely recommend.....
author: Leslie Y.

description: I came to Turtle Tower with my friend for early dinner! Their Pork Rice plate was delicious but I really enjoyed the broth for that night's pho special. The broth was hearty and full of flavor!  Customer service was amazing! Very tentative and good atmosphere to dine at night. Keep up the good work.
author: Rachel M.

description:
Finally tried Turtle Tower's infamous chicken noodle (pho) soup. The pho is more like the Chinese-style "ho fun", fatter in shape and can be less al dente. I've tried both the small and large bowls - wish there was something in the middle. The soup was definitely delicious but after having it for the 2nd time there was nothing special that would make me crave it. No doubt there's MSG. I've tried a few Vietnamese places in SF and none seem to surpass Y&Y on Clement St. 

Worth trying once to know (or not) why everyone talks about TT. I wouldn't recommend going out of your way to try it. Definitely overrated.
author: Jackie C.

description:
I pass by this Turtle Tower on the 8x numerous times since it's opening. Didn't feel like walking over to Subway for a sandwich or McDonald's for fries and nuggets. I decided to try the food here, so I came in and ordered a #2 which was a small bowl of Rare Beef Rice Noodle Soup. The beef and rice noodles were delicious, soup base was very rich in flavor. The menu item I ordered was delicious and I am coming back to try something else next time I pass by.

The restaurant is clean, staff members are friendly providing efficient service.

This place has seating for about 20-30 or 40 customers.

Turtle Tower - my new go to restaurant for Vietnamese cuisine cravings.

FYI:
This restaurant is one block from the courthouse and police station on 850 Bryant St. If you are feeling hungry right after completing jury duty and you crave for pho, then come on over Turtle Tower.

Payment Method: Cash Only

Price Range: $
author: Bennett W.

description:
THIS PLACE SUCKS. I have no idea why people love Turtle Tower's chicken pho so much, it's utterly bland and tasteless. 

What really turned me off from this particular location was the time I ordered their steamed chicken (without rice) to go for $8+. I opened the container to take a peek at my food before leaving the restaurant because my order felt really light. Turns out I got less than a chicken leg. Most of the "meat" I got was skin and bones. The waiters there were extremely rude when I raised the issue. The debate got kind of heated my friend asked the waiter if he would have paid $8 for the pathetic chicken platter I got, and he retorted, "Well, I wouldn't have ordered that dish." Total BS. In the end, I just asked for my money back and left feeling pissed.
author: Catherine C.

description: Awesome service and some of the best pho in SF. This location is also super nice and clean! Perfect for a chilly day. Say whatup to Thé!
author: jason y.

description:
I've eaten at the Turtle Tower Restaurant on Geary Blvd. numerous times, and I've never reviewed them so when I saw that Turtle Tower was opening up a third location on the corner of 6th and Bryant Streets, the space formerly occupied by TEN7M and Quiznos before that, I was giddy with anticipation being that the new location is just a block and a half from where I work.

Fast forward only two short weeks and the restaurant is now open for business serving a limited menu during their soft opening.  The official grand opening is scheduled for next Wednesday, June 1, but I couldn't wait one whole week so as soon as I heard what the limited menu was I stepped in to try it out.

For the record the 4 items served on the Wednesday I visited were the Well-done Flank and Beef Brisket Noodle Soup, the Rare Beef Noodle Soup, the Chicken Noodle Soup and Imperial Rolls.

Those four choices suited me fine as all I really wanted was a hot bowl of beef noodle soup so I ordered a large Rare Beef Noodle Soup and a couple of Imperial Rolls.  As I've come to expect from their Geary location the service here is just as speedy with your food ready in mere minutes after your order is placed.  Accompanied by a lime wedge and some thinly sliced jalapenos plated separately the clear beef broth seemed just a tad too oily (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/KAHDxIOccnc1P1m5abjM0A?select=qPxHdydcJr9tM9QTa4xC_w), but once I dove into that bowl the extra oil on top seemed unnoticeable.

The flavor-rich broth was perfectly seasoned and I loved the hint of ginger in it.  The portion of noodles and beef to broth was perfect.  The Imperial Rolls can be ordered as an entrée with vermicelli noodles and fresh veggies, but I elected to order just two on its own (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/KAHDxIOccnc1P1m5abjM0A?select=zdAwClljoGD8NWdEzZUlDg).  These were very good as most deep-fried goodies are, and since I do no deep-frying at home you can bet I'll order these again on a future visit.

So far in 2011 I've done a lot more cooking at home, and brown-bagging my meals for work have become the norm for me, but I know for a fact I can't make pho this good at home so I may need to rethink this whole not-going-out-to-restaurants-too-often thing thanks to the new Turtle Tower Restaurant.

As mentioned by another Yelper in her review some culinary surprises available only at this Turtle Tower location awaits you.  For a sneak preview I've posted the menu in the photos section.  Welcome to the neighborhood, Turtle Tower!  I have a feeling you're going to be seeing me very often.
author: Wilhelm Y.

description:
Location #3 for Turtle Tower is open for business! (including weekends) http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/turtle-tower-restaurant-san-francisco-3?select=XyE2ArO33JSt29m8FdVF5Q#XyE2ArO33JSt29m8FdVF5Q The official grand opening is next week Wed. June 1st, 2011.

5 stars seem like a high rating, but there aren't many worthwhile eateries in the area (near Hall of Justice), and the staff are super friendly. So they get extra points for all that. Like most TT fans, my favorite is the Pho Ga.

Those stuck on jury duty will love this addition. I know that they already can get Vietnamese food from Grab N Go across the street, but in my opinion TT's food is way better.

The space is smaller than the branch on Larkin street. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/turtle-tower-restaurant-san-francisco-3?select=4tmpNXJCPcq3MWQQOyokrA#4tmpNXJCPcq3MWQQOyokrA During this soft opening week they feature a limited menu, but the best news is that they told me that they'll start making custom made banh mi on the grand opening day. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/turtle-tower-restaurant-san-francisco-3?select=qPxHdydcJr9tM9QTa4xC_w#cw_9kbK5kfy_PJj88t3X1Q Note: don't expect it to be as cheap as Saigon sandos.

The banh mi (price yet to be determined) includes the standard butter, mayo, cilantro, carrots & jalapenos, then pick your choice of 3 proteins: pate, ham, sausage, fried egg, chicken, and pork. One of the few to offer a fried egg option, others are Bun Mee, Little Green Cyclo food truck, and Banh Mi Ba Le in Oakland.

Most prices are similar to the Larkin location, including the imperial rolls for $2.15 each (ouch!). Except that most Pho (small $6.20-$7.20, large $7.20-$8.20) and entrees costs about 25 cents more here. Not by much, so I think it's okay.

I'm concerned that this area has no foot traffic on weekends. Except for a few places like McDonald's, most eateries are open weekdays for lunch only. So I don't think it's wise for TT to have weekends hours. A soup business is different from other eateries. The stove remains on for long hours to keep the soup hot, so their utilities bill is high even when they have no customers.

I'd like TT to remain in business, so they need to make some wise decisions from the beginning. Otherwise they'll suffer the same fate as all the previous tenants that went out of business at this corner.

Hours: daily 9am-9pm (revised 2013)

** Update 2013: In case u ever found this shop closed, when u thought it was open. Here's a brief synopsis of the schedule changes. Initial operating hours were 7am-5pm, later extended to 9pm, with a break between lunch and dinner service. Later it changed to continuous service, to match their other locations. Then on January 2013, the schedule was cut to Mon-Sat 10am-4pm, closed Sundays. And in March 2013 they changed their minds again, so it's back to 9pm, including weekends.
author: Luis C.

description: There was a hair in the fresh spring roll. When I told the cashier about the issue, she just said sorry and didn't proceed to do anything else
author: Henry C.

description:
What I ate: Goi cuon, pho ga, chrysanthemum tea
Visit date: May 30, 2012
First time? Yes.

Ok, so it's not in the best part of town, but if you're craving some stellar goi cuon, Turtle Tower is the place. I normally get my goi cuon with just shrimp -- the pork just never cut it for me. I forgot to say 'just shrimp' here, but no worries. At the Turtle, they use a succulent grilled pork which makes the goi cuon so much more flavorful. Their sauce was finger-lickin', too -- not too thick and not too runny.

Now, what brought me here was Scoutmob's (Am I allowed to name drop like that?) free pho ga deal. The pho ga was subpar. Sure, the broth was good (not the best, though), but the chicken was chewy. Not ok. And, they keep the skin on the chicken. Maybe that's good for flavoring, but I don't like eating it. 

After soup, I wanted something cold (ice cold!). I had the chrysanthemum tea (from a can) and asked for ice so the sweetness could be diluted (you know me and not liking super sweet drinks). This was a perfect way to end a meal.

Staff is friendly, and they have fancy bag hooks under each table. Plus!
author: Erin G.

description:
NORTHERN STYLE PHO
(5 stars)

Once you go Northern, you never go back.

- FOOD, delicious pho
- PRICES, affordable
- SERVICE, fast
- AMBIANCE, small

I go to this location because its the less crowded one and I find it to be the cleanest too. I like exposing friends to "northern style" and when they have it they are pretty amazed. Only come here for the soups, the sandwiches were not the business. When I bring people here they never believe me how good it is until you dip into it. 

HEFFER STATUS.

PHO SOT VANG ($6.50) - Beef stewed in wine sauce noodle soup. It doesn't look the best but it is SO AMAZING. Can I make love to this soup because it is just that amazing. Hmmm Hmmmm Hmmmm....

PHO GA ($6.50) - Chicken noodle soup. Yah, doesn't sound interesting but this is the best chicken pho i've ever had. You just have to order it to really know what it is all about.

Will I be back? YES YES YES YES YES.

JABA APPROVED. Until the next review....
author: Jane A.

description: Been here a few times and have been a fan especially the one on Geary. Went there at 7pm on a Thursday and ordered two large chicken phos. The bowls came out and had less food than a small. Definitely couldn't see much noodles or chicken. It was all soup and chicken skin. Very disappointed and still got charged full price. If you're going to be brutally honest about the quality and food, be at least a little honest about the price. Not cool from someone who's a frequent customer.
author: Anonymous C.

description:
Came back and tried the #10 Pho Ga Long or chicken soup with "giblets" which consist of liver, gizzards, and 1 unborn egg, cut in 2 pieces (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/turtle-tower-san-francisco-5?select=Ujq4MeJCfNLuNiajT-JSSA&userid=DsHsuhUvyyW_75zFcJxkKw#Ujq4MeJCfNLuNiajT-JSSA)

Food was better, service was worse.

No issues with the noodles this time. Nice amount of chicken, gizzards, and liver. 

Place was 1/2 full when I arrived and it took about 15 minutes to take my order after they took orders for the two tables seated after me. By the time I got my refill of hot tea, I was done eating.
author: Andrew C.

description: No idea why this place only has 3 stars, it's amazing. The noodles are soft but you have the options to change them, the broth is extremely flavorful and not because of MSG. I'd highly recommend the chicken noodle soup or (pho GA), if you're feeling adventurous I'd recommend them with the giblets too - they add an extra depth of flavor and interesting texture.
author: Keyue B.

description: The pho ga is what everyone raves about, so that's what I got. It was good--fresh, with the amount of chives in there, and light. Exactly what we needed on a cold, foggy day in March.
author: Rosy H.

description:
After going to Turtle Tower in the TL, I had high hopes for this one. I'm a huge pho fan and I had an insane craving one day during lunch. I'm still craving pho. This was just terrible.

The broth was bland. The beef was just a giant stuck together chunk. AND THERE WAS NO HOISIN SAUCE. How do you serve PHO with NO HOISIN SAUCE. Also there are no mung bean sprouts which is another WTF. Even the whitest and worst pho places I've ever been to have bean sprouts and hoisin sauce.

Minus all the stars for not being real pho.
author: Paulina D.

description:
The chao ga (chicken porridge) is absolutely awful. Absolutely no taste, and the rice seemed like 5 days old stale. But when I told the waiter, he was like ok, and allowed me to order a chicken pho, my usual. Lol I vow to never venture out of my turtle tower chicken pho obsession!

Tried the imperial rolls too! Very delicious!!! Also the #1 with the beef brisket was amazing too. Still will come back again and again
author: Annie K.

description: Rare beef and well done beef pho, "small size" is huge in flavor and quality.  They have a nice coconut juice and fresh spring rolls (but being pre-made, some pieces of rice paper have turned into the hard plasticky stuff).  Delicious!!!
author: Terry K.

description:
I was really craving pho one evening after watching a horrible game of the Toronto Maple Leaf losing. I needed to drown my sorrows in some delicious noodle soup. However, I'm new to San Francisco, so I really didn't know where to go. My friend suggested "Turtle Tower" -- but the one in the Tenderloin (then to find out that it was closed). So we ended up in the one in SOMA. 

My friend said that the chicken pho was the most famous one -- however, I wanted to have some beef pho (because that's the usual, right?). I got myself the large, considering how hungry I was, and I wanted tripe -- so I got the one with everything in it? 

Good? Meh. It was not the best pho I've ever had... I've had better -- even in Toronto. I was super duper disappointed. However, I've been hearing that the best pho is in the South Bay - maybe I should venture there.
author: Joanne W.

description: If you don't know what northern Vietnamese pho looks and tastes like, then don't come here judging for what it's not supposed to be. The broth and noodles here are awesome. If you're Taiwanese or Chinese-descent, try this. Great standby in the middle of a bizarre part of soma.
author: Elain S.

description: Chicken pho is the BOMB here!  The one with the giblets is the best.  Beware that all chicken meat is with the skin as some people get turn off by this.  The broth is light yet flavorful.  The pho here is also very different and unique only to Turtle Tower.  It is a thinner version of the Chinese chow fun and very smooth.  Because if its texture, it is not soggy at all.  This location is less busy than the main location on Larkin even though it's half the size.
author: Rose L.

description:
I am from America but have loved Vietnamese food for most of my life. Little flavor in Pho broth. Bland chicken and noodles tated old. I couldn't eat it at all. This is not the type of food I expect when I order Vietnamese.  
I also hate when places have a cash only policy and get attitude when the only cash I have is $100. Take debit or drop the tude. Will not return, do NOT reccomend!
author: Amanda M.

description: Having never experienced Northern-style pho, I was a little confused when I got my meal and I there were no bean sprouts, hoisin, or thin noodles. By the time I finished my pho, however, I realized just how much I had been missing out on by only confining myself to one type of pho. HOLY MOLY: this stuff is incredible. The broth is so rich and delicious that it needs no additions. Every slurp is packed with powerful flavor. I love the thick noodles, especially after they have absorbed the brothy flavor. I don't know if Turtle Tower is just super exceptional, or if all Northern pho is this amazing, or if both are true, but I definitely recommend going here. Turtle Tower is low-maintenance and cheap but tastes as good as the fanciest restaurants. Can't wait to go back.
author: Riva L.

description:
The boyfriend and I came here on a rainy SF night hoping to grab some hot soupy goodness and wait out the evening rush hour commute. Parking was easy to find although traffic was pretty bad since they're right by the entrance to the Bay Bridge.

We walked in around 6:30pm and there was only one couple ahead of us waiting to get seated. The tables were filled save 3-4 tables that were waiting to get bussed. There were two servers - male and female - running around serving up food, taking orders, dealing with the checks but no one took notice of the crowd growing waiting to get seated and the dirty empty tables. I notice that the girl was doing most of the running around - she seated the couple ahead of us - while the boy was just hanging around behind the counter. We stood around for about 10 minutes without getting acknowledged until I had to walk up to the girl and ask if we could get a table for two.

Finally the girl started cleaning up some of the tables while I guess some of the kitchen staff took pity and had to come out to help her. I don't understand what the heck the guy was doing behind the counter doing nothing. 

Food-wise, everyone knows Turtle Tower has bomb chicken pho. It's always tastes the same to me no matter which location I go to but for service I would prefer the Geary or Tenderloin location. Service picked up and became more efficient since the restaurant got quite crowded after we got our table. I guess the servers just haven't figured out how to work as a team yet.
author: Bonnie S.

description:
The chicken pho is great.  Also the bean drinks.

Don't get the rice dishes.  That was a big mistake I will not be repeating.
author: Niniane W.

description: The number 1 is what I always get. This isn't your regular pho restaurant. It's an authentic Hanoi style which I prefer much more. The quality of broth and cooked meats has never disappointed me.
author: Jonathan M.

description:
Long over due review.

Me and my dude come here religiously.  I like pho don't get me wrong.  But this place does pho well.  My dude loves this place, I think we eat here at least once a week.  We come here so often that our favorite guy sees us asks "same thing guys?" and we say yeah and he gets it right every damn time.  I don't even know your name homeboy but you the real MVP.  No one else is as dope a server as he is at this joint.  He's the only one that serves us hot tea and put ices in our water.  So the food...
I always get a #3 and he always gets a #4 (this one has tripe) I'm not sure what else is in it.  I think there's rare steak and brisket in both of them.  We always get a solid amount of meat and a nice portion of noodle.  And the noodles...flat pho noodles.  These are life changers.  Taste way better than any other pho noodles I've had before.  And the broth?  Lovely flavor.  And it smells good.  Yeah, they always provide you limes and jalapenos, too.

We also get fried eggrolls.  Sometimes they're overcooked, but most of the time they're on point.  On point like their friend to golden perfection.  The vermicelli is soft and sticky.  Sometimes it's hard to pull it apart but it's no big deal.

They're not that expensive either.  For the two of us to get a small and large pho and the rolls, including tip, it's normally $30.  So yes, we'll be back again next week probably.
author: Sara P.

description: Probably the worst turtle I've ever been to. Portions are small as hell. Servers here are not attentive and maybe shouldn't even be servers anymore due to lack of customer service. We ordered extra chicken pho and no one ever came to clean out the previous bowls we finished. Chatting with coworkers ARE NOT PART OF YOUR JOB. Never coming back to this location and definitely not worth my tips. Owner should definitely rethink of closing down this restaurant and firing your manager as well
author: Christine B.

description:
To be honest, we came here for the free pho ga scout mob app. However, I was really disappointed due to the over hype by my friends. I thought that this was going to be such a great deal because I was meaning to try this place for ages. BUT THANKGOD I didn't have to pay for the pho or else I would have flipped a bitch. Come on, I am vietnamese and I know what good pho tastes like. I have to admit though that the broth is pretty refreshing and light, but nothing is comparable to the classic beef pho. 

The bf and I ordered two pho ga and spring rolls. Firstly, the pho ga is super simple. They do not even have hoison sauce! I MEAN COME ON.. i grew up using that stuff for every soup I eat! Then they tell me that they do not add any veggies like bean sprouts either!! WHOA DER.. thats the sole reason I come for pho! And on top of that the spring rolls were a little less than $6 but really cost .50 cents to make. They were sparse in every detail, there was definitely not even noodle, sauce or shrimp. SOOOO LAME. Overall, I would probably give it a better star if I had eaten the beef pho, but to be honest.. I really NEED HOISON SAUCE!!! :( Plus the wait may be really long considering the small tables and you might have to share a table with strangers as they have these signs that say "sharing table"

On a brighter note, the lady that runs this place is SUPER nice and friendly. She speaks really good english and has a great sense of humor. Not to mention that this is the cleanish location I have seen.
author: Anh Thu P.

description:
How can you rate anything less than 5 stars for #9 Large?

Make sure you add in 2 spoon fulls of siracha&1/2 spoon of fish sauce. Then you add siracha, lime juice, pepper, and fish sauce into the jalapenos. 

For a meal less than 20 dollars for two, the quality/taste/price just really cannot be beat. Everything else is AIGHT.
author: Wendy X.

description:
it doesnt seem as good as the one on geary but considering there arent many other choices for a nice bowl of noodle soup, this is the best option you have in the soma area. 
its a small place so you should also prepare to wait if you get there around noon.

my default at turtle tower is always the chicken noodle soup so i also cant say how the other choices are.
author: Alex H.

description:
Turtle Tower is unique because it serves northern-style pho, also known as pho bac. Its simplicity sets it apart from the southern style pho you'd find in most restaurants. You don't get the plate of garnishes considered standard with southern style, so you can't customize your pho. Northern pho is designed to eat exactly as is - though there were actually some sauces on the table and jalepenos brought on the side, so maybe pho bac isn't as strict as I thought. Or Turtle Tower has made a few compromises. Either way.

I always think of parking in San Francisco as a big pain. Parallel parking and meters prevail, and I'm too lazy to deal with it all, so I rarely make it into the city. Parking here wasn't too bad, though. After a few laps around the block, I found a nearby spot. The SoMa location is on a corner easily accessible from the freeway and has a sunny interior, with shades of yellow and cool old photos on the walls. It was noisy, not a place you'd like to sit for hours, but comfortable enough.

The menu features pho, bun, cm, banh mi, and a few special items like chao (rice porridge) and even xoi (sticky rice). Though I've been advised to try the pho sot vang, I had to first try Turtle Tower's specialty, the pho ga. It turned out to be an amazing choice.

Think of it as the best chicken noodle soup you will ever eat. A fragrant, flavorful chicken broth deepened with the wonderful spices that define pho. Excellent quality, though quite oily. Thick, fresh noodles that render you incapable of understanding how any restaurant can serve anything else, finished with a generous topping of green onions and cilantro to brighten the dish. It's heavenly. If you were hungover, sick, or depressed, I think this would fix you right up. It was damn near perfect, but the serving of chicken, though ample, was a tad dry.

Tender, moist chicken would have made this pho absolutely flawless, and would probably have had me on my knees with tears streaming down my face. I'm kind of glad it wasn't, so I could keep it together. But the one flaw could be overlooked, and I'll still consider this one of the best bowls of pho I've ever had. The portion was huge, too. We both ordered smalls, which were only $6.75, and were more than satisfied. I couldn't even finish, which was unusual for me! Thanks, Turtle Tower!


Rating Breakdown:

Taste (13/14):
Broth flavor- 5/5
Noodle & meat quality- 4/5
Garnish selection- N/A (automatic 2 pts)
Portion size- 2/2

Restaurant (14/16):
Service- 4/5
Cleanliness- 5/5
Atmosphere- 3/4
Speed of arrival- 2/2

Total: 27/30

Join the phoventure at www.phoacrossamerica.com
author: Victoria T.

description:
My friend dragged me to this place because he was saying they had the besstttt Pho Ga... hmmm it was ALRIGHT.

I wouldn't say the best Pho Ga, but it would be a nice remedy after a hangover though. There's really nothing special about it. What I liked the most is actually their Banh Mi because it had scrambled egg in it. A bit pricey compared to other Banh Mi (i.e. Saigon Sandwich). I just wanted to try it because it looked interesting.
author: Karla Marie D.

description: Get the spring rolls and pho ga and you're good to go. Normally I'm a pho tai kinda guy, but I think that their noodle's style, which is softer and flatter than the usual southern vietnamese pho shops, suits chicken better than beef as the textures are a closer match. My only gripe here is that you will die of thirst since the water cups they give you are for ants, and no one really pays enough attention to constantly refill your water.
author: Omar M.

description: Delicious pho! At first we were surprised that there was no basil or bean sprouts but then the owner explained to us that the pho is northern style and that bean sprouts and basil was actually an American modification. Super nice staff. Great place, I will definitely come back.
author: Trisha K.

description:
I eat here for lunch very frequently because of the convenient Soma location. Compared to the original Tenderloin location the food here has somewhat less of the home cooked feel and more inconsistency. I order the Chicken Pho Ga 95% of the time when I come here. Most of the time when something goes wrong, they skimp on the chicken or give you chicken that is more than 50% skin, other times the soup is too light. Overall, it's still very good though. Considering you are getting boneless free range chicken, homemade soup, and fresh rice noodles, it's hard to find anything this healthy as a lunch option that isn't a sandwich or salad. 

Also be aware that since the Tenderloin location has closed temporarily until they open the new one a few months from now, they are doing a lot of catering out of the Soma location, which can mean your usual order that is normally served within 5 minutes can take up to 15 depending on what time you are there.
author: Mark Y.

description: Busy northern Vietnam style - no sprouts or hoisin - pho. Cash only, clean little place, they use good ingredients. Only issue: bland.
author: Andrew K.

description:
Had a pretty horrible take out experience. I've eaten a lot of pho in my day, and the bottom line is that the pho ga I picked up was unappetizing. The chicken broth smelled funky, I didn't trust the meat. They also forgot to pack the fresh herbs, siracha, viet Bbq sauce, etc. Actually, I had to flag someone at the restaurant to even pick up my stuff; I stood there behind other patrons for 10-15 minutes waiting for a glance from the busy staff that never came.

I've been to the Turtle Tower on Larkin and had a great meal there. I think I caught these guys on a bad and busy day, but a bad review is justified...chicken soup is basic, customers shouldn't feel compelled to throw it away. Ever.
author: John D.

description:
After waiting 15mins for a table during lunch hour, we were seated for our disappointing bowls of pho. 

Everything was just meh from the broth to the meats--they didn't even offer mint or basil with the soup. Still searching for a good pho place in SoMa...
author: Mimi T.

description: I always call ahead and order the pork bun. They're fast, nice, and delicious. The food is n't exactly perfect, but for lunchtime pickups it's one of the less oily options in the area. Plenty of food, too. The sauces, meat and noodles are packed separately, so the noodles don't get soggy. They only take cash, but there's an ATM by the door.
author: Amy C.

description:
As a Vietnamese gal, every once in a while I would crave pho...

Since I'm too lazy to Uber to the restaurant, I usually get delivery of 3 bowls: 1 dac biet (beef base broth), 1 chicken pho, and 1 egg chicken noodle soup. 

The small bowls are actually REALLY filling (thank you American sizing) so I divide them in half, heat up the broth on stove, place the noodles in a soup bowl and then pour the broth into the noodles @ boiling temperature (3-5min). 

Can't really rate condiments because northern pho is less dressy than southern pho. But I cheat and use that bottle of hot sriracha in my refridgerator. 

My advice is to not order the rice wrapper rolls. They were really dry :( 

Also can't rate service or cleanliness of restaurant because I eat at home. With my cat.
author: Momo M.

description:
I had the Rare Beef Pho and it was easily the single worst bowl of pho I have ever had the displeasure of coming across.

The meat had that sour, on the verge of being spoiled taste that was utterly horrific. I'm really not that picky about pho, but I've had enough that I know a decent bowl from a terrible one. 

The broth was underwhelming and the noodles were overcooked. I had a few bites and left the rest of it on the table.

The place was totally empty which should have tipped me off that something was wrong. Service was alright - I had to get up to pay at the register, not sure if this is normal, but the guy working there was nice enough.

Regardless - never again.
author: Nika M.

description: This was the most bland pho I've ever had. The broth was so flat -- tasted like greasy salt water. No flavor of anise or any spice :(
author: Negien M.

description:
Hm....I thought this would be SUPER good but was disappointed. I guess this location is not as good as the other Turtle Tower.

Ordered the Pho Ga. LOVE the fat noodles, super chewy. The bowl was actually too small! The soup was spilling over the moment I dipped in my chopsticks. Soup was not too salty, but also not the best chicken noodle I've had. The chicken was slightly juicy but wish there were more of it.

Also ordered the spring rolls and was disappointed again. The lettuce tasted bitter and the rolls were tiny. Shrimp kind of dry and the peanut sauce was average.

PROS
-Pho Ga is above average.
-Hangover food.
-Pretty fast.

CONS
-Cash only
-Super small so the tables are cramped.
author: Ting Jung L.

description:
I would say that Turtle Tower is very unique for a pho restaurant. This is the new chain that just opened and it tastes the same as the other turtle tower restaurants also. 
I came to this site because of the Scoutmob deal of a free regular sized pho ga! 

Very quick service. We got our food within 5 minutes of ordering even though it was pretty busy when we went. 

I ordered the Pho Ga here. The noodles aren't your average pho noodles, rather they are flat and thicker rice noodles. They also don't have the usual siracha or hoisen sauce to put on your pho but they give you a little plate of jalapenos and lemon and you have fish sauce and spicy sauce on your table. My boyfriend puts the fish sauce on the jalepenos in the plate and dips the chicken and noodles in the sauce. The broth is good and I can drink the entire bowl in one sitting. Very tasty and the noodles compliment it well! I haven't tried anything else on the menu but Turtle Tower is mostly known for their Pho Ga. 

A tasty and different treat from your normal pho place!
author: Audrey C.

description:
came here for some quick lunch before baseball game. Turtle Tower is usually pretty good but this branch was awful.
the service was slow and it took forever for the food to come out. we ordered the chicken and beef pho noodles. chicken - was well overcooked and dry. we asked for chicken skins as a side to add some flavour as it was blend even went adding chilli sauce. when the skins arrived, the waiter told us we could have asked for skins to be left on the chicken when we ordered. 1. we were never told that and 2. never stated in the menu.
the beef pho was also bland too.
on paying the bill, we told the cashier and she had no idea what we were talking about, referring to the chicken skins. we also said service/food lousy compared to other branches. she said what other branches.
wot a let down ...
author: Lop H.

description:
I really enjoy the pho ga at Turtle Tower. But this time I went to the SOMA one for the bahn mi. What can I say, I love banh mi more than pho. I was pretty disappointed with the banh mi, unfortunately. You can choose up to 3 fillings for your sandwich, from the following choices: grilled pork, grilled chicken, sausage, pate, ham, fried egg. I asked what happens if I only choose one filling, and the guy said I'll just get more of the one filling.

I ended up getting two banh mi's, one with grilled pork, and one with pate, ham, and fried egg. I was very excited, because I've never seen fried egg as a filling before. When I opened the pork banh mi, I was surprised to see how little filling there was. What happened to more meat? The pate was kind of weird tasting. Fried egg was awesome though. The bread was a softer, more buttery kind. But I think I like the crustier baguette better.

I think I'll stick to the pho ga at Turtle Tower and get my banh mi elsewhere.

EDIT 5/21/2013: Pho Ga = tons of MSG. Avoid!
author: Sherry L.

description:
Disappointed.  We weathered the storm, so very excited to have Pho.  After finding a parking spot, we walked in to discover cash only.  To the right of the front door stands the atm machine.  Really?  

There are so many reasons I left disappointed and hungry.  Oh well, the food looked great but I will not pay atm fees.   

If you are a cash person, please give this place a shot.  By no means does my review reflect the food.  I will certainly give it a shot when cards are accepted.
author: Ken M.

description:
Wooops; ordered the wroooooong thing here. It's all about the pho ga at this unassuming corner joint. 

I placed a to-go rice dish order. Immediate bomb. I shan't err again, as i've read the trusty reviews, and also read my electronic SFBG. Clean and small, casual.
author: Jana C.

description:
I got a bahn mi today because it was too hot for soup. The banh mi was not so good. The bread was missing a chunk from the top so the "insides" were exposed. There was a lot of butter - I don't remember ever tasting butter in a bahn mi and overall didn't taste so good. I would not get it again. I know most people going to turtle tower probably wouldn't be ordering bahn mi anyways but just in case! :)

Also, we saw on the website that there was porridge on the menu. We purposely went there today because one of my friends wanted to get the porridge, but they didn't have it and it's not even on their menu.
author: S H.

description:
In a word: uninspiring

I'll start by saying that I understand that this is northern-style "Authentic Hà Ni Style"; thick(er) noodles blah blah blah. I get it, I have been to Vietnam (north and south) and have had pho from both. I am not disappointed in the noodles because I knew what to expect. Turtle towers website states "Turtle Tower's specialty is its broths. Strictly northern-style, the soup comes with no side garnishes or bean sprouts, common accompaniments of Southern and Americanized pho." While I acknowledge the approach, I wanted some damn garnishes and siracha! I was hungover, I wanted to sweat into my soup and be on my mary way. "Americanized" pho? You're in America, bro. let me garnish this bish!

Instead, what I got was a so-so bowl of pho. The broth was good in the pho ga but it didn't blow my mind like they think they do. Size wise, the "large" was equivalent to Kevin's noodle house's medium and came into $10 after tip, which is about "Americanized" as pho gets. In Vietnam it's considered "poor man's soup", so simmer down guys. When asked if I wanted a water or hot tea, I asked for both. He looked at me stern and says, "no, which one?!"... weird. Theyre both free, but okay.

Note: I went at lunch time which was prime time. I waited about 15 minutes for a table of one and many others waiting as well. Two older Vietnamese gentlemen walked up, said something to the owner/manager and got seated before everyone else without ever putting their name on the list. Although my Vietnamese is non-existent, context clues will key you in that these were his buddies so they get preferred treatment. Any other time of day, with minimal wait, this would be whatever and shrugged off. During peak hour with tons of people waiting, not cool.

Not terrible, not the best.
If I'm working a block away again, ill pop in... but I won't go out of my way for it. 

Get over yourselves, TT.
author: Ryan L.

description:
First a clarification: 
     I noticed that the 6th street location has significantly fewer stars compared to the original restaurant? I have been to both spots many times and  I'm telling you they are very very similar.  I have no idea what the Yelp others are talking about?  I dare you to a blinded, head to head taste test!

The review:
     Seriously now...yes, the chicken pho (Pho Ga)  is that good.  I call it a spa treatment for the stomach after a hard day (or night) .  Put another way, this is as good as -maybe even better then- your grandma's chicken noodle soup.  Ya see, most noodle soup places have one or the other: great noodles or great soup.  Rarely does a place have both! This is why i'm dissing your grandma in such a pubic place.
     If you are new in town or just visiting SF, here is how I order it;

LARGE PHO GA  (That's their chichen pho of course!)
     - i ask for less noodles because its always more than enough noodles and i want all the beautiful broth i can get.. 
     - if you or your friend are squeamish about chicken skin, you can ask for no skin or just breast meat for a little extra $)  
     -everyone gets a side of sliced jalapenos and lemon wedge. Dump the jalapenos into the soup (if you are into spicy) and ask for some extra lemon.  I squeeze one wedge in the soup and one in the little condiment dish, where I will add fish sauce and pepper to taste. This is your "house-made" dipping sauce for your chicken:)
     -please note  this is northern vietnamese style so you dont get that plate full of bean sprouts and herbs

IMPERIAL ROLL 
     -entree order so you get the lettuce, vermicelli, and herbs to make wraps.
      -order comes with three rolls.  But you can order them individually (without the sides) if you are alone or want a just a little more.
     - I use a drizzle of sriracha in the dipping sauce for a little kick.

VIETNAMESE COFFEE 
     -thank God they still use the individual drip method (i hate it when it comes premixed)
