     -after brewing, I will sometimes carefully spoon out some of the sweetened condensed milk at the bottom of the glass. Then of course stirring together the coffee/milk and pouring it over the ice. (Its sometimes too sweet if you don't...you"ll understand when you see it) 

HOUSE TEA
     - its free and good for you 

Post Scriptum:
     "But joe, my boyfriend is in the mood for beef and he gets kinda crabby when he's hungover?"  I hear ya! No worries, when I'm in that red meat mood, their beef Pho is a very good arternative. But actually i would recommend:

 PHO BO AP CHAO NUOC (Stir-fried Beef with Celery, Carrot, Onion, and Leek) Its pan-fried with the same noodle and then soup is poured over.  I love this one too!
author: Joseph C.

description:
I really like the place on Larkin so I tried this new outpost. I smelled cat litter on entering and my #9 pho ga was just as this other Yelp writer mentions.
"the bottom line is that the pho ga was unappetizing. The chicken broth smelled funky."  I am writing this as a public service, in hopes that the management might notice and do a quick cleaning of the place and its broth practices. Plus am I wrong on the cat litter- cat box smell? Cat Litter smell is a real bad sign and this will reflect on the pristine , clean, authentic, & excellent Turtle Tower on Larkin's rep.

Please fix it.
A Fan of Pho
author: Ken S.

description: So amazing I've come here three days in a row. The chicken pho is so good that I dream about it sometimes. I get anxiety from even thinking about ordering anything else because of the intense FOMO I get from not getting the chicken. If I could not get fat I'd eat at turtle tower for every meal.
author: Jie G.

description: Everyone keeps talking about the pho here.  I think its OK... personally I think Chicken Pho you in millbrae is even better. They don't serve hoisin sauce here btw. Didn't have to wait for this location.
author: Stephanie C.

description:
There are a lot of reviews of this place that essentially rate it as "adequate."  That's being very charitable.  Or maybe people just have very low standards.  I think "terrible" is closer to the mark.  My wife ordered the Ph Gà. The chicken broth was bland and flavorless. Reminded me of Campbell's canned chicken noodle soup.  The cuts of chicken were all dark meat - fatty and gristly. No bean sprouts or basil, veggies which are standard with the dish everywhere else. I ordered the Bún Ch Hà Ni (pork with vermicelli). The pork came in a bowl with a greasy broth.  The Imperial Rolls were badly deep fried - dripping with grease.  

Sunflower (which is only ok, IMHO) is vastly superior.  If you want truly outstanding Vietnamese try Phuong Thao Sunnyvale.  Best I've had in the Bay Area.
author: Franklin F.

description:
And another 2012 Big Eat checked off the list!

We actually only came here because SO was closed on a Saturday night for some reason, but we've heard good things about Turtle Tower and it was right around the corner. It was a pretty cold day, so of course getting the Pho Ga was perfect. The Pho Ga really hit the spot, and came no more than 5 minutes after we ordered. The staff was definitely very quick, from order, to serving, to getting your check, so we were in and out within 30 minutes.

Street parking at this Turtle Tower location is pretty easy to find and it must not be one of the more popular locations considering the Yelp reviews and lack of wait we had, but the Pho Ga definitely lived up to its reputation!
author: Ada C.

description:
I came here for the free pho go deal from Scoutmob with my brother and friend.

We were seated right away by attentive waiters. They acknowledge the Scoutmob deal and were really nice about it. My brother had trouble getting on the app, but they took his word for it even though we insisted that we properly check in.

When our spring rolls and three hot steaming bowls of pho ga came out, we dug in right away cause we were starved.

The spring roll was a clear rice wrapper of greens, strips of sweet pork, vermicelli, and king shrimp. It comes with a satay-ish sauce with chopped peanuts, which was different cause usually it comes with a clear fish sauce with sweet, pickled carrot. I didn't really like the combination of the two and for four pieces for $5.50, I cannot justify ordering this again.

The pho ga did not have the classic rice vermicelli that is used for pho. I think this was cause we showed up late in the day and after a full week of free pho promotions, they ran out of those noodles.  However the broth and chicken did save the entree! The chicken is actual just-minced chicken, not some stale pieces chicken breast cutlet that's been sitting around for ages. It's not dry, it actually quite moist. That's a plus cause I honestly cannot stand eating dry sandpaper chicken. The stock used for the broth is flavored well enough that I didn't add any condiments, just a squeeze of lime to bring out the tanginess.

One thing I'd like to add is that they are CASH ONLY. They had one of those ATMs that charge a hefty fee for withdrawals and the nearest BoA or Chase is miles away.

Overall, Turtle Tower is good for your quick pho craving. It's not what you would go to for the best pho around SF, but it satisfies you when you're doing jury duty and the only other fare available is McDonald's.
author: Anna F.

description: So good ! I finished my bowl so fast and was eyeing my friend's until she finished. #10 is the way to go. You get more giblets at this location too. They just remodeled - glad they're re-opened!
author: amanda l.

description:
My boyfriend has been raving about this place for months now so, I decided to give it a try. Let me tell you, you will not be disappointed.

The flavors of the broth, noodles, and the type of meat of your choice is so delicious that you will not need to add any sort of condiment. The broth itself is really flavorful while the noodles are soft and fresh. I got the #4 which included 3 types of meats. All tasty and really easy to eat. It literally melts in your mouth. They do have a signature lemon sauce that you can ask for on the side that goes really well with the broth. Next time, I will probably get a small instead of the large. The large was way too much for me to finish and I did not want to waste any of the food. 

The service was cool and I did not have any problems with my food like other establishments that I have tried in the past. I will most definitely come back again.
author: Anastasia A.

description:
Tonight the muuusic seeems so loud!
I wish that! we! could! looose this crowd!
May-be! it's beeetter this wayyy.
We'd hurt each oth-er with the things we want to saaay.
We could have been so gooood togethah,
We could have lived this daannce forevah,
But nowwwww who's goonnnnna daance with meeee?
Pleeeease staaayy!

...And that was upon only having stepped inside the door.

$4.50 lets you choose 3 of the following to be included in one Vietnamese sandwich: fried egg, grilled chicken, grilled pork, jambon (ham), pate, sausage. I didn't ask, but I figure you can choose the same item for all 3 or do two-and-one if you want.

Note that the sandwich will be JUST the bread and whichever item(s) you select. If you want things that come standard on other restaurants' Vietnamese sandwiches, e.g., mayo, shredded carrots, cilantro, jalapenos, butter, etc., these can be added for $1.55 each.

Yes, each. As an example, think of a standard less-than-$5 chicken Vietnamese sandwich. It has bread, chicken, mayo (or something like it), cilantro, jalapenos, and shredded carrots, all included in the less-than-$5 price. This exact sandwich at Turtle Tower sets you back $10.70. Those following my Vietnamese math will recognize that this amount can get 3 sandwiches at Saigon Sandwich or a whopping 4 at Cam Huong. #justsayin

Another menu notable is the side dish "Long Ga: Chicken Giblets". Upon asking which giblets, I was told it's chicken intestines. A small is $3 and a large is $5. I'm definitely returning at some point to investigate.

ICED TEA: I watched the worker make this. It was a glass filled with 3/4 water then topped off with tea. I'm not talking about a glass of water into which were placed tea bags - this was already-brewed tea added to water. I could still taste the tea, but I thought the watering down aspect was odd.

The worker told me this location opened last year. So I'm guessing the 2007 and 2007-2008 ratings plaques on the wall were for the other locations. Also, there was a Scout Mob deal posted at the register, but I didn't read it.

You know I was,
I was wondering, you know, if
if you could keep on, because
the force, it, it's got a lot of power, and
it make me feel like um
it, it make me feel like uh...
WWOOOOOOO!!!

3 1/2 stars.
author: Dan B.

description:
Why, why do you disappoint me so. I got the vietnamese sandwich with pate, grilled chicken, and fried egg. I was hoping for the fried egg to be oozing out, but it's cooked well, more like a scramble.

I'm sticking to Grab-N-Go down the block for my vietnamese sandwiches.
author: Mandy D.

description:
One of the best soup joints I've ever been to.

The pan fried Beef noodle soup (menu item #6) is a-freakin-mazing. so good.

I take new co-workers there for lunch when they've been with the company awhile as a delicious rite of passage. 

Every single person I've taken there has jumped at the chance to go back..
author: Cmd C.

description:
My favorite pho Ga place.... I'm addicted to this place we come at least once a week. Best Pho Ga.
5 stars!!
author: Phoutty K.

description:
I've trekked all over Vietnam and while I'm not a fan of Northern Vietnamese beef pho... this was beyond meh. I was very disappointed. I couldn't eat more than 2 bites of the beef pho and ended up ordering some fried egg rolls just so I wouldn't be completely hungry. 

I'm a bit flabbergasted by the long wait lines for... this.
author: Evie D.

description:
This is the newest Turtle Tower location.  I came here around the time they first opened, and a few more times after that.  Out of all three locations, I'd have to say Larkin is the best, followed by Geary and then this one.  

Maybe its because this location is still relatively new, but the broth just doesn't taste quite as good as the Larkin location.  Their Pho Ga #9 is pretty much the same, but the #6-Stirfried beef with celery, carrot, onion and leek pan-fried noodle soup still needs to be perfected.  They need to stir fry the veggies longer to bring out the flavor.  The broth needs more of a greasy flavor to it.  

The space is very small, so if you come during the lunch rush, expect to wait.  There's only street parking in the area, so make sure to bring change to feed the meters.
author: Patra I.

description:
First meal in SF after landing, of all the things to eat in SF what do I choose to eat?  Pho.

Parking as it typically is for my spoiled O.C. girl self, horrible.  

It's a small shop and there was just one girl manning the whole place when I went, but it also wasn't busy either.

Pho ga without giblets/innards - broth had a nice deep flavor to it and the noodles were the fresh rice noodles which I thoroughly enjoyed.  However, I ordered the large to share with my friend who wasn't really hungry and I have to ask, "Where's the chicken?!"  They put a tiny portion of chicken meat that would barely qualify for the amount a kid's bowl would have.  

The downside of this spot is that they didn't give me any of basil and bean sprouts that I really like to put in my soup, and the condiments were lacking.  The chili paste was not the good stuff and made my soup taste like a Chinese supermarket.  Thankfully I had spooned that portion off into a small bowl before I put the chili paste in.  

Two stars for the broth and fresh noodles, I think I might come back, but maybe to another location just because I'm curious to see why they have higher ratings.
author: Priscilla C.

description: chicken noodle soup that I was looking forward to was way too salty. we also ordered the stir fried beef with vegetables rice plate. the beef was also very salty. very disappointed.
author: Linda O.

description: Came to this place with a coworker for lunch and we requested a table for 2. The owner asked if we mind sharing a table of 4 with two other strange men that we did not know. We kindly said we would prefer a table for the two of us for privacy. The owner gave us a mean look and whispered to his waiter "These guys don't want to share so they will have to wait." A party of four arrived shortly after us and he sat them at our table right away. I asked why he didn't seat us first since we are waiting. He said he did not want to lose money because we are only two and doesn't want to "waste" a table for four on us. He never apologized for the inconvenience he just kept saying "Since you don't want to share best go somewhere else" nowhere in the restaurant does it say you have to sit with strangers. I get horribly disrespected and will never come back here again. I asked for the General Manager and Tai said that it was him. I cannot believe how he treated us. He never smiled or apologized he had this mean look on his face "share or get out of my fucking restaurant." I hope he goes out of business this place is a fucking joke.
author: Michael P.

description: Sometimes you just need chicken noodle soup!!! If you want more veggies, order number 5 with chicken instead of beef. Then you get celery, carrot, and onions too. I wish you could just buy the fried chicken leg without the whole rice plate and that they took credit cards bc I don't often carry much cash.
author: Patricia A.

description: Not sure why the SOMA location is rated 3 stars. When they first opened, they dealt with some issues but seem to have ironed out the kinks. Always providing more than satisfying pho and fresh spring rolls.  My go to is their rare beef pho. Helps that they accept credit cards now.
author: Anna C.

description: Oddly rude, wouldn't seat my party of two at a reasonable sized table despite availability. Didn't eat there and won't return.
author: Richard F.

description:
Ventured to the Turtle Tower in SoMA and ordered the Pho Tai (rare beef noodle soup). First time trying "Northern style" pho, which apparently is served without the bean sprouts, basil leaves, and lime wedges that I'm accustomed to. No worries, going with the flow, I thought...

Either I was extremely hungry, or it was just that good. I'm leaning towards the former and a wee bit of the latter. I do have to say, their rare beef was exceptionally on par - soft and tender, melts in your mouth, just the right amount of redness, and complimented the soup base well. Though I finished all of my soup (an anomaly for me), I did feel as if it was missing...something. Let's just say, an extra kick. Bean sprouts, basil leaves, and/or lime wedges sure would have been perfect! 

Overall, my friend and I were satisfied with our noodle soups on a such a chilly and rainy early evening. However, my friend did say the main location is better in terms of food. Lat but not lease, cash only.
author: Phoebe C.

description:
My family is from the northern region of Vietnam. I took my mums here when the place hadn't relocated yet and after trying the pho ga soup, she exclaimed that, "dis style of cooking bringing me back to the nort". Sure, whatever that means. 
I had no clue what she's talking about but after a few more dinings here, I was hooked. Why? Because it's just like how my mums cooks her pho! Yes, it's a very simple yet complex dish. It's essentially broth from beef bone marrow with some spices and herbs but it takes a long time to cook as with any bouillon extraction. In any case, this soup is Bac (northern) style cooking (usually lean, bland and simple). 

I come here strictly for their pho tai (flat rice noodles with beef in beef broth). I find that the homemade noodles have just the right amount of consistency to them; not too chewy not to mushy-soft, a little slippery with a light bite. The taste is very light and you can definitely taste the freshness of noodles just made. With the slightly sweet, subtle taste of the broth with simple garnishes like green onions and cilantro (none of that beansprout nonsense), it is really the soup for the soul. That with the semi rare slices of beef, that gets cooked in the hot simmering broth to give it the right tenderness, is seriously some good stuff. I can't help but feel at home with my mums whenever I eat a bowl of this stuff. I can really relate to my mums when she says that this reminds her of home in Vietnam because a bowl of this belly good stuff brings me back home, where my heart is- with my mums! 

Oh, it's very casual, good for solo lunches and cash only. And they open as early as 10 am on weekdays. Go get your pho-licious fixins peeps!
author: Laurel P.

description: I wish to give this place four stars because everything else was flawless but the pho was honestly a disappointment. It was good but that's because I was hungry  I got the rare beef as recommended on Yelp. It was literally one small, but really delicious piece of meat. I've also had plenty better broth.
author: Tiffany H.

description: Got the chicken pho and oh man...that broth is delicious. Not too heavy but still full of flavor. This dish is perfect for cold, rainy days because it'll just make your insides feel warm. Loved how it had thick noodles rather than the traditional skinny ones. This dish also gave you like real chicken but my only qualm is that the chicken to noodle ratio was a bit lacking (not enough chicken). Because the dish was so flavorful, you don't need siracha or hoisen sauce.
author: Alice C.

description:
Grilled pork appetizer - the pork flavor isn't really good, and it was grilled for far too long. Stay away from this.

Imperial rolls - this is tasty, but it's super greasy

Pho combination - their pho uses flat noodles, also only comes with jalapeño and lemon. The meat is too rare for me. Also no tendons. Broth had a funny taste. I would never come here for pho. I didn't like it at all.
author: Mark D.

description: Got pho ga delivered last night because I wasn't feeling well & it was pretty good. I wish they had bean sprouts and hoisin sauce though ... That always elevates the pho. I'd give this place 3 1/2 stars
author: danielle a.

description:
Stumbled in
for some late-night pho.
Ordered up a bowl of Pho Ga
Not bad, kinda average...
...for some reason I like the Turtle Tower in the 'loin better.
...better yet are the pho places in SJ
...my parked car was still there afterwards.
...pardon my random thoughts.
author: Derek N.

description:
I know that the specialty here is Pho Ga (chicken Pho)  but I ordered the Pho Bo Dac Biet (Special Mixed Beef Pho) instead . The service of the pho was different in that they presented it with just a couple wedges of lemon and some sliced jalapenos . We didn't get the plate of bean sprouts and Asian basil that you get with pho in other places. I was told this was because they serve a Northern style of pho unlike the Southern style served in other places.  There was also no hoisin sauce on the table which is also indicative of the Northern style of pho. 

The soup was more delicate than the usual bowls of pho I've had previously. The broth was lighter and the soup was herb-ier. I added a little fish sauce (that was on the table's condiment cradle) to add a little salt hit to the pho. 

The soup was great and I'd definitely eat here again. I like their lighter brtoh and more delicate soup.
author: Sherman B.

description:
I visited Turtle Tower with my mom on a Friday afternoon around 1:00 pm. I thought we would miss the lunch rush, but there was still a group of customers hovering around the front entrance. We put our name on the list and the lady let us know that it'd just be 15-20 minutes.  In a little bit less than 15 minutes, we were seated and with menus/water in front of us.  

My mom and I ordered:
-Pho ga (Chicken, noodle soup) ($6.20 for a small bowl).  The bowl itself was big enough to share between my mom and I, since we had ordered another dish as well.  The dish has a very simple and subtle flavor to it.  They give a fair amount of noodles and several small pieces of chicken (with the skin on it).  This was alright, but I wish it had a little bit more flavor to it.  I added jalepenos to try and spice it up a bit.

-Pork rice noodle rolls ($8.70): this was my first time trying this dish (I'm not sure what the Vietnamese name is) and it was pretty good.  The rice rolls are filled with chopped up/ground pork and topped with fried onion pieces.  It also had a pretty simple flavor.  It came with a dipping sauce, but I also requested fish sauce for a little bit more flavor.  It was nice trying both of the sauces. 

-Tricolored drink (about $3).  I usually don't like these types of drinks, but my mom wanted one- so I tried it out.  It was very sweet, but pretty good overall.  There are beans and jelly in the drink.

The restaurant itself is pretty small, with maybe 10 tables or so.  It seems like they do a lot of to-go orders.  There are a lot of people working in the back/kitchen constantly bagging up orders.  I'm not sure if it is worth a wait longer than 15 minutes or if it should be on the 7x7 list- but it's okay. 

Notes:
-Street parking may be difficult during the daytime. I was lucky and found a free two hour space just half a block away.
-Be willing to share a table, it'll cut the wait time.
author: Samantha L.

description: After eating here I never needed to go to another pho place. The freshness is unmatched and they use real meat and tripe that doesn't seem to be frozen! You won't be disappointed
author: Claudia R.

description:
Scoutmob free pho ga for the win!  

Came here for Friday lunch; beat the lunch rush crowd.  I parked a block away in a free two-hour street parking zone.  

Got my small bowl of free pho ga and ordered 12. bun cha to go... they have good bun cha; love the pork patties.  Pho ga is actually not my thing but for free.99 it was de-rish-shus.

Fast service, cheap food... I prefer the TL location for some reason but the food tastes the same.
author: Erika C.

description:
I'm soooo excited that this opened in our neighborhood! Had dinner here last night and pho ga was soooo good. It totally hit the spot on a cold night. It still taste the same from the other place in the TL. And the place is a lot cleaner and they take credit card! We ran in at 8:57pm and they still served us even when they're suppose to close at 9pm.

Definitely be back here again to have my fav pho in the city! :)
author: Cynthia C.

description: If the Pho Ga (#9) isn't interesting enough for you I recommend #6, which has some stir fried vegetables and stir fried noodles for extra flavor.  #6 comes with beef but they'll substitute chicken for an extra $1.
author: Dave B.

description:
(See pics)

Review #1022.

Chicken- energizes!
Soup- heats up!

Pho Ga is 3.75 stars but everything else is 3.

Came here and tried different dishes and most memorable is the pho ga (chicken.) The soup base was excellent and was very hot. The fun was soft and tender. The chicken was okay.

They didn't have fresh soy milk on one evening but did have green coconut. However, it was not the whole fruit but was with 3 slices of coconut and coconut juice in water and ice cubes.

The fish patty was a bit salty but added hot sauce made it better and it eas only $2.50.

Other dishes such as vermicelli and seafood chow fun were more Chinese style and were okay.

The take is stick to the pho, especially in one of those chilly San Francisco evenings!
author: T L.

description: I'm not big on pho, but I really liked the pho here. I hear it's even better at the other locations, so I'm eager to check them out. The spring rolls weren't the best I've ever had, but the pho and chicken broth were mmMm mMmm mmmm.
author: Diana K.

description: Great consistent pho! Been my to go spot for years!  Bang mi is as long really solid. Often busy but they handle it well.
author: Ben C.

description: I agree with the other reviewers; the other location in the Tenderloin tastes better! The broth is not served piping hot.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
The Pho Ga (chicken) is perfect for a cold night or if you're feeling under the weather. Mix of white and dark meat in a flavorful broth with thick white noodles. 

Cash only.
author: CL S.

description: Orange Juice is not exactly fresh squeezed. I watched the hostess get an already squeezed glass out of the fridge. At the other turtle tower they squeeze it right when ordered. Ordered a # 4 with steak on the side and chicken broth and a Pho Ga. Pho Ga didn't have much chicken and the broth wasn't that great plus there was a hair or something like that in the pho ga. We were given a new pho ga after telling the hostess about it.
author: Adeline L.

description:
Thank you Scoutmob for FREE Pho Ga!

My husband and I tried pho for the first time...and what a better way then by getting it for free.  We arrived around 3pm on the last day of the Scoutmob offer.  Luckily the wait for a table wasn't long.

However, after we were seated, it took a LONG time for someone to take our order.  Several wait-staff walked past our table several times.  Two of them made eye contact but kept walking.  One of them even took the order of someone who was seated after us (at least he didn't have to wait too long).  Other than the long wait to order, the staff was pretty friendly.

After we ordered, the food came pretty quickly.  Maybe it was because I was a pho-virgin but I felt that the pho was really bland.  The noodles had no flavor.  The broth, although very clean, also lacked flavor.  I used the lime wedge and jalapenos that accompanied our soup but that wasn't enough.  I had to ask for more lime and added maybe 3 spoonfuls of fish sauce (and I'm not a big salt person).

I think I just may stick to ramen...
author: Rose A.

description:
Went to this location of Turtle Tower Restaurant, 6th & Bryant, because of the Scoutmob deal.  It's a long walk from Civic Center Bart so I don't recommend walking.  Better to drive.

Wait was maybe 1hr, I don't know.  Very long.  We still put our name on the list.

FREE Small pho ga chicken noodle soup (reg $6.20).  I loved it.  B. not so much, he doesn't like their noodles, but I did.

Giu Cuon Spring rolls $5.15 - 2 rolls cut up w/ mint, shrimp, pork, fresh rice paper, peanut sauce on the side. Tasted ok.

I wanted Banh Cuon - it's hard to find everywhere, so was looking forward to it.  Sold out when I went.  So sad.

Steamed chicken w/ bone $8.20 small - it was ok, nothing special.  Lemon/salty dipping sauce on the side.

Iced condensed milk Vietnamese coffee $3.20 - That's pricey for Vietnamese iced coffee.  Tasted ok.

Our total about $18 before tip.  They take credit card.  One unisex bathroom in the back.

Closed Sun
M-Sat 10-9

Website:
www.turtletowersf.com
author: Ann L.

description:
SCOUTMOB!!! For free pho ga it's pretty damn tasty. The broth has definitely been stewed for hours and there probably was 20+ chickens' bones in that soup. Yum! I also love how they de-bone the chicken and it was boiled just like how my mom makes it. I wish it came with bean sprouts, maybe for the paying customers they will provide it in the future. 

The imperial rolls (fried egg rolls) are ok. Nothing to rave. I don't think I'll order it again as it was expensive. I think I'll just go for the pho ga if I'm craving it. Nothing else on the menu looked impressive.
author: Vanessa K.

description: I love pho and eat a lot of it all over the bay area so I'm always interested in finding a new restaurant to try out. this place was great. It's small so I guess it can be crowded at lunch but we only waited about 10 minutes just after noon. the soup was delicious and the prices fair. I like meat pho with lots of veggies and this place had a few of these options. some places give you just meat or just veggies, so this worked for me. CASH ONLY, but two bowls of pho were $15 so no problem.
author: Bob U.

description:
I'm not a big fan of pho, really. I never crave it. I've never said "Wow, this is great!"

Well, Turtle Tower.. you've changed my mind. Perhaps I was starving after a soccer game when I happened to stumble into here.. but yes, this was pho that actually made me exclaim, "Wow!" 

This northern-style, chicken broth pho really hit the spot. It tastes much lighter, and yet, has so much flavor. Some citrus in the broth also enhances the soup. The noodles were also just the right texture. Just tough enough to not be chewy, and not disgustingly soggy.

I'm definitely coming back! Next time.. we'll see how this place works as a hangover cure!
author: Kazu O.

description: Chicken Pho, spring rolls and imperial roll were all excellent.  Location is clean and has a nice modern feel.  The service was fantastic, so sweet and accommodating.  Highly recommended!
author: Patrick S.

description:
I love love love a steaming bowl of pho on a foggy cold SF day which is like 285 days a year....  After hitting most of the well reviewed spots on Yelp, Turtle Tower is hands down my favorite for taste.  I get the same thing every time, pho ga (chicken).  The broth is light, flavorful, and very tasty, the noodles are thicker than the typical vermicelli, but I like it more, all the accouterments condiments (cilantro. & onion) are already added except for hot peppers, no side of basil & bean sprouts, but I don't miss them one bit.

This is like comfort food from granny if granny lived in Hanoi.  I look at this as my healthy alternative to Ramen :).

Other locations are equally tasty in the Tenderloin & Richmond.  The SoMa location has the easiest parking.  Cash only, service is fast but zero frill.

For hipper versions of tasty pho that feels less authentic but there is decor & better service, I also like Tin on Howard  & Mau in the Mission.
author: Rosalyn C.

description: Ok, I gave it another try, Was told that the Chicken noodle soup was the truth.  Yes indeed, it was good.  Come to find out that this is their pride and joy.  If you do happen to eat here, order this for sure.  The only thing they forget to add when taking to go orders is the lemon pepper sauce, which enhances the soup.  Double check to make sure they throw that in.
author: Pedro N.

description:
The one on Larkin was way better than this.

I've been craving Turtle Tower for awhile now and decided to go to this location just because it closes later than the one on Larkin. They have a dinner menu and a lunch menu but you can order from either one. Of course I stuck with the only thing I really know, their Pho Ga (chicken noodle soup).

The Pho Ga broth was a bit salty than I last remembered it. So salty that I poured a quarter of my water in my bowl and probably could have gotten away with pouring the rest of my water in too (well maybe not). The noodles were also mushy and overcooked. Probably the reason why I didn't really feel like finishing it all up.

Their service was good. She made sure that right when I put my menu down, she would take my order so I wasn't left waiting.  I loved how they poured us water using the Brita Filter.
author: Lauren K.

description:
Holy Crap 3 stars really? This place was recommended by our Vietnamese friends. I couldn't be more happy with the recommendation myself. My children and their mother love it too. 

It is not a fancy place, but it is nicely decorated, super comfortable. Food is phenomenal, affordable, and a lot of it. They didn't bug out because we share like crazy and that's always a bonus because we always do.
author: Marc R.

description:
A popular local lunch spot. You can go there and see folks who work at the police station nearby grabbing a quick bite to eat.

They even have pho to go, which is handy if you're in a hurry.
author: Ellie P.

description: The place is not the nicest but definitely the best chicken noodle soups in the neighborhood. I also like the fresh squeezed orange juice. A great place when you feel something not heavy and soupy.
author: Shannon J.

description:
This isn't the best chicken pho I had but I think it does its job.  Friends of mine told me that they are known for their chicken pho so I had to give it try.  I went to the TL location first and found out there was a location closer to where I live.   I always order the chicken and giblets pho with a Vietnamese ice coffee!  I think Pho is the perfect cure for being sick.  This place is cash only but the quick service is always a bonus.

I also really like their dessert glass  counter near the cashier.  All the noms!
author: Alister L.

description:
Been going here since 2007, when I moved up here. Went every week, but now that I moved far away and have a busier schedule, I try to go every month. The owners are really nice and staff is friendly. They have the best pho ga I have had and brought friends (from SF and out of town) here every chance I get to any of their locations in the tenderloin or mission bay. But why the two stars? 

The flavors have been consistently tasty. However, after years of patronage, I am indignant at the change that they made. Went last Friday for my fix, and I realized that their portions decreased! Their small looks petite and their large looks like a medium. Came hungry and left hungry. 

It's understandable that they increased their prices $ 0.25-0.30 year after year, but to decrease their portions, too! It felt like a "screw you - we care only about getting ur money!" In light of the expansion of TT with the larger space in the tenderloin, expanding to mission bay, and offering delivery over the past couple years, I was very happy for the owners and for the increased availability of my fix. But if the growth comes with the greed that leaves customers feeling stupid and cheated, I will have to take my money elsewhere. 

Going to miss you TT! But as you know (since you have made it abundantly obvious), it's only business.
author: Mi M.

description:
I came here with a friend because she had a scoubt mob deal...free chicken noodle soup! I expected it to be a small bowl of soup, but it was actually quite big and good. It's a Vietnamese version of the dish. It definitely was not pho though.

The service was nice, but seemed a bit aggressive. I didn't like how they made us give them our email addresses. 

The imperials rolls were small. It cost $2 something for one teeny roll. Poo!

All in all, it was decent - probably because I only paid $4 including tip.
author: Margaret R.

description:
Came here on a late Saturday afternoon and the place was empty. Minutes later, a couple more parties trickled in, so I guess we brought business with us.

We all opted for the PHO GA and I got the PHO GA LONG (with chicken gizzards). Although we all ordered a small, the portion was pretty decent, I wasn't able to finish mine. It came with a generous amount of rice noodle, overwhelming amount of green onions, a handful of chicken slices, and a limited amount of gizzards. Although it wasn't bad, it wasn't amazing either. The broth seemed watered down and a bit lacking in flavor. 

Aside from the "Northern style pho" (thicker noodles) that distinguishes this place from its counterparts, I can honestly say that Turtle Tower did not leave much of an impression.
author: Ada C.

description:
Finding myself frequently in the mood for pho lately, Anna D and I dropped by Turtle Tower on her suggestion, seeing as I'd been avoiding them up until now. For what reason I did this is unclear now, and unfortunate, as it turns out that the food here is actually rather tasty.

After Anna explained that this wasn't your "typical" pho, and done in the style of North Vietnam, where they specialized in things like chicken noodle soup, I ended up ordering a pho ga, and getting an imperial roll to share. The imperial roll, while tasty, was a surprisingly small bite-size portion (given the price), and greasy to boot. The pho ga however, was enjoyable; it did, however, become fairly salty towards the end (probably a result of sitting in the broth so long).

And while I think they're a tad higher priced than most places, I can certainly see myself coming back for their noodles.
author: Johnny W.

description: Great food and great service. The pho ga is so hearty and hits the spot on these cold sf nights.
author: Aaron V.

description:
The Pho here is some of the best I've had.  It's warm and filling but also somehow fresh-tasting.  And that's just the broth.  Great offal cuts complemented with rare and well-done slices of beef make for a varied and robust meal.

Being sandwiched between warehouses, overpasses and gathering-places for the homeless, not to mention being several blocks from reliable transit, it is distinctly uncomfortable to walk to even if you're used to the area.  That combined with the early closing bell and the broken ATM (it's a cash-only place) make it feel like they don't really want your business.  But sometimes you just gotta plan ahead and make the trek.

I haven't had any of the other dishes.  Withe pho that good, why would you want to?
author: Nathan C.

description:
The second time I came here, I remembered why I didn't like it the first time around. The noodles for the pho are all wrong - they are wide rice noodles and extremely overcooked. Perfect, if you have no teeth. 

Also, I had always thought thai basil, bean sprouts and hoisin were standard accompaniments for pho. Like ketchup with a burger. Not so at Turtle Tower. Ask for it, and they will laugh at you. What??

People seem to like the pho ga at Turtle Tower. But i'm doubtful that would have been any better than my pho tai. The pho ga comes with the same mushy noodles and lack of veggies. Add to that a sketch location and it's certain that I won't make the same mistake in coming here again.

**UPDATE**
Another Yelper kindly pointed out that Turtle Tower serves Northern Vietnamese style pho, which uses minimal garnish/condiments and wide noodles. Lesson learned: for  delicious pho, seek out Southern Vietnamese restaurant.
author: Cindy T.

description:
Now that I've managed to have the beef and chicken pho many times, I do have to say that their broth is something different from most standard pho places.  It does have a bit more umami flavor (rather than just pure salty) in the chicken broth.  My wife adores them because she says their chicken broth, of all pho places, tastes the most "clean".  

The sandwiches are good (I like the options to choose 3 proteins), and the summer rolls and egg rolls are solid.  Overall, a pretty solid menu.  

Tips: Cash only.  Parking is a pain around that area (especially around rush hour), so if you're super lazy and willing to pay a $10 fee, you can use trycaviar.com to get them to deliver it to you.  They are a little stingy with their condiments, so make sure you ask for them.
author: Frederick L.

description: Order fresh spring rolls and got refrigerated spring rolls. I'll stick w the Larkin location next time.
author: May N.

description:
Terrible service and attitude. 

First time I asked to order, the sarcastic response I got was: 'IF you don't mind, there's a table ahead of you, is that ok!?' 

When I asked for the check to the waiter who was cleaning up the table next to me, his response was: 'you gonna have to wait.' And then he continued to clean the table. 

The food was mediocre. I would never go back again.
author: Kelvin Y.

description:
A great replacement for the horrid TEN7M that was here as well as the Quizno's before it. This is exactly the sort of thing SoMa needs to revitalize the lower area from like 6th to 8th St. The kitchen turns out perfect pho just like the other location, no disappointment there. Service was still a little green but it's opening week so they get a break. (I had to suddenly change my order to a take out order and they got a bit confused. Happens everywhere.) I'll be at Turtle Tower regularly for my work from home days in SF.

Watch out for the weekday lunch crowd - they are totally descending on this place! And with good reason!
author: Josh K.

description:
The broth is a little different and wasn't bad. Personally, I'd prefer the regular pho broth to this one. 

The service was decent but we kept having to ask for water, they hardly ever served us unless we asked. 

The place is a little small but the prices are like that of a typical pho restaurant. 

OVERALL: not bad but I'd prefer somewhere else
author: Titus S.

description:
I LOVE Turtle Tower. I think it is THE best pho I have ever had. 

This place is northern Vietnamese food. Not your typical pho. So if you come in, don't expect it to be the skinny noodles with bean sprouts/basil and lime. They don't give you that extra condiments.

My favorite from there is the Pho Ga. The Chicken Noodle Soup. The noodles are soft and not too hard. The chicken is not too dry. And the soup has a great taste. I love coming here when I'm sick, cause it clears up my nose and makes me feel better. 

Every time I am in SF, especially if it is on a cold day, I will try to make my way to go to one. They have three locations, the one I usually go to is the one in Richmond. However, I was at AT&T Park and the one on 6th St. was closer.

If your gonna eat pho and your in the city, I would say go there. It's too good to not try it out.
author: Alice T.

description:
Let me start off by saying I really like Turtle Tower. I have been to all the different locations in San Francisco. And it's hard for me not to like a Pho place.

But this place is incredibly incredibly disappointing. The food is tolerable, but the service is unbearable.

We stopped in on a late afternoon to grab a 'quick' lunch. There were four of us, and we just wanted the basics. The restaurant was full, but I would not call it busy. We stood there for 15 minutes, without getting a seat. No one sitting down at the tables were getting served. They were clearly properly staffed, as half a dozen staff stood their idle. They had this poor girl at the front of house managing everything. We finally gave up, and decided to order our food to go. We thought that would speed things up. Nope... We stood there for another 30 minutes waiting for our food. This is Vietnamese food! It should not take more than 10 minutes to prepare. In the process, we also saw a few people who got their seats, decide to walk out as well. 

I have no idea why this place still gets business. Their food is fine, if you don't mind waiting an eternity to get it luke warm.
author: Winny F.

description:
What is all the rage about this place? 

First I must admit that I've been eating Vietnamese food for the past 15 years and I never ever order chicken pho, I always go for the beef. 

Apparently, I've been eating southern Vietnamese food all my life because Turtle Tower touts itself as a Northern Vietnamese restaurant. 

We ordered the chicken pho and the lemongrass shaking beef bun (noodle), and a Vietnamese ice coffee 

chicken pho: flavor is okay but nothing to write home to. maybe it's good for when you are sick and want chicken soup but I wouldn't want this normally 

lemongrass shaking beef bun-horrible. the beef was gross, the noodle was gross, the sauce was gross. I hardly ate any of it and it's a big bowl for $8.20. If we come back again, I will NEVER order this dish. 

The highlight of my meal was the Vietnamese ice coffee that came in the actual french press. Amazing. The only bummer was that t was $3.50 for a little cup =(
author: Betty C.

description:
I came here for dinner with my gf on Monday night looking to score some delicious vermicelli. Boy was I disappointed. I didn't realize that this place is only really known for their Pho...which I am not a fan of. Instead, I directed my gaze towards their vermicelli, of which they only had two choices...and neither looked that good. 

When the waiter came around to grab our order (friendly and attentive guy btw, this review is entirely about the food at this place. The service was fine), my gf ordered the beef Pho and I asked for the vermicelli. To my surprise, they are all out of that. What? No vermicelli? At a Vietnamese restaurant? The hell! Ok ok...I am sure I can order something else. Nothing else on the menu looked appetizing (remember, I don't like Pho), so my gf finally recommended the beef stew. Ok, one beef Pho and one beef stew please *gulp*. I guess the worst thing would be that the food tastes bad. Its only $9. We'll just grab froyo afterwards anyways.

Our food arrives a short time after we order (again, the service is fine here). Boy, did my beef stew look disappointing. There was a side of rice, a tiny (and I mean tiny) bowl of beef stew, and what was supposed to pass as a salad. I've never seen a more depressing salad in my life! It consisted of a tiny piece of lettuce, a slice of a vegetable I didn't recognize and five peels of a carrot (yes, I counted). At least the Pho looked palatable. 

I took a bite of the beef stew and was completely disgusted!!! The stew consisted entirely of beef fat (or what I think was beef fat). Small globes of fat that must have been sitting around in the kitchen for days. At this point I just gave up with enjoying the meal entirely. I finished the cup of rice and waited for my gf to finish the Pho (she tried a piece of the stew and said she's never seen beef stew taste this bad before). 

We paid the bill and left promptly. It was the most expensive cup of rice I've ever had. We stopped by Subway on the way back to the car and then got some froyo. That footlong couldn't have tasted any better!

I just hope my experience at this place was a one of, and that it was a bad idea coming here on a Monday night anyways (perhaps the food is leftovers from the weekend?)
author: Sasha T.

description:
To be honest, I like Southern Vietnamese food better so that may skew my perspective of this place as this is Northern Vietnamese food.

What really turned me off to this place was the hostess/waitress.  Since we're relatively new to this style, my friends and I asked a few questions and the waitress reacted more annoyed than anything else.  It wasn't as if the entire place was packed and we were holding her up.  The place was half-empty so she had the time to "sell" the food and help us decide.  Also, the service was relatively slow as we had to ask for water several times before it was actually brought out.

As for the food, it was just ok.  It wasn't memorable either way.  I left a bit unsatisfied so I went to another Vietnamese restaurant the next day for lunch in order to satiate my craving.
author: Ron E.

description:
Come early to avoid the lunch rush. Lots of jury duty ppl here so be prepared to share a table to be seated faster.

I love thier pho ga and be sure to order extra jalapenos on the side. I also got thier vietnamese iced coffee which kept me awake for the just of day of jury selection 0_0
author: Christine W.

description:
Open early. 

I'm a little surprised after reading other reviews because I feel like I receive nothing but 5 star service!

I've never had to wait, my food is always hot (even when I'm running late from meetings)

They offered a great coupon during their "Grand Opening" (a little upset they didnt have a full menu this day, was still their "limited menu". Even if they did give a deal, I've never felt like I had to use it because I find the food cheap already!

My recommendations are definitely a banh mi: any way you like it, and their chicken pho. very flavorful and the noodles are definitely refreshing from the more norm vietnamese restaurants.
author: Sheena S.

description:
The pho is okay. Nothing special. 
Their Vietnamese coffee is really good though because it's strong and aromatic. 
They don't have the best customer service though. Majority of the staff is rude. Here's one thing that happened: They forgot to bring me a straw when I ordered my coffee so I went to the front desk to ask for one. I can let it slide that they didn't apologize, but it really pissed me off when they blamed me for it. They claimed that they don't need to provide straws unless the customer specifically requests for it, so it's my fault that I didn't get a straw. Funny thing was everyone before and after me got straws with all their drinks, including the coffee.
author: Joey I.

description: Went in to pick up my order. Asked for no cilantro and when I pointed out that my order had cilantro they offered to make a new one...and charge me for both. Awful.
author: Megan M.

description:
The dirtier the restaurant, the better the food.  From my experience, that's not always the case.  Although that might explain why the original Turtle Tower in the tenderloin, which was a pretty dirty restaurant before the renovation, has a higher rating than this one.  My taste buds however say that both turtle towers are equally good.. and my eyes and nose tell me this location is cleaner.

Whenever I feel like Northern style pho with the thick rice noodles and no bean sprouts, this is my go-to spot.  The broth is always so flavorful and clean.. unlike the other pho places in sf.  Haven't tried the other things on the menu, and don't plan on trying them any time soon.

Typical asian restaurant service, which essentially means subpar service.  If the service was better, four stars easy.
author: Shawn P.

description:
First time here. Hot day, so i ordered the Bun Cha, grilled pork and pork sausage over vermicelli.  It came on a plate.  I'm used to having this served in a bowl so you can mix the meat, vegetables, and sauce all together.  Maybe because I'm a new face, they wanted to see how I was going mix and eat without making a huge mess.  The waiter later gave me a small rice bowl, so I could mix about 2 mouthful at a time. Very tedious, but I wasn't in a hurry.  The food was good; pork and sausage were very good and not salty.  Noodles were good and had a nice flavor.

Oddly, the whole place smelled like bleach.  Maybe they just finished cleaning the place before I got there.  I'll have to go back to try some of their other dishes.
author: Les T.

description: I'm a broth girl - totally makes the pho or ramen or whatever Asian noodley thing you've got. So far, this broth is more convenient than tasty. They're super fast and reliable if you need a pho-quickie but watch out, they only accept CASH.
author: Dora C.

description: You're a fool if you get anything but the pho ga here. If you stick to that plan you'll have one of the greatest cheap meals you can get in sf.
author: Peter N.

description: We had very high expectations as people rave about Turtle Tower, albeit normally they talk about the tenderloin location.  We ordered out on a Monday night and got 4 dishes and every single one was inedible.  The spring rolls and banh mi were stale, the pho bo xao had burnt noodles, and both the pho bo xao and the com ga xao ca chua were bland.  We couldnt even finish the food.  We are never eating here again!
author: Lindsey F.

description:
The San Francisco fog is clinging to you like vines on a tree, chilling you to the bone. The wind isn't strong, but annoying in its persistence. It's dark. You see drab faceless buildings housing wares unknown. You are hungry. You need something hot. Something that will invigorate your soul. You need pho.

Well, here's the place to get it if you ever find yourself on Bryant and 6th, wandering the streets.

Go for the rare beef, and tripe. Toss in all those peppers and whatever else they give you that's fresh. Go easy on the sriracha. A small bowl is plenty actually, and if you are extra hungry, ask for extra meat. 

And bring cash.
author: Boris C.

description: Very ordinary pho. Broth is a bit bland and service was a bit slow too.
author: Austin W.

description: Dude, this location sucks!  My Banh Mi was missing 3 ingredients and the Pho was bland and lacked edible pieces of meat .  Why does this location under perform?  It's like they have no idea how good the tenderloin location is.
author: Darin E.

description:
This place IS clean for a pho joint!  And the service was good -- when we left we were thanked by multiple staff members for our business.

I tried the chicken pho, which was just ok.  The noodles were overcooked.  Also tried the fresh spring rolls with shrimp & pork, served with a peanut sauce, and those were pretty good -- they used more lettuce and less vermicelli noodles, but the portion size was reasonable and the presentation was nice.
author: Beatrice W.

description:
Chicken pho was okay; it was too bland for me after about 5 spoons.  I had to spice mine up with lime, pepper, fish sauce, and sriracha lol!  Basically very light and clean chicken broth soup with noodles and small pieces of chicken.   I really didnt like the haw fun noodles, i prefer the traditional pho vermicelli.  There was not enough chicken in my soup either, they really skimp on the chicken.  And what i don't like was they put little pieces of chicken fat strips in the soup..that's kind of disgusting no?

The weird thing was my friend ordered his with no cilantro..the soup tasted better but it was also oiler.  It was almost like a different soup base because his was more cloudy and mine was a cleaner clearer broth.  But we both ordered the same thing!   

I would only come here if i was sick and needed a light and clean broth.  The broth was nicely made with chicken flavor..but how much chicken broth can you really drink?  I definitely prefer regular pho...not worth the hype at all!
author: Terence N.

description: Very rich a flavorful Pho. Good price. Fun little whole in the wall. Much better than Black Pepper Pho.
author: Gentry W.

description:
Stick to their tried and true and you won't leave too disappointed.

Stumbled in on New Years Day and was promptly seated and fed. Thank you Asian joints for always being reliably open on any holiday! We went with not Pho for some reason... I guess we were feeling adventurous this new year, and it was a mixture of hit and miss. 

The Spring Rolls are solid 3stars... I'd get them again if ever in the mood.

The Chao Ga (Chicken Porridge) wavers at 3stars... Its on the thicker side than what I'm used to, and the chicken was kinda dried out and bland.... definitely not as good as what my mom makes at home, but it will do.

The Beef Stew in Red Wine Sauce??... I've never seen anything like it. We were thinking it was going to be more like Bo Ca Ri (Beef Stew Curry)... but it was beef stew in a strange artificial looking red wine sauce that tasted purely like corn starch - eeck, pass!

From my experience, I'd say the Tenderloin location is probably better, but for being conveniently located down the street for our lazy asses... this place is a-okay.  Just remember that it is cash only like all other Asian hole-in-the-walls.
author: Lana N.

description: Usually no line at this location. Food comes out fast! The chicken pho here is so good! Perfect comfort good!
author: Xue C.

description:
This review is just for the pho ga (chicken pho, number 9).  The broth is amazing.  It's our go to hangover meal.  

The first time I went to Turtle Tower, I ordered regular beef pho.  I remember being really unimpressed ... and it was just different from the pho I was used to.  I haven't ordered it since.  Stick with the chicken pho and you're good to go!
author: Dina H.

description:
Best pho I've ever had. The broth is to die over and the pho just raises my HP back to about 90% after a night of partying.

I prefer to go to this location as it's usually not as busy, it's more accessible as it's right off the freeway, and it just feels a little cleaner to me than though TL Turtle Tower.

The only thing that's a drag is that the restaurant is CASH ONLY. They have an ATM but who wants to have to pay withdrawal fees?
author: Christl A.

description: This place cuts corner everywhere. No basil, lemon instead is lime, fried spring row is as thin as my index finger. Skip this place.
author: Alfred L.

description: I love this restaurant because I love chicken pho and my little brother loves turtles - so I always think of him whenever I eat here. Also, they take credit card and the food comes out in 10 min. I tried my friends dishes and they all tasted good
author: Gina H.

description:
My wife and I have been wanting to go to Turtle Tower since it opened here and finally made the trip the other night because we were in the mood for Pho.  They have a dinner menu that I understand is unique to this location, but you can also order from their regular menu.  The dinner menu seemed to be pricier than the regular menu and everything we ended up having was from the regular menu.  I understand they have expanded their hours and are now open later.  

We decided not to have our usual Pho Tai and try some of the different things on their menu and I'm really glad we did.  My wife had the Bun Cha and that was by far the best dish of the night.  It was wonderful and the pork and sauce were just wonderful.  I got the Ap Chao which is a Beef Pho dish with pan fried noodles, vegetables, and stir fried beef.  It was also very good.  We also tried the Bunh Cuon, which was not out favorite dish, but still good.  Everything was flavorful and fresh.  The waitress who was working that night was very friendly and helpful in guiding us through a number of different options on the menu.  One of these days I'm sure I'll get back to try the Pho Tai, but with all the options on the menu I may end up trying something else.  It's a great place and I'm sure we'll be back.
author: Scott L.

description:
I've heard  SOOOO much about Turtle Tower being the must check out place for pho in the city and was really excited to go with some friends to the soma location. The six of us cramped in a little corner and waited anxiously for our food. It was just....ok. I kept thinking to myself the entire dinner, is this really it? What is the rave about? Am I missing something or did I order the wrong thing?

Broth is meh, nothing super flavorful. The meat comes in chunks and I'm at this point convinced I like the sliced meat better in pho and it was just....ok I guess.

Oh also, the bathroom at this location is gross. Seriously, not ok.
author: Angela S.

description:
I eat at this location on 01/23/2014,I had a very good small pork sandwiche..The bread was a crunchy "French bread" I requested no house dressing or butter.. I was prepared with cilantro, carrot , pork.. The meat was better then other tower place location..
It cost 4.50..
1-They sat me along with some dude sucking on his noodle soup.. I don't mind as long if the asked me.. Very ridiculous .
  2-There was a girl wearing a tight skirt on the other table and I didn't notice until she kind  switch seat thinking I was looking down on it.." Ooh well" I wasn't and 
I really wish I didn't come at this particular location.. 
It is an unfortunately situation because I'm take class near by..
author: Pedro D.

description:
I only eat the pho ga at the Turtle Tower restaurants and this location has the same great flavor that I enjoy; however, sometimes the broth comes out darker than usual with a stronger taste.  

My review is really about my overall experience since I've been to this location several times in the last two months.  Their consistent service of having only one waiter on duty REALLY irks me.   Each and EVERY time it takes them at least 10 minutes to get me water and take my order after I've been seated, and that's pretty ridiculous to me considering it'll only take me 10 minutes to eat.  I've never spent an hour at a pho shop until I came to this spot (from being seated to paying and leaving).  Granted, the waiter is pleasant enough but  I HATE the service so much that I'll need to find another pho ga shop.  =(  I'm praying that the Larkin location is only closed for remodeling.

You might wonder, "why don't you just order to-go?" and the answer to that is I have and I got sick immediately afterwards.  Granted I didn't eat the soup till 2 hours later but I boiled the sh**t outta the broth so what the heck gives?? Maybe I should have microwaved the sh**t outta the noodles too, and along with it the jalapanos and lemon too???

Anyway, this location is terrible.  They really need at least two servers everyday.  I had my last straw with them Wednesday night; I'm not coming back.
author: Blia L.

description:
Go to the location in the tenderloin.  

First, they stopped serving Pho at 6pm.  They are trying a dinner menu.  Are you kidding?  The place is known for Pho.  At least offer it.  You can offer other stuff, but keep the heat on the Pho broth.   The service was terrible.  We waited for about 25 mins for soda.  It wasnt like they forgot, they kept coming by and telling us it is on the way.  

The dinner menu (which we were forced to get) was OK.  The pressure cooked duck was pretty good but not as flavorful as I would expect. Most of the flavor ended up in the noodle rather than the duck, so make sure you slurp up the noodled when you order this dish.  

The stir fried beef was pretty good, but nothing special.  Just beef cubes with brown sauce.  

Overall, the food was a 3 star experience, but the service and the lack of Pho at dinner takes it to 2 stars.

By the way, the lemon soda we waited for...not worth it.  It was basically Sprite with a squeeze of lemon.  They would have been better off doing it like in Vietnam and use club soda and maybe a splash of simple syrup.
author: Scott C.

description: More disappointing than the first time i learned about push up bras...im sitting here now and felt compelled to tell anyone who is a fan of good food to stay away from here. I ordered the fresh spring rolls to start. The rice paper wrapper was hard about an inch in on both ends. Onto my pho. Pho my God, awful! The broth was tasty but not even hot enough to cook the raw think sliced beef (its still pink after 5 minutes!)  Hope i dont get sick. Also i guess this place is from the north where they do not serve pho with basil,  bean sprouts, or hoi sin sauce. The most disappointing part of the pho is no tendon amywhere here :( a staple for good dac biet pho! Lastly, my thai iced tea is the worst ive ever had. Id say it had no flavor, but that would be inaccurate. Its tastes like the homeless filled streets just outside the door. Turtle tower, you are the WORST vietnamese restaurant ive EVER been to.
author: Tommy C.

description:
I honestly haven't had a better pho ga (chicken noodle soup) anywhere other then Turtle tower. However, I haven't been to Vietnam and I'm not declaring that it's the best ever; It's just the best among the ones I've tasted in my lifetime. 

The broth is so simple and clean, yet packs the right amount of flavor for the noodles. 

At this particular location I only ordered my pho ga 'to go'. With a quick scan of the place, it seems to be a lot cleaner then the original location out in the tenderloin. I did realize recently that that location has gone through a renovation.

I also ordered the pork chop over rice. This dish however is pretty typical and doesn't quite stand out as anything out of the ordinary.

Overall thoughts: Definitely worth coming to Turtle tower for their pho ga! Getting it 'to go" is a great option as they separate everything for you to combine at your own convenience.
author: Stephanie K.

description: Love this place. Very close to school and it's pretty cheap! They have lots of choices.
author: Alex S.

description: Decent pho ga, but it's not as good as the original location in the Tenderloin. It is also on the expensive side and not necessarily better than other pho options. My usual thought process is if I want chicken pho fast and I'm in SoMa, I go here to get pickup (I live a block away). If I want regular pho and have some time, I go to Miss Saigon.
author: Ray N.

description:
I saw people's postings for the Pho Ga and decided to give it a try. But I am soooooooooo disappointed!

It is super duper salty that I have to add several bowls of water but still found the soup noodle too salty to eat. I think I had drank the salt that I need for the rest of the week. Besides, the noodles were overcooked. I felt like I just bought a giant bowl of salty stock!
Couldn't stand it at all. Starving, but I had to throw it away and find something else as dinner. Very not happy with it.
author: Angel W.

description:
This is their newest location, and the pho is still reliably good.  I'm not a huge pho expert, but I've had it at a big handful of places and Turtle Tower remains the best I've ever had.  I've had it at all three locations and it's great, every time.

This location is the cleanest of the three, and is located near some food trucks as well.  Parking can get a bit frustrating, as it IS downtown, after all :).  Their bahn mi isn't the BEST I've had, so when I'm craving good bahn mi, Turtle Tower isn't my first thought.  When I want pho, it's Turtle Tower, every time, or I find something else to eat if I can't make it to one of their locations.
author: Hope O.

description: I tried turtle tower for the first time last night and it was delicious! My friend and I both got the beef pho with tripe. The meat was higher quality than the ones you normally find in pho at other places. The soup was so yummy. The noodles were interesting...not your typical pho noodles but they got addicting after a while. I definitely ate more than I intended to =P I'll definitely be back again soon!
author: Annie Z.

description:
Great FAAA Place! 
I'm joking, forgive me! I meant great Pho place in the SOMA district if your on the run. 

My usual order is #6 small with a Ice Coffee! 
Basically #6 is a bowl of pan fried flat noodles w/ a bunch of different ingredients. It consist of beef, leeks, onions, carrot with some nice stir fried action before serving in a hot bowl of broth! 

Parking may be a pain in the ass so get here before 12 to save yourself some time waiting and finding parking.
author: Eric Y.

description:
HMmmm I guess you can say I'm partial to the traditional southern style of Pho because this just wasn't for me. I came here with the bf and I ordered the Pho Ga while he ordered the beef one.

The broth of each was okay. I found it not tasting as "clean" enough and almost too salty and yet missing something. I know they do not serve hoison sauce here but I really did miss it! The noodles were delicious and so was the meat, especially the beef. However, if I was ever craving this style again, I'd rather go to Pho Hai Noi in San Jose just simply because they do serve more the condiments that I'm used to and what I love about eating a bowl of Pho. 

At least I can say one more thing crossed off the 7x7 list. Onto the next!
author: Annie M.

description:
Get the beef or chicken pho.  Their broth is really good, but I still prefer Kevin's Noodle House's broth best.  This is a close second.  I didn't order the bahn-mi, so I can't review it.  However, to avoid bahn-mi regret, drive over to Saigon Sandwich in the Tenderloin (down the street from the Turtle Tower-Tenderloin).  

Now the little things: 

Dining room is way too small for a pho house.  

Disposable wooden chopsticks are a no-no for pho.  I can't explain why.

I prefer my noodles slightly more al dente than how Turtle Tower does theirs (at all three locations).  

Tea, not water, should be served automatically on cold days, ALWAYS--no exceptions.  Hell, even on hot days.  And nix the tea charge on the menu, even if you have no intention of actually charging for tea.  

Iced coffee was good.  I never use a straw, but my wife would have appreciated one.  

Not the cheapest bowl of noodles, but it was one of the better bowls in SOMA.
author: Stephen F.

description:
This review is only for the SOMA location.


It's pretty hard for me to find a pho place that i despise but this place came reeeeeeeeeallllly close. I had the pho dac biet (combination) here and it was very mediocre. The broth wasn't very flavorful and I really dislike the type of noodles they used (larger and flatter than regular pho noodles). Add all of that to getting warm water that would never get refilled, no thanks buddy. I'll be back, but only to the one in the tenderloin.
author: William L.

description:
Came here with a friend after a hike. We had the pho tai (pho with thinly sliced rare beef), fresh spring rolls, and chargrilled pork. The beef on the pho tai was melty in the mouthy delicious - probably the tastiest beef I've had in this dish (and I've eaten this probably billions of times since infancy). 

Sadly, the pho broth wasn't very flavorful or beefy and a let down, and the noodles were more Chinese style (wider and soft) - I'm not sure if that's due to the North Vietnamese influence, but I prefer the thinner, firmer pho noodles that are what I've come to know as the standard. 

The pork and spring rolls were tasty, and the rolls included char-grilled pork along with the usual shrimp, which was an atypical but definitely welcome addition. 

Not sure if I'd visit again, but tons of available parking in SOMA and no wait time were definite pluses.
author: Selina K.

description: Let's be honest, I am having a secret affair with the Pho Ga here. I have dreams about this stuff, and like Chik-fil-A, they are closed on Sunday. Which, if you like to drink on a Saturday night, it's the saddest thing you can wake up to after a long night of drinking. Go here, enjoy the pho, have some spring rolls, begin cheating on your other Pho Ga.
author: Carey T.

description: Came here for their FREE Pho Ga (Chicken Noodle Soup) from ScoutMob. Let just say the noodles were not the vermicelli noodles I thought it would be and it also came with a limited amount of vegetables with only jalapenos. You would also have to ask for sriracha sauce probably because they do not want you to drain it for them. Well you can't beat the price of free I guess. We also ordered spring rolls and it seemed different from what I would normally get from other Vietnamese restaurants because its not deep fried with fish sauce instead it was wrapped with rice wrap with vegetables and shrimp. Another downside its that it is cash only so when we payed with a card without knowing the worker pointed towards the ATM behind us with the heavy fees. Tip for future customers! BRING CASH.
author: Peter C.

description: Extremely sub-par doesn't do it justice. The broth smells like a wet dog, not something I want in my face or stomach. The wet dog smell encompasses the entire restaurant, should have been a warning sign. Ordered a pho tai chin, the meat was fatty and dissolving into my broth, not a good sign. Definitely will not be coming back.
author: Stefan R.

description:
Northern Vietnamese casual dining in SOMA.  The prices here are a bit pricey for run of the mill Vietnamese food.  Try the original in Little Saigon instead.

They have a good selection of Vietnamese sandwiches for the local lunch crowd.  Probably worth a try next time.
author: Laurence H.

description: Service was good, and the setting was fine. Alas, my taste buds did not find the food here to be agreeable. I had the crab rolls vermicelli noodles and the pho tai. Neither dish left me impressed. Perhaps I just don't like the northern take on Viet food.
author: DV P.

description:
WTF?! I do not understand the hype about this place whatsoever. 

I ordered the pho ga, and geez louise, it was soooo plain and boring! It was literally flat rice noodles, chicken broth, and a few strands of chicken mixed together in a gigantic bowl. It was the worse I've ever had, and dare I say, a waste of calories! I could have whipped it up in my kitchen in a few, and it would have tasted a lot better. Well, there's a caveat: I'm a spoiled little girl whose daddy buys her fresh "hand-pulled" egg and rice noodles from the local Asian grocers.

For an appetizer, my tongue was also poisoned by the imperial rolls. It was just a deep-fried mess! The oil tasted old, as if the restaurant used the same wok of oil for endless days.

Do yourself a favor, and skip to another pho place. Toodles, Turtle Tower! We will never ever meet again!
author: Mabel Y.

description:
I was excited to have a Turtle Tower in the area as i love the one in the TL. Had been looking forward to a visit for almost a year. Unfortunately... 

Food was fair/good, but The original in the tenderloin is excellent. One trip here to the 6th street location and I realized there are just soo many better places to go in the soma for a meal. Top 3 issues: 1. I was very surprised to see mexican cooks in the kitchen and on that alone almost left. Nothing against mexican cooks at all but... the original and every other Pho place i've ever been to has vietnamese cooks. Curious. 2. The service was worth 2 stars and we were only 1 of 4 tables in the place. No request to refill waters, tea, nothing. No clear answers when we asked about the different dishes, and although we ordered different dishes, he brought us the same dishes. Dumbfounding. 3. Homeless guy standing out the window with his belly hanging out, staring at us throughout the meal ensured i will not be back.
author: Adam X.

description:
I was craving some pho on a cold SF day and sent my husband to go pick up some soup at Turtle Tower based off of a trusted friend's reference.

There is something about their pho broth that is so tasty and delicious. I'm the type of person who ends up dousing my noodles and meat with hoisin sauce - but there was NONE needed for this - at all. Also, I'm generally not a fan of thicker noodles, but these noodles were silky and soft as well.

They'll be seeing me again...and again...and again!
author: Bella B.

description:
Not good! I had grilled pork over rice. The pork was very dry and unappetizing. We got Imperial Rolls also. $2.15 for one roll is pretty pricey and it was pretty sad. We will not be going back here.

There are a lot better Vietnamese places within several blocks.
author: Gregory W.

description:
Turtle Tower is bringing much needed dietary diversity to the otherwise fast food neighborhood our police, judges, attorneys and jurors have to choose from as they crank the gears if our justice system at the courthouse.

Staff are very enthusiastic and friendly.  Decor bright and clean.  The place was packed indicating other food choices were also good.

As every Tampopo fan knows, the secret to noodle soup is the profundity of the broth. This stew was obviously prepared overnight. Exquisite flavor complexity, sparing on the oils, not leaning on sodium/MSG as a substitute for flavor.

Now I have a reason to want to be selected as a juror!

Fantastic pho! (Yelp won't let the funky "o" in "ph" print in their site.  But you know what I mean.)
author: Christopher A.

description: Creative entrees and a very nice, thoughtful and kind server who returned my gf's purse!  Kudos
author: Tony N.

description: Pho Ga is good, but not as good as the original location (in Tenderloin).
author: Jess C.

description:
my coworkers and i heard about the scoutmob deal for free pho ga... but ended up coming to turtle tower a week later to pay the full price instead. the place was pretty poppin, it initially appeared to be a order-and-bring-food-to-seat type of approach, but it turned out to be a sit-down restaurant.

i ordered the small sized rare beef pho, which wasn't too shabs. it was filling without being MSG overload. the beef was cooked nicely, medium on the outside and rare on the inside. the wider rice noodles were a pleasant surprise. instead of the usual sriracha/hoisin/plate of bean sprouts and mint leaves and jalapenos, we received fish sauce/hot sauce/small sauce dish of lemons and jalapenos.

the service is good, but a little slow. however, it wasn't as slow as the vietnamese coffee drip speed! one of my coworkers ordered a vietnamese coffee, which was initially forgotten but brought later. it was one of those coffees that are brought to your table to drip into a cup. which was pretty interesting to look at ... for the first ten minutes! it took the entire duration of our meal for the coffee to reach the halfway point of readiness. my coworker ended up squeezing the rest into the cup and asking for a plastic cup to bring it back to our office.

overall good price, good food, slightly slow service, SUPER SLOW VIETNAMESE COFFEES.
author: Caitlin C.

description:
3.5 Stars

I stopped by Turtle Tower's newest location in SOMA for a late lunch. I immediately noticed how much smaller this restaurant was compared to their Geary counterpart. Coming in at 2PM on a Friday I still had to wait roughly 15 minutes for a table and I was definitely surprised!

Once I got seated I continued to play the FUN waiting game since their was only one server handling the cash register and all the tables. I guess it can't hurt for the server to smile now and again. He definitely seemed exhausted.

Once I finally put in my order for a #9) Pho Gà - Chicken Noodle Soup, I patiently waited another 15 minutes before the bowl of delicious came my way. A couple other things to note:

1) The broth is amazingly tasty and light. You might get addicted to it too. I pretty much drank all the soup from the bowl.

2) Turtle Tower is Northern Vietnamese styled so your bowl of noodles won't be accompanied with a lot of extra condiments like bean sprouts and basil. Your order will come with sliced jalapenos and lemon though.

3) The noodles are flat and wider then your typical Southern Vietnamese styled Pho.

4) Remember to bring CASH, unless you want to use their ATM.

There was nothing wrong with the food and it was solid 4 stars. I was disappointed in the wait time and the service offered at this location so I slightly lowered my rating.
author: Jason H.

description: Not been impressed so far with the pho or chicken on rice dishes. Coming from eating at countless pho places all around southern cali, I've been shocked at what passes as cheap and good up here in SF.
author: Rharrison79 ..

description: Dear owners of Turtle tower, it's okay that sometimes accidents happen, people find hair in their soup. But what's NOT okay is that after you were told that there's hair in the soup, your waitress don't apologize and shows no regret as if it's normal to find hair and we are the crazy one for requesting for a new bowl. Start some customer service training or acting training, at least pretend that you care. Your soup is good and people love it. But if you continue to treat people this way, you won't be in business for long. Always remember, customers first. Sincerely, your supporting yet very disappointed customer.
author: Mindy C.

description:
I had the rare steak pho. It was different from any other pho I've had and I have to say I liked it. 

First off, the broth was fattier than your average pho broth. 

Second, the noodles were wider. I liked this better than the skinny noodles because they still had some pull to them. The skinny noodles often soak up too much of the broth and become mush - so I liked their wide noodle choice better. 

Thirdly, rare steak pho often comes with a thin slice of meat that is very dry and flavorless. Here they served it in a patty like form and it was much more flavorful and tender. 

There is a bus stop right outside the restaurant so it's pretty easy to get to from the financial district. 

I wouldn't say it's cheap but only because we're talking about pho - any other food and I would think that such quantities were a bargain.  But for pho... even the large size wasn't that big and it was 8 dollars.
