They only take cash but they have an atm in the restaurant.
author: Gee H.

description: I'm not sure why this location has significantly worse reviews than the other ones... I got the Pho Ga, and thought it tasted like it did at the Larkin location.  In fact this location should be better!  It's in a safer area, there is more parking, and the inside appears cleaner.  Only reason why I deducted a star was since the spring roll was ehhhh....
author: Tiffany C.

description: The dish that everyone raves about, the pho ga (chicken noodle soup), is really just so so.  Besides, which chicken noodle soup comes with NO veggies?
author: Kristen S.

description:
Haven't had any northern-style Vietnamese food since my trip to Vietnam a while back, so figured I'd give it another whirl...

Ordered the pho with brisket and flank and after one taste I realized that I really am a Southern (Vietnamese) boy. After hundreds of pho bowls at home and at the many pho joints around the Bay Area, the Northern style broth just isn't for my palate. It just lacks a certain "oomph" which isn't to say it's bad just different. 

Wifey ordered the Bún Ch Hà Ni which was very good and make me regret ordering the pho. Both pork preparations were well done and uber flavorful nicely balancing the salty vs. sweet quotient. 

Will likely come back to try some of the other dishes, just not the pho.
author: David H.

description: We ordered pho from Turtle Tower via Caviar. It was awful. Watery, clear broth, weird texture to the rare beef, too oily and no flavor. Gross.
author: laura r.

description:
Terrible Pho:

-No bean sprouts, or basil. 
-Chicken was attached to skin, or fat.

Beef Stew:

-Bland
-Mostly skin and fat.

I will never go here again.
author: Lejf H.

description:
If there was a no star that is what they would get. IDK but maybe its like Osha the more they have and further away from the Original the worse and more of a rip off it is. Do not go to this location. To be honest I have never been to any other location so maybe they are all chintzy on their servings and flavors. I have been here three times tried three different items and all were bad verging on inedible. 
Bunh Mi uh gross can you put a pepper in at least to mask the flavor?
Stir Fry beef with tomato umm as the saying goes "where's the beef?" Oh and the alleged soup that comes with the stir fry umm is that dirty socks?
I hope they care and read these Yelp reviews becuase I heard search great things about Turtle Tower.
The Quiznos that used to be here was a better meal.

DO NOT EAT HERE UNLESS YOU ENJOY BEING RIPPED OFF AND BAD FLOVERLESS FOOD.
author: Matthew B.

description: Same Turtle Tower quality as the original location but with easier parking and no waft of excrement when you get out of your car.
author: V N.

description:
I came here A LOT when I worked at 850 Bryant. At the time, it was brand new and the "it" place for lunch. The pho ga is definitely really good and healthy tasting. Their Vietnamese sandwiches are average - its nice that they allow you to combine different types of meat [or even an egg] if you wanted to. Their regular pho is OK, nothing really stands out. 

The service here is pretty slow and they always seem to run out of something. I've been to Turtle Tower in the TL too. Food is about the same but the restaurant itself feels kinda dirty.

I would come by if it was convenient & I was in the mood for pho, but there are definitely better Vietnamese restaurants around.
author: I. L.

description:
Came here to try their pho ga for free, thanks to Scoutmob!  As expected, business was crackin during lunch service on a Thursday.  
I rarely go for pho ga because my mom makes it just the way I like.  However, seeing as it's FREE, why not.  
I have to say that I was pretty impressed with what I got.  Flavors were good and overall, i didn't feel unhealthy after; I liked that there isn't an oily film over the broth.  I would return to try other stuff.
author: Christopher L.

description:
I have had a lot of Pho in San Francisco and this is by far THEE best. 

Cannot STAND when Pho broth or noodles are bland - Turtle Tower is full of flavor and a great size portion! The place is so clean too! Don't go somewhere else, PHO HERE!
author: Jaclynn F.

description:
I have very healthy, active sweat glands.  They are easily activated.  Especially when I wear long sleeved shirts, eating hot soup with spicy red spicy spice can be a near-death-by-dehydration experience.  Simply put, it's really embarrassing to watch me put away a bowl of hot anything.  Everything is fine until I start sweating, without warning or a build up, SUDDENLY sweat is pouring down my brow.  And my neck.  And my upper lips.  It looks like I'm having a hot flash, sudden death, and food sweats all at the same time.  Really quite frightening.

This brings us to the reason why I have never eaten a meal at Turtle Tower.  I usually order my chicken rice soup to go, then find a drafty, solitary location.  Maybe I eat fast.  Though not as fast as my BF.  And apparently Jessica T. is a hoover when it comes to food.  

The Chicken rice soup (it might go by another name but right now, I'm too lazy and unmotivated to lift a finger to research what the proper menu name might be) is made with chicken broth, rice cooked until it is quite loose but not yet paste, cilantro, chicken parts and water.  The cilantro makes it better.  All you people who cannot taste the true enlightening flavor of cilantro should feel sad that you will never know the grace of god in the form of cilantro.  Has anyone realized that the issue of cilantro has divided the world as much as the religion?  I think I just found a conspiracy!

As with most viet restaurants, MSG is a common seasoning in the kitchen.  When I eat MSG, it feels like someone put ruffies in my food.  One minute I'm chatting and doing fine, the next minute I've passed out, face first on the desk/floor/bathroom stall.  I won't remember anything when I wake up.  It's like those few hours of my life were stolen from me.  Now, what girl wouldn't like a decent black-out every now and again.  However, it's really frowned upon when that happens at work.  And everyone is staring at me.  Yeah.  I tend to drool a lot when I'm in these MSG-induced comas.
author: Christina C.

description:
This may be one of my deep dark secrets, but I've never been a huge fan of pho. 

Until now. The pho ga at Turtle Tower literally rocked my world. So flavorful and delicious! The location isn't the best, but this pho ga is worth skirting the tenderloin for :P
author: Eliza D.

description:
TT! The one in the tenderloin is suppose to be really good! So when we happened to park right in front of this one on saturday, we decided to eat here after a rehearsal.

place seemed clean, and they were nice. but man is it pricey for pho....to me anyways.

I just got the small pho ga, and it was $7. it was okay. nothing special

my friend got the banh cuon, and that was $8-$9. super small....rice roll...ground beef...and few pieces of cha lua. fish sauce wasn't that great.

will not be back.
author: Christine M.

description: I thought it would be better.  I had the chicken noodles.  There was not much flavor, curiously.  Chicken noodle soup of any kind out of a can has way more flavor.  The only real flavor was in the broth, which tasted vaguely fishy -- it was not in the least bit appetizing.  Service was non-existent -- I had to keep flagging someone down to refill the thimble-sized water glass.  It's a very short walk from home, which is appealing, but there wasn't a single thing about the experience that would compel me to return.
author: Thomas M.

description:
They finally open until 9pm and they are located within my vicinity.  Turtle Tower is not only the best hangover food but a remedy for being sick or a hot spot to bring your friends that are in town.

You have to forewarn people that it isn't the traditional southern style pho that they are used to.  If I haven't eaten anything all day before coming here, I can probably finish a large bowl myself.

This location offers a few things that the other Turtle Towers don't offer that you should check out:

1. Fried Chicken
2. Banh Mi with fried egg

This location is also cleaner and the staff is a lot nicer unlike the other location.
author: Carli F.

description: Dont go. I dont want to share one side story, so wont say anything specific. Just look at the pic that I shared and check Health Score. Lets not support this type of not-clean/dishonest business.
author: Michael C.

description:
I came to this location based on convenience on a rainy evening and it worked out great. I ordered a large Pho Tái and it hit the spot. Prices were reasonable.

The meat was tender, the broth was amazing, unlike any that I've had in this city. Noodles were soft and thick (they way I like them). They had fresh coconut juice in a glass with the meat which was also refreshing to have along with my meal. 

Would definitely check out their other locations for comparison!
author: Rachel W.

description:
I like this place the chicken Pho was really good and clean, nothing more nothing less. 

I had the sauteed beef soup and it tasted like beef chow fun soup and I dont know if you like chow fun, see i love chow fun. The soup was really good, it didnt taste too oily or make me feel bloated after. I genuinely like this place, the food all taste very fresh and clean, unlike most other Pho places. Overall great place, parking in this area though, sucks.
author: Luigi B.

description: Lame, tasteless, "northern style" soup. I cant even call it pho, it just... isnt. Cash only which means I always pay an ATM fee, WHO CARRIES CASH ANYMORE? One star because the service is fast. Willy only eat here out of desperation...
author: Vee N.

description: I am a big fan of the original Larkin location.  My friends had already told me this one wasn't as good so I was probably biased.  So consider this an interim review until I can reconfirm with a 2nd visit.  I ordered the rare beef pho and did not like the meat at all.   Noodles were good, as were the imperial rolls.  This is a much more convenient location so I'm hoping next time it's better.  I'll have to order the pho ga, which my boyfriend liked.
author: Vivian W.

description:
The only reason I came here is because it's the only Vietnamese place within walking distance.  For the quality and quantity of the Pho and Banh Mi, I feel it's subpar and overpriced.  

Growing up in Little Saigon has impaired my taste buds for city living :-(  

$7+ for one banh mi with little flavor and ok ingredients is a shame.  I'll wait for my buy two get one free specials in SoCal next time.
author: Alex T.

description:
I'll admit it, after my first visit to the original Turtle Tower, I was not impressed. I went in expecting southern style pho and was devastated by the absence of bean sprouts, extra difficulty in picking up the thicker noodles, and...umami that accompanied all my previous pho experiences. However, after understanding that Turtle Tower serves northern style pho and learning the differences between the regional varieties I went back, tried chicken instead of beef, and became a huge fan. 

Eventually my frequent cravings for pho ga started creeping into dinnertime, so I decided to give this outpost a try.  From one unsavory part of the city to another, the pho ga seems pretty consistent to me - piping hot with a nice, clean broth that leaves me feeling fully comforted. The service has always been friendly and I like how I've never had to wait for a table when my weekday dinner or weekend lunch cravings strike. I've even branched out and tried the stir fried beef noodle soup (basically chow fun soup), the stir fried beef over vermicelli noodles, and the grilled pork vermicelli dish, finding all to be pretty delicious (though salty) when the mood strikes.
author: Krystle S.

description: My favorite pho to date. Their Pho Ga (Chicken Pho) has a tasty broth that tastes clean and free of any unwanted msg. This isn't a bowl of pho i would need to add anything too. A little chili sauce and jalapenos for some heat does just the trick. I normally add heavy amounts of sirarcha and oyster sauce but Turtle Tower doesn't need either! Just FYI, It's a little pricier than most pho restaurants. I'd rather pay a couple extra bucks for better quality noodle soup though.
author: Samantha L.

description:
If you ask me, this stuff is overpriced.  The pho here isn't even made with pho noodles.  Only coming here for my favorite work lunch combo ... the Vietnamese coffee and the fresh shrimp spring rolls.  I'm not hungry for anything else here and really won't be paying for it either.

Not sure why people are saying this place is cleaner.  The place is poorly ventilated AND it has flies buzzing around all the time.  Kind of gross.
author: Kimberly C.

description: I come here often on my lunch hour.  I had always heard great things about the chicken broth.  I can't say that I've ever been disappointed. The servers here try hard to tend to everyone and shuffle poeple in and out so that there's not a huge wait.  My suggestion arrive before 11:30am or after 1:30pm in order to avoid a long wait and write your name down!
author: Monique T.

description:
Came here after a night at City Beer because ScoutMob had a free Pho Ga (Chicken Pho). Worse decision ever. My apologies to everyone for dragging them out there.

It's north Vietnamese, so I'm not going to complain about how "different" the dishes were. The sticky rice and sausage looked decent and the egg roll was at least pretty, but the soup noodles were easily the worse I've ever had. The chicken tasted like something awful and I literally picked out all the little pieces from my bowl. The broth tasted like msg (not in a good way) and I was so thirsty afterwards that I actually started to feel sick. The beef pho wasn't much better.

Skip this joint. Your taste buds will thank you.
author: Sue Y.

description: I stopped coming here after I ordered take out and this weird brown thing was hanging on my chicken. When I looked closer, it was a feather. First I was like... okay whatever. I mean... I'm sure I've eaten more nastier things without knowing it... especially when you eat in Chinatown. But at least they try to hide it better!!! Then I found a few more pieces with feathers still stuck to the chicken. By then, I lost my appetite and just stopped eating. THE END.
author: Johnson S.

description:
This new location just isn't as good as the one in the TL. Service is much slower and the pho isn't as good. The place is a lot smaller too so you'll probably need to wait a bit longer for a table.

One would think that the food should taste identical to the other locations...but they either are not sharing their recipes or are just using different cooking methods.

I'll skip this place for now and head to the TL instead.
author: Lester W.

description:
I've was super excited when I heard TT was opening in the SOMA.  I am a big fan of Pho Ga and I love how they are accommodating. (dark meat only and no greens)  Most places would say: "SORRY" we cannot do that for u. haha

Walking distance from my office is a plus, however the only negative is they are not open on Sun.  Why TT Why?  

Convenient, clean, and YUMMY!

Thank you for coming to SOMA~
author: Sandy L.

description:
I was on my lunch break and initially was headed over to Grab 'n' Go on 480 6th St.  However, I decided to give this place a try rather than saunter by.  They'd only been here three months, but it's rare Vietnamese places ever disappoint.  

Beginning with the positive, the place is very clean and comfortable for a  tiny corner cafe.  They also use Brita filtered water, and they are friendly.   Maybe there are other good things about this place like better service or food.  I doubt I will try again though when my regular "hole-in-the-wall" lunch spot is up the street serving cheaper, tastier, food in larger portions and in a timely fashion.

I ordered a Vietnamese iced coffee as soon as the menus were handed to us.  I didn't get my java treat filtering on the table until fifteen minutes later after I had reminded them once before.  Shortly after, my order of stir-fried beef with celery, carrot, onion, leek, & tomato and steamed rice arrived.  Unfortunately, my ravenous appetite was not satiated when I noticed scarce quantities of small overcooked morsels of beef burrowed among the fresh veggies.  All this for $7.20!   I was on a time schedule, so I scarfed it down anyways.  During the entire time, tiny droplets of iced coffee were dripping into the glass.  It was like watching a leaky faucet.   I moved the filter around to get it to move, and an older bald man who appeared to have some authority in the restaurant told me to stop messing with it because it will move slower.  He was nice about it and offered to bring ready made coffee if it didn't finish filtering in a few minutes.  Against my internal wishes, my friend decided to order one too and now both of us were waiting for our iced coffees to finish filtering drop by drop.  Conversation ceased as our attentions were directed toward staring intently at our iced coffees filtering out of these antiquated filtering devices.  Another guy comes back to check the drip and tells us it will be finished in five minutes.  It's a good thing he didn't wager us!  They had to give us both remnant filtered coffee with what fresh coffee of ours did filter in to-go cups.  This is approximately thirty minutes later if not more after finishing lunch.  

I guess I can look on the bright side:  At least, I got to enjoy my iced coffee in class during the lecture!
author: Elizabeth S.

description: completely overrated. there's nothing special about turtle tower pho.
author: Judy L.

description:
Be warned that this is NOT the usual Southern style pho that most people are familiar with.  I don't know all the differences but this place has clearer broth, wider noodles, and no hoisin sauce.

If you bring a Turtle Tower virgin here, you have to clearly state the above and verify that they are ok with trying something new, even if they claim to like pho.  Especially the hoisin part, because that really upsets people.  I've taken visiting friends and they absolutely hate it and don't eat their food and/or give me crap to no end for being a Yelper who recommended such a disappointing pho place.

I personally am not a huge Turtle Tower fan myself, but I don't think it's any better or worse than other pho places.  I still prefer Southern variations, but I like TT's pho ga when I'm feeling ill.
author: S L.

description:
I think people either love or hate the pho here. I love it here, because it is one of those few places that you can find northern style pho, which the broth is lighter, and they don't make it too salty. Those who b1tch about the sprouts need to get over it.

They use the wider rice noodle here, a large is probably more like medium in other place. My favorite is large #4, I can eat that day after day.

Othere dishes are also pretty good, their chicken dishes is okay....

Quick service, clean setting, it is your typical neighborhood stop.

Cash only now.
author: Alice C.

description:
turtle tower been going down hill lately. all their stores need to hire new workers. they are so damn rude. the customer service is crap.

crap service!crap service!crap service!crap service!crap service!crap service!crap service!crap service!crap service!crap service!crap service!crap service!crap service!crap service!crap service!crap service!crap service!crap service!crap service!crap service!crap service!crap service!crap service!crap service!crap service!crap service!crap service!crap service!crap service!crap service!crap service!crap service!crap service!crap service!

do not go here or any turtle tower restaurant.
author: Taye N.

description:
Went here for the first time a month ago and just came back again today.  I have never been to the other Turtle Towers in the area, but avoid this one at all costs!

On my first experience for lunch, we ordered pho and vermicelli bowl.  The pho came out pretty quick, but the noodles were pretty soggy and the soup was aaaaaight.  Time goes on and the vermicelli never came out.  We ask about our order and they said it would be coming up soon, they forgot about it.  To make up for our wait, they gave us an order of spring rolls on the house.  The only problem with a complimentary dish is that it should taste good.  The rice paper on the spring rolls were hard.  You cant give a free appetizer when forgetting about an order and have the comp appetizer be horrible!

I don't know why we came back second time, but this time it was for dinner.  This place is very strange.  Their dinner menu does not have pho or vermicelli or any typical vietnamese dish that most people are used to at a vietnamese restaurant.  They only have pho for take out.  All the other dishes are ~$20!  What are they thinking!?  This is one of the worst vietnamese restaurants I've been to in the city.

Avoid it for dinner.  If you want good pho in the city go to Tin on Howard and 5th.
author: Baek C.

description:
Came here for a quick bite on a Wednesday night, it was not crowded and my friend and I were seated immediately. The place is pretty cute, with booth seating as well as window seating, and it's nice and clean. I got the braised beef with lemongrass noodle, my friend got the imperial rolls with noodle.

I have to say that upon first bite, I was not really impressed. There wasn't enough "lemongrass"-ness and it was a bit bland. I got bits and pieces of lemongrass, along with some cilantro. But the dish grew on me as the sauce (they provide it on the side) soaked in after a while and by the end I was thoroughly enjoying it. The noodles were the vermicelli type and was "al dente" if that's possible with these types of noodles. I know I've had it worse at other places. There was also a good amount of beef, just wish the flavor was a bit stronger. Not bad for $7. My friend did not like his imperial rolls at all.

Overall 3 stars for the mixed experience, but I would come back again and give it another try :)
author: Linda L.

description:
The Chinese style soups (with egg noodles) are decent, with the broth having good flavor but seeming a bit heavy and oily.

The banh mi are where it's at. They're not traditional per se, but a slight variant. They taste heavier, more substantial, more integrated than a standard Vietnamese sandwich. The whole thing melds together into delicious, warm goodness. And they're really cheap.

They get crowded during lunch so show up early or order to go.
author: Alexander J.

description:
It's a bold statement, but I will claim that no one loves pho ga more than I do. My personal rule with Turtle Tower is: if you take a friend to lunch here, do not tell them that you are going to have pho (especially if he/she/they is/are Vietnamese). Otherwise, you will get a look like you are growing horns out your head. Meanwhile, your friend will continue to sit there waiting for what he/she knows as the "real" pho. The more neutral name for this bowl of deliciousness is noodle soup. Huge regional (and political) differences apparently.

Furthermore, there are two major differences between this location and the one in TL: the absence of pigeon poop stench (during the travel from your car to the restaurant) and the shrunken menu. But let's face it, the only thing you need to order is pho ga anyway.
author: Lily T.

description:
Meh.

This review is for dinner. 

I was looking forward to trying out TT's pho and noodles, but found out that they do not serve any kind of noodles or "lunch menu" items after 6:00 pm. They only have pho for take out. 

The dinner menu is small and only had variations of duck and crab dishes. The dishes are all priced close to $20.  There are various appetizers, but they are not super interesting and overpriced.  I wasn't impressed with the menu and my friend and I just ordered a papaya salad and beef dish.

Service was slow.  The restaurant wasn't particularly busy but the salad and beef took a good 20 minutes. The waitress seemed annoyed that we didn't order that much. She was a bit patronizing.
 
Neither dish was very good - papaya salad was $10 and only had papaya and some shredded carrot and dried squid. The beef was too corn-starchy and overall was not well done and $13.

I won't come back here for dinner.  There are a lot of other Vietnamese restaurants to go to.
author: Cindy Y.

description: Free pho ga!!!! I came here cause of scout mob's free deal. I think this place serves northern vietnamese food? The pho ga isn't the typical vermicelli noodles I usually get. It's wide flat rice noodles served with a clear chicken broth and pieces of chicken  with a side of jalapeños for your pleasure. The style of cooking felt more like chinese food. But like I said, it's probably northern vietnamese cooking. Overally, it was nice alternative to the usual chicken noodle soup I eat. The small was surprisingly filling.
author: Virginia Y.

description:
Hmm...been a long time fan of the OG TT in TL. Decided to come here because it was: 

1. closer to me 
2. cleaner 
3. Not in the TL (no offense TL, but even though you have some grubbin' places, I hate how it smells around there)

The first time first time I came to this location, it was amazing, I was so stoked that I didn't have to brave the TL anymore. But the second time, my food and service was definitely sub-par. The grilled pork in my Vermicelli dish came out cold and really hard, it was so tough, you would think I ordered jerky or something. My friend ordered the soup and it was really bland and had no flavor, the TL location is much better. Hopefully, they are just working out their kinks in this location, I will definitely come back for another try though. 

3.5 stars (partially biased just because I love the OG TT and staff)
author: Kristina L.

description:
So so pho.

Noodles were substantial and soaked up the broth nicely.

Chicken was plentiful although quite a few pieces still had a very unappetizing strip of fat.

Broth seemed clear and healthy at first but the glaze of oil along the container was disappointing.

Small and efficient space. Friendly service.

Neither of the last two make up for underwhelming pho. Sorry Turtle Tower.
author: Jason B.

description:
This is, THE BEST pho I have ever had (and that says a lot because I eat a lot of Pho)! I had the #1 (Well done beef and brisket) pho. They use chow-fun type of noodles, instead of the usual vermicelli noodles that is used in most pho; they are so much easier to eat than the usual super long noodles that make a mess sometimes. I also had the imperial rolls that you wrap in lettuce and mint leaves + dipping sauce~ delicious! They say there is nothing like their noodles anywhere else in SF. 
The ambience isn't the greatest, but it's still worth going to! Can't wait to visit SF again to try it out :)
author: Kristina J.

description:
After having Turtle Tower in the TL a year ago, I swore to myself I would never come back. Never having been a huge fan of Northern Vietnamese cuisine, I just didn't like the idea of eating pho without any condiments or any of the usual accouterments.

But like a moth gravitating towards a flame, Scoutmob's promise for a free bowl of pho ga shamefully pulled me back. But you know what, this time it was worth it.

Though my position on Northern Vietnamese-style pho hasn't really changed, this Turtle Tower's pho ga was definitely legit. The broth was flavorful, the chicken tender, and the noodles clean. I thoroughly enjoyed my bowl and wished the deal was for a bigger bowl after I was done with it.

The location itself isn't ideal. It's still in the TL and the streets can really smell depending on the time of day. The space is small inside and when it's crowded, the hostesses will ask if you mind sharing a table with others. 

Overall, if Norther Vietnamese cuisine is your thing, definitely stop by for a bowl. It's a better alternative than many other pho joints in the city.
author: Tom P.

description:
i use to go to the one in TL a lot! until i found a cockroach in my noodle soup, then i vowed never to go back again

now that i work next door to the soma location, i thought i'd give it a try,,,similar to the TL location minus the roach

this pace seems like they charge a bit more than the original location, but this one takes credit card
author: Long C.

description: This is Northern Vietnamese food so it has a little different flavor. The broth is reaaaalllly nice and it is cheap! Every time I have been the service is fast and good. I'll keep going as long as that doesn't change.
author: Moline D.

description:
I've been to this particular one twice. Both times I order the Pho ga, (flat rice noodle with chicken broth and chicken). I think their soup is inconsistent. The first time I had it the soup tasted great, can't remember anything wrong with it. But the second time, the soup was definitely a bit more saltier. The soup was good, but just a bit too salty for me. 

Service was good, they were able to seat me right away on a late sat afternoon. Took my order promptly. The food usually comes out pretty quick here. Vietnamese Ice coffee was okay, it didn't drain that well and I couldn't drink it until after I was done with my noodle so I had to get it in a to go cup, even then there was still half the coffee trying to drip through.

I've tried the one on Geary, twice also, and I think that one might be a bit better, because I remember the first time I had the Pho ga there it was freaking AWESOME!

Ambiance/atmosphere: Both places were kind of your typical Vietnamese noodle place...although it felt like this place had a younger crowd.
author: Amy L.

description:
This place is similar to the location in the tenderloin. Here are the pluses for this place:

- cleaner
- water from brita filter

Downside:
- less food for more money
- they close at 5
author: Eva Y.

description: The young woman that supervises the facility is very rude. She wants to argue with customers and treats the employees rudely.
author: Emily A.

description: Had chicken pho last night from there. It gave me the stomach flu. Up all night and morning, feeling the full symptoms. Called into work sick. Will never ever go back there again.  If u want the stomach flu, eat there. Terrible place.
author: Jonathan B.

description:
The mrs, me, and another couple went here for our dinner and movie double date because we were all craving pho and Vietnamese sandwiches but when we got there, those items weren't available if you're dining in and are only available for take-out.  Last time I checked, movie theaters aren't too thrilled of patrons bringing in outside food.  

Instead, you have to pay for overpriced and mediocre tasting Vietnamese fusion type food.  Needless to say, we won't be going back there.  The only highlight was we thought that the movie was funny.
author: S S.

description: My parents and I like coming here when we want to order chicken pho. They don't give a lot of chicken, but the soup tastes great. The only thing is they don't give you any bean sprouts and mint leaves. There is no veggies with this pho ga. They are doing well since there are three different locations in SF. I will be coming back. Their pho ga is listed as 1 of the top 100 food you should eat in a SF magazine.
author: Jennifer T.

description:
For me, not the best Pho in the city.
Raw beef was ok but not the freshest. I liked the soup though.
They don't give you the add-ons like bean sprout and most importantly NO BASIL. Also they give you lemon instead of lime.
I would probably go back sometime, not for the food but for the convenience since they are in walking distance from my apartment.
author: Hide S.

description:
Wheres the beef?

Rice plates have very little meat compared to other vietnamese places. 

For their pho, the broth doesn't seem to taste like the one at the tenderloin, it's not as thick / meaty / salty. 

And it's pricier than most vietnamese places.

At least it's clean, well lit and friendly. I think this turtle tower and the one in richmond are similar, but nowhere near the goodness of the tenderloin one.

The question is then, if your in the area, should you come here, a pricy place thats soso, or go to grab-n-go, kiddie corner from this place and get cheaper soso vietnamese food. At least you get more meat with grab-n-go and it's cheaper.
author: ToAsTy T.

description:
My new fav pho place in town.

The broth is lovely with delicate ginger.

Both the pho ga and the beef with tendon, flank, and steak are wonderfully delicious.

But it's only this location that is good.  I tried the Larkin location a few times and it's no where near as nice.  In fact, as yummy as this place is the Larkin location is dull and boring.
author: Lev E.

description: The only good thing on the menu was the chicken pho. The spring rolls and imperial rolls were no bueno.
author: StylesUlove F.

description:
I came here on the very last morning of the Scoutmob deal. There were only two tables occupied because it was 30 minutes into opening. Parking was horrendous. I think it took us 20-30 minutes to find parking. When we finally decided to use coins (after I found some coins in my purse) we found free parking right in front of the store. The waitress spoke very fluent English and was very nice. 

The Pho Ga was a bit strange. In the beginning, it was good. The soup is light and pretty delicious. One third into my bowl, the tastiness started to disappear. I've eaten Pho Ga all my life and I never remember experiencing this phenomenon before. I think the noodles weren't soft enough so when the base cooled down, it tasted weird.

Bottom Line: I wouldn't pay regular price for this Pho Ga. It's pretty expensive regularly (I'll give this a 2 out of 5). Since I got it for free, I'll add one star.
author: Theresa N.

description: 2nd time here, not happy with the Pho' or anything we had. Kinda bland, kinda like lets push the price of things to see if we can make more profit. (like the tiny sized appetizers they have as "specials".... which were not special) We were not happy. Life is too short to come back to this joint.
author: Matsuo U.

description:
For a vietnamese girl, I am sad to say that I really don't like pho. I'll probably eat it once in the duration of an entire year.

On a good note, I came here for lunch the other day because the weather's been chilly and I've been having an odd craving for noodle soups. Knowing that turtle tower offers northern style fresh noodles (banh pho tuoi), I opted to try pho here than the competitor down the street.

Coming from an anti-pho person, I think their pho ga was pretty good. The noodles were nice and soft, and the broth wasn't bland nor salty. One thing I have to point out though is you can see that their broth is very oily. You can see the layer of oil sitting atop the soup. Other than that...it was pretty tasty.

I made a little salt, pepper, vinegar and lemon mixture to dip my chicken in and it was nice and zesty. The flavors together were great. I also had a thai tea which was just ok, a little bit sweet, but I don't mind it. Now I know if I'm craving pho, I can come here for the noodles I prefer.
author: Stine H.

description:
I love pho. 
This was one of the biggest disappointments: totally bland. Practically a tasteless broth. And noodles that were very very overcooked and soft.
author: DJ C.

description:
I'll return soon enough to give it another try but for all the raves about it having great Vietnamese food I didn't find it that great.

Had the pho ga and bbq pork noodle dish and thought it was tasty and filling but we'd had better of each dish before. The service was fast and food came to our table quick and pipping hot.

It's definitely better than most of the mediocre restaurants in the area but that's not enough to impress many. Maybe it was just an off day
author: Sam H.

description: Great chicken noodle Pho, and the meat is organic, so you can rest easy eating it.  This place is no frills, just good food.  The pho is Northern style, which has a lighter broth and is perfect on rainy days or when you're feeling ill.  My girlfriends and I go here often after work and enjoy a nice hot bowl of goodness.  Highly recommend.
author: Ashley K.

description:
Pho Ga is super tasty and I didn't get my "MSG" cough after I ate the bowl.  It's a bit pricey $6.50? for a small bowl. 

Street parking is a plus.

Bus stop rights in front of the restaurant.

Crispy Imperial roll was dinky but tasted good at $2.15/one. 

This location is a bit out of the way for me but since I was in town, I decided to give it a try.
author: Jboogie L.

description:
Since Turtle Tower in the Tenderloin closes fairly early, and the Richmond dist location is far from convenient, opening this one here to replace the once failed chain Quiznos has proved this chain Vietnamese restaurant made the right choice. They have longer business hours which cater to the late dinner crowds and also gives the SFPD a healthier option to McDonalds or Subway. 

We had to try this place out also because of their extended dinner menu offered here aside from the usual chicken noodle soups and beef stew noodle soups at the other locations. 

We ordered their chicken noodles soup (of course), with a side of 2 imperial rolls (dinner menu ones have crab and pork in them) and one order of their rice rolls with diced mushrooms and marinated pork. 

Chicken noodle soup : excellent soup base, tender pieces of shredded dark and white chicken meat.

Imperial rolls : not my favorite. It had a onion infused taste to it and I do not like onions at all. Imperial rolls at PPQ on Irving still gets my #1 vote.

Rice rolls with pork/mushrooms: very fresh (waitress made sure we knew they made a fresh batch of these rolls around noon.) The rice noodles were soft and not too chewy. The marinated pork and mushrooms inside were very tasty and I couldn't stop munching on the left over scraps that were on the plate. This is a dish I would recommend trying out if you want a different type of appetizer to go with your entree besides imperial rolls or spring rolls.

They also had whole roasted crab on their dinner menu, which I plan on trying out next time! 

Service here is where I had to knock off one whole star! Maybe because it's still new, they don't have a full staff for waiters/waitresses, but that night, they only had one server/waitress/hostess. She practically had to multitask all night. I felt a little bad for her. Given she was the only one, service was pretty slow and my water wasn't filled once. It's ok....I can't let the service here stop me from coming again. Overall, I enjoyed my meal and hopefully they hire more help so my next experience here would be completely awesome!
author: Christina T.

description:
Turtle Tower has authentic Northern Vietnam soups and dishes that seem to rival home made.  I've found that they seem to take extra time in preparation for the soup and side dishes, avoiding cutting any corners.  They focus on a particular regional style and do it well.  Northern Pho rarely if ever has lots of bean sprouts and basil for you on the side.  The pho comes with hot peppers and some sauces.  There are normal herbs and vegetables are in their fresh spring rolls (that seem to have grilled meat, not fried). 

The soup noodles #4 came out with flat rice noodles, rather than round.  It was delicious.  I've also had one soup with beef stew and one called "bun thang" with round noodles.  These were tasty.

I've also found that it is better to go early as sometimes it can get crowded.  It's worth coming back.
author: George G.

description:
i don't get it - why is this place always packed? i mean, that's great for the owners as they seem to have been the only ones to have luck at this location in the last 7+ years.  but this place seriously served me almost the worst pho i've ever had. i think the only worse bowl i've experienced was in florida... that had a lettuce floating in it... yeah.

the beef (flank) wasn't cut properly and looked like someone chewed it up and spit it back out. it also took forever to come out. maybe because someone was still chewing someone else's bowl.
author: Judy C.

description: Had jury duty & this place is very convenient at the corner of 6th & Bryant.  So glad I got there before the lunch crowd with a line out the door.  Tried the chicken noodle soup, with egg noodles.  It was very flavorful & loaded with chicken, veggies & noodles.  Loved the fresh jalapeno to put on the soup.  All in all, a very good deal & staff was friendly.  Cash only!
author: Donna W.

description:
I've been frequenting this place a whole lot more since I work no more than 3 blocks away.

Their Pho Ga is getting better and order a side of Ga Luoc, their poached chicken on the side. You'll enjoy the greater parts of the chicken, and it comes with a side dish of lime/salt/pepper.

Still, don't order their beef Pho, not much more than broth and noodles. 

I'll continue to return here on my lunch breaks and hopefully try something new, and when I do, expect another update!
author: Christopher L.

description:
beef pho - it was a toss up between the beef and the chicken, but i'm always more partial to beef pho. I got a 'small' bowl which is essentially more than enough for a person. It came steaming hot with broth, a good healthy portion of meat and noodles. You really get the pungent taste of the beef broth and the meat is pretty tender and ready to melt into your mouth. 

I do have to warn you though, the pho is a bit more like the northern hanoi style so you won't get hoisin sauce or the bean sprouts. I know everyone complains about this, but give this type of pho a chance!  The only things they give you to add into your pho are jalopenos, lemon and fish sauce. 

Some other highlights are the 'che' aka vietnamese dessert - my favorite is the 3 colors one " che ba mau" -- green pandan pudding/jello, sweet beans, cocconut milk ice, and more asian jellos. DELICIOUS! 

I also had a bite of my friends vietnamese sandwich -- good solid sandwich: meat, pickled vegetables, pate, butter sauce, on a big crispey crunchy roll.
author: Christine B.

description:
Why do they always pick me for juries?

3 of us went to this location for lunch during jury duty.  

Since I took BART to Civic Center then walked, I don't know about the parking situation.

Luckily we got the last table available.  We noticed during the lunch hour people were waiting for tables.  

The service was prompt & our orders arrived quickly.

We all ordered pho.  Mine was vegetarian.  Both the size & taste were fine.  I also ordered the Vietnamese drip coffee, which I really like.  $7 for the pho, $3 for the coffee.

Before visiting the Asian Art Museum I have dined at their tenderloin location.  The menu, service, & atmosphere seem similar.

The verdict...guilty of being a good Vietnamese restaurant.
author: Saul M.

description:
Went there for dinner because of the reputation of the parent store and was jonesing for some Pho in my neighborhood.   Was quite disappointed.  It was overpriced and limited.  Menu items running around $15 with a very small selection.  However, the stars goes to the nice manager/server who let me order out of the dinner menu which saved me some money and got me access to the pho.  

Mind you this is NORTHERN region pho, so it does not come with the greeneries as the Southern...the more traditional pho as most SFer knows it.  

The broth was salty and not particularly flavorful, and the beef steak was so so.  If you go with Northern food at least make the broth out of this earth as there is no way to really supplement it as with southern pho.

However, I would probably return to try some of the rice dices.....just not at dinner prices.
author: J P.

description:
Their pho is quite good. No I take that back. IT'S SO FREAKIN GOOD. 

It's not your typical pho you get from most restaurants. It's northern style pho which uses flatter noodles, different cuts of meat that are ridiculously tender, a whiter broth, and you dont use sriracha or hoisin sauce. Although I do love all types of pho, this is probably my favorite. 

Also, try their sandwiches. it's pretty delicious. I want it now. 

They did a weird thing with not selling pho for dinner but now they do. The only issue is that sometimes the broth is not as hot as it should be and the meat doesnt get cooked as well. oh well. still awesome.
author: Young L.

description:
It's been a long time since I've had food this bad in this city. A friend recommend it, but I can't remember who. When I do remember, I'm unfriending them in real life. 

We didn't have the pho. Maybe that would have been better. The stuff we had is making me nauseous just thinking about it. If pho is the star, take the other stuff off the menu before everyone one-stars you to death.
author: Bib G.

description:
I'm "that guy..."  The guy who goes to a Vietnamese restaurant and orders a rice plate or a vermicelli bowl instead of a bowl of hot delicious pho or noodle soup.  I guess I'm just not a big fan of noodle soup (udon, ramen, won ton noodles, etc..)

So here is my review of the grilled pork chop rice plate.  (My usual choice when going out for Vietnamese).  Compared to other pork chop rice plates, this has got to be the worst I've ever had.  The dish was devoid of flavor.  Perhaps, this menu item should have been titled "pork JERKEY over rice."  Overall, this rice plate was a let down--dry and flavorless.  I wouldn't even subject more beagle to these scraps.

The group of 6 I was with also shared 3 orders of the springs rolls.  I had a much better experience with these.  The servings were large.  We probably only needed to order 2 orders.  Each order contained 3 spring rolls, but were cut into 6 pieces.  Each piece itself could have served as a single roll!  Flavors were inline with your typical Vietnamese eatery.

Overall, I can't attest to the actual noodle soup dishes, but the rice dish that I ordered was horrible.
author: Matt S.

description:
If you want the famed pho from Turtle Tower in the Tenderloin, do NOT, I repeat, do NOT go to TT in SoMa for dinner!!  They do not serve pho at night in the restaurant - only for takeout.  instead, they serve relatively pricey entrees (ranging from $15-28) in a space and neighborhood that warrant only $8-10 entrees.  

In addition, the service was slow even though we were the ONLY TABLE in the entire restaurant.  

At the end of the meal, they give you a complimentary bowl of some green jelly-like substance.  I gave it a shot - it was not worth it, even though it was free.
author: B. Y.

description:
I was left dumb-founded by the quality and the service of this place. I was compelled to write a review as soon as I walked out of this place. So First  we walk in and the guy was already confused that we wanted to eat there and not take out.... So we sit down and order our food. The guy that was taking our order came back and actually said that I should change my order because I may not like that particular dish. He brought out the sauce that they sauté the vegetables with and had me smell it. I thought it was alright, but he said that I would like the tofu better.  I was like okay, whatever.... My bf ordered a duck dish...

They bring out the food after a long wait, and one bite of the rice, I knew everything was going to go down hill from there. How does a Vietnamese restaurant mess up rice??? It was sticky and not fully cooked... My vegetable dish with tofu was ridiculous. The tofu came in a separate plate and had no flavor! I added hot sauce to it and made it a bit better... The vegetables looked more like a soup with some tomatoes here and there and long string greens that were not cooked well at all. The soup was tasteless as well...

My bf duck dish was just as bad if not worse. The sauce looked like gelatinous, slimy, clear, slime. We couldn't even cut through the meat. I feel bad for the duck who lost it's life to become such a horrible dish....

Not to mention, they said they would bring out tea for us, and didn't.  We ordered a coconut juice and they didn't bring it even after we had asked for it. We wanted to get out of there as soon as possible. My bf was pretty pissed about spending money at this place. They charged for the coconut juice that we didn't receive. So I told the confused guy and he simple said that he would have the other guy take care of it. He left it on the counter and didn't even tell the cashier to change it. I went up there and told him and just paid for the disgusting meal even though I know I shouldn't have...

I have never had anything so bad. There is a McDonald's across the street. I don't think there has ever been a time where I would rather have McD.......
author: Nadia M.

description:
Not impressed.

The pho was good, but the imperial roll vermicelli dish we had was tiny and not presented well. It was just sort of a weird dish, that wasn't plated to be mixed, but we weren't given enough lettuce to make wraps. It was just sort of a "small plate of stuff to eat," rather than a meal. And it was overpriced. For the same price, we could have gotten a nice full meal somewhere else. If I ever go back, I'll stick to the pho.
author: C. H.

description:
Came here for lunch with some friends, since we were going to be in the area. I've tried the other turtle towers and I really enjoy Chicken pho as well. So every time I'm craving a chicken pho, or have a hangover (like my friend did the day we came), soup noodles is the way to go!

Ordered a small chicken pho. Tried the soup, ate the noodles and chicken.. there is definitely something missing. I can't pin down what it is. Might be the soup base, but it just doesn't taste as tasty as the other Turtle Towers that I've been to.

Overall, this place wouldn't be on the top of my Turtle Tower list, but will stop by only if I'm in the area. I've had better...
author: Tiffany T.

description: This place is one of the best and most consistent Vietnamese restaurants on the city. My favorite thing to get here is the chicken banh mi, though the pho is also quite delicious. What makes the chicken sandwich is the fact that they grill it right before and it's very fresh. After I ate one, I literally retraced my steps and had to go back to get another!
author: Jimmy H.

description:
I love pho, and went for the beef combination pho.

The whole soup smelled kinda weird. The meat was either frozen, or not super fresh.

It didn't come with the usual soy beans or herbs that you can add in the soup either.

I stopped mid-way on my large pho, because frankly it wasn't very good.

Still waiting for a good pho place in SOMA/South beach!
author: Matthieu T.

description:
Turtle Tower is some of my favorite pho in the city and I was thrilled when they opened the Soma location! The first time I went the service was terrible. Disorganized etc but the food was delicious. 

The second time I went, for dinner, they wouldn't let us order pho. They gave us a 'dinner' menu that did not include pho. We were told if we wanted pho we would have to take it to go. We were one of two tables in the entire place! It was hard to believe that they couldn't say something like, next time, you will have to carry it out. It was absurd. 

So fine, we ordered and then we waited, and waited and waited.....finally we asked about our food and it turns out it had been sitting behind the counter for who knows how long. The waiter didn't bother to tell us it was ready!

Boo hiss.
author: Miranda J.

description: Just as delicious as the original in my neighborhood. And the perfect stop on these cold winter days. I had the Pho Ga and some spring rolls. The large is just a dollar more than the small and definitely enough for two meals.
author: Christy Z.

description: The food is ok, but it's exceptionally slow for some reason. I've been here twice and each time waited a half hour for a sandwich
author: Amy T.

description:
We went to the little saigon location more than a yr ago and the wife didn't like it but I thought it was ok. I figured she didn't like the decor or 'hood and that impacted her decision. One bad experience and she writes it off forever. I'm much more forgiving.  So I was excited to try it again closer to our own 'hood.

First off I ordered spring rolls. The rice paper was dry like it had been sitting out for some time or not wet enough. Not a good start to help sell the wife. Second there were no condiments on the table so we had to ask. I thought these were staples to a Vietnamese place. Third and the biggest killer was that we both thought the pho broth was bland. She always gets chicken and I always get some beef mix. I got just rare beef this time and the meat looked beat up and was a bit on the tough side.

I convinced her to go back again and we'll pass on pho and see if their rice dishes or sandwiches are any good. if either are good I might upgrade the rating. 

Everyone has their go to pho place but this one is not on our list. Not even close.
author: Paul B.

description:
I had such high hopes for this place due to the 4.5 stars my fellow yelpers gave.  Unfortunately, my hopes were all shattered.  

The wait was excruciating.  With a long list on their whiteboard, I would think they would make every effort to turn their tables quickly.  I hate getting my check before I ask for it in a nice high end restaurant - but at a casual joint like Turtle Tower, they should be dropping those checks on the table as soon as the customer takes that last bite of banh mi or swallows that final spoonful of soup.  Not to say that they need to rush their customers but sometimes, a nudge in the right direction is just what you need.  Better for revenue, better for tips, and better for the people waiting in line.

The staff seemed confused.  If you ask for a simple change in one of their menu items, they have to check with the boss first.  That is something you can prep your staff on beforehand.  I noticed one customer ordered a small bowl of noodles, received a big bowl, was charged for the big bowl, and when he questioned it on his bill, the server looked doubtful and asked another server for help.  I thought they would adjust his bill and only charge him for a small bowl but they didn't.  That doesn't seem like a smart business decision.

The banh mi is weird and not exactly authentic.  I'm not normally concerned about the cultural authenticity of my food - as long as it tastes good.  Turtle Tower offers banh mi with butter, mayo, veggies and a choice of 3 items: pate, jambon, sausage, grilled chicken, grilled pork, and a fried egg.  But how can you offer pate and jambon for banh mi if you don't have cha lua??!!?!  It's a disgrace to the banh mi.  I'm not even going to discuss the randomness of having a sausage and fried egg option.  

Btw, if you want to pay an additional $3.50 for extra chicken for your pho ga, you should know that it comes on a small condiment dish.  I also don't like how the banh mi comes in a basket.  Considering how it's a sit down lunch, shouldn't my food at least come on a regular plate?

I give it one star, partly because yelp is making me do it, partly because they pour their water out of a Brita pitcher, partly because the disposable chopsticks are the good kind.
author: Peggy N.

description: Turtle Tower I like this place because it's by my school/job and their soups are really great packed with full flavor. There is not really anything mind blowing about this restaurant but I like the atmosphere and it's outstanding customer service. There is not much to write unless I try more soups but hey, it's better than canned soup lol.
author: Ahrmon R.

description: Way under staff, no service and no one pick up the phone for to go and it took 20mins get the food for a bowl of pho to go
author: Winfred L.

description:
I never write reviews, but felt that I should warn people about this place.Not sure if they break health violations or not, but I was grossed out enough to vow to never come back again.
My wife and I were big fans of the original Turtle Tower in the Tenderloin and would go out of our way for their tasty pho- steamy tasty broth and their unique wide noodles. It wasn't the cleanest restaurant, but there wasn't anything that grossed us out. I am pretty tolerant of dirty places.
After our last visit to this location, sadly we will never return to any of the Turtle Tower locations. We came for dinner at around 6:00 and I asked where the restroom was- they pointed to a room where I had seen a guy on a ladder. I figured it was a closet because he was putting things into cabinets, but no, that was the bathroom. When I got into the bathroom I saw that the cabinets were storage for their food containers, napkins, etc.. About two feet next to the toilet, sitting on top of a trash can was a bag of to-go sauce lids. Health code or not, I find this super gross and unhealthy. Food-related anything does not belong in the bathroom.
My wife had already ordered and we had a super sleepy kid with us, so I decided not to say anything to my wife and go ahead and eat.
Regardless of the bathroom experience it was a terrible meal. I had the #1 well done brisket and beef pho. The broth was not hot- just warm and the beef was nasty looking- like somebody had chewed on it a while and spit it back.
My wife got the vermicelli noodles with imperial rolls and it super sucked. The imperial rolls were burnt, and the noodles were slopped onto a plate and spilling over the side  and when the waiter brought it to our table he was touching the noodles with his fingers. Gross.
On top of it all, mediocre service by distracted waiters.
One of the most depressing meals I've had in a long time.
author: mack h.

description:
Setting: early dinner with a fellow pho lover!  The place was clean and parking was easy. Unfortunately the restaurant isn't on google so it's easy to get lost and go to the wrong turtle tower. Make sure you explicitly clarify the address with your dining companion! 

Order: Empress rolls to start. Or rather, an empress roll. Not a lot of value there, but it was crispy, hot, and quite good. For my main, I ordered chicken pho with stir fry veggies. The bowl was large and the flavor was good, but the chicken was on the fatty side and thus the broth was greasy.  The other Turtle Tower gives nice thick slices of chicken breast.  There were also a lot fewer accoutrements than I'm used to (no basil, sriracha, etc). 

Cost: $13 including tax and tip. Still a solid deal for dinner.
author: Janet Z.

description:
i don't know why I gave this location a shot after being turned off by my first visit to the location in the TL. OH... i remember now! scoutmob had a promotion on it for a complimentary small bowl of pho ga. 

even though it was complimentary... i wish i went somewhere else for lunch. i just don't see what the hype was. soup was pretty bland.. .service was off (even for a new location) and the noodles were way too soft. 

if i were to come here again... it would definitely NOT be for their pho ga....
author: amelia g.

description:
After an hour wait on a chilly San Francisco night to redeem our Scoutmob deal, we were informed that they had run out of pho noodles.  We asked if they would substitute an entree to be redeemed, but the staff member pointedly claimed that the deal was only valid for chicken pho.

I understand that is exactly what the deal was for, but they must have known they were running low on pho noodles, and could have kindly informed those waiting outside about the situation.  Also, with a couple hours left on the last day of the deal, could they really not satisfy the handful of customers who were still steadfastly waiting to try the noodles?

This wasted hour will leave a bitter taste in my mouth should I consider their pho in the future.
author: Andrew M.

description: A decent spot for pho in the SOMA area.  I'm sure we'll meet again.
author: Gerald C.

description:
I came here with my trusty scoutmob "free pho ga" coupon. I've been meaning to make a trip out, since this location is more convenient for me. They've been alternately not open for dinner, then open but pho only available for take out. This seems to have changed, since we came early on a Friday (at 5 pm), and were promptly seated for some sit-in pho.

The ambience is bright and clean, though you might have to share tables when you come during a busier time. The waitress was very friendly, even when we told her we were using our scoutmob coupons. Probably the best service I've had at a pho place, although it was a little hard to get their attention to get our check.

The pho itself - we ordered pho ga (chicken pho): 
- Love the flavor of the soup
- Noodles are wider than the normal pho noodles you see
- Soup is more of the northern style pho you'd get (we just went to Hanoi earlier this year, and it was reminiscent of the pho there)
- Along with that, you don't get the "normal" toppings of basil, and bean sprouts. You do get some jalapenos.
- Meat is actual pieces of chicken, as opposed to the thinner shabu shabu style chicken. I liked that.

Overall, this is the best chicken pho I've had in SF. It's the most authentic chicken pho I've had, and I would definitely go back.
author: Erin Y.

description:
Got to go for lunch with my co worker. 

I got the rare beef pho. I like the meat they use for this pho. However they did not give hoisin or sriracha for to go orders to make sure you ask for it. 

My Vietnamese co worker said the broth was good, a little fatty though. 

Not a fan of the fat noodles but all Turtle Tower locations seem to use this. 

Was crowded for lunch. People waiting out the door. Parking is a bit tough but there's 2 hour parking around so you don't have to pay meter.
author: Jessica L.

description: The Pho Ga is really special here. It has that "just like mom used to make" feel and flavor. Warning: the large dish is VERY large. It is so delicious that I can't stop myself from eating it all and then I feel like I am about to explode - it is a love hate type relationship. Mostly love ;) Even for people who don't typically enjoy Pho, I would recommend the Pho Ga. The chicken broth is just delicious. The people are always nice and courteous. North Vietnamese food doesn't have oyster sauce (unfortunately) but with the flavors here you shouldn't miss it. I would give it 5 stars if their beef pho was as good. It's not bad - I'd order it again. But really the chicken dish is the must try here.
author: Nivay A.

description:
They must have read my review!  I went back about a week later and there was almost no chicken skin in my pho ga!  Right on!!!  

Imperial rolls are still a little expensive.  I'll just eat fewer.
author: S. Y.

description:
I've always wondered if having to fight off crackheads is what makes the pho at the Larkin Turtle Tower so delicious. To answer this question, I tried this new Turtle Tower in SOMA. I found that without crackheads on the street, the pho is JUST as delicious.
     This week was the grand opening, so they only offered a limited menu. However, their famous chicken pho was on par with their other locations. The place nice and clean. There was no sticky floors or sticky tables.
     In the absence of crackheads, this location offers something the Larkin location doesn't...Bahn mi. Not the best I've ever had, but the bread was fresh, the pate, pork, and ham were all flavorful. THe carrots and cucumbers added great texture, but no daikon radish.
     I see a lot of potential in this place. With this location being so close to me, I'll definitely be back when they are ready with the full menu.
author: Siao W.

description: I ordered (2) spring rolls and they gave me (1) peanut sauce. WTF!
author: Gwen K.

description:
Be afraid of their chicken pho.. its like crack.. makes me come back for more!! I usually get 2 if I have a crazy hang over along with vietnamese coffee. yee~ baby! 

I have been eating at Turtle Tower's other locations in SF for years. Both Larkin and Geary locations are great. But this new location on 6th and Bryant is even better!!! How convenient!!!!

THE ENDUP Sat/Sunday afterhours/day party crowd will fill this place up as soon as this place opens on Sunday. Str8 crackhead status no doubt.
author: Calvin H. L.

description:
A cute clean place.. The staff was extremely friendly. I ordered the Pho Ga
and it was massive.. They use wide rice noodle which is different than I am use to but still good. It did not have much chicken but the broth was flavorful.
I shared the Imperial roll which was not as good I am use to.. They were small and very greasy..
author: Robert O.

description: it's cool to have another location close to the office. better come early though. the spot is a bit small... maybe about 10 tables? food is exactly as expected from the TL location. mMm...
author: Ann T.

description:
I had a field meeting at nearby South Beach Friday that run during my usual lunch hour. Thinking about what to eat, I decided to check out this new Turtle Tower location.

First thing I notice is that it's smaller than either of the other two locations. They were offering some items as Grand Opening specials still, so I ordered one of then: the beef stew with wine sauce noodle soup.

The reason I'm giving this a low rating is because after I ordered (and it took longer for my order to be taken than it should have in the first place), the food didn't come for a long time. It was a small restaurant and I think somebody should gave observed that there was a problem, because I was looking at all the passing staff with no food on my table for quite some time. Finally the guy who took the order made the observation, asked me about that, and at least he nicely apologizes. Still, I feel that's a sign of lack of overall attention. Hopefully it's something that will be improved upon.
author: H K.

description:
So, apparently I have been eating un-authentic Pho for some time now.  

I ordered the #2 Pho with rare beef.  I must say the beef was the best quality beef I have ever had served in Pho.  The noodles were different, too.  They were flat fetuccini style vs. vermicelli style.  No matter.  They were still good.

However, the plate of add-yourself-toppings only had a lime wedge and some jalapenos.  No bean sprouts or basil.  There was also no Sriracha or hoisin sauce at the table.  There was jar of red pepper paste which I opted to use in place of the Sriracha.  When I asked about hoisin, all was explained:  Hoisin is not an authentic condiment for Pho. The choice of toppings is northern style (basil and, I'm assuming, bean sprouts are typical of southern style).  They do have Sriracha, but the owner prefers to use the uncooked paste rather than the cooked Sriracha sauce, a personal preference but he will bring you Sriracha if you ask.

So basically, it is very tasty Pho, good quality meat, but no hoisin, basil or bean sprouts leaves me a tad torn.  

I would go back since its close, cheap and good quality, but maybe with a hidden bottle of hoisin in my purse ;-)
author: Annette W.

description:
I like Turtle Tower because they're different from most Vietnamese places I've been to. I can expect a healthy tasting, yet still delicious and fulfilling meal. I love their chicken noodle soup, the broth is so yummy. I'll find myself spending the first 5 min of receiving it just sipping on the broth. I'm glad they opened one by my work :) 

One disappointing thing I might add - the eggrolls are SMALL. I love fried eggrolls (the Imperial one) and I ordered it last week. It was the size of my index finger (length and width, no kidding) and they charged $2.15 EACH (I ordered three). Never again.
author: Rosie W.

description: SLOW SLOW SLOW.  One guy to seat and take orders and to run the cash register.  On a Sunday!
author: C L.

description:
Awesome to have this place in the neighborhood. We went there at lunch on a Saturday expecting it to be quiet (our hood is a little sleepy on weekends). The place was packed with a wait list.
Food is still a limited menu but the pho ga, spring rolls and banh mi were all really good. Sandwiches are unique -- you can pick 3 ingredients to combine -- and a great value.

I only hope they extend their hours into the evening.
Welcome to the neighborhood!
author: Margie L.

description:
:: Service, Setting ::
Just opened, so service is disorganized. 

The place is generally set-up for tables of 2 people. Went with 4 people and ended up waiting for 30min as pair after pair who walked in the door were seated minutes later.

:: Food ::
Vietnamese sandwich was DELICIOUS, and only $4.50. I got to choose 3 meats from a list (fried egg, grilled chicken, grilled pork) and the sandwich came with the usual veggies and slathered with butter.

Maybe it was the wait, but the sandwich was to die for.
Note: HaNoi cuisine, but I forget the veggie their menu said they don't use
author: Frances N.

description:
Looking for a gourmet Ph and California Asian fusion cuisine? Don't come here. Looking for ambience? Don't come here. 

Looking for tasty Ph and other tasty traditional dishes? Looking for a vietnamese place in SOMA for your lunch break stop?  Looking to avoid the overpriced lunch spots and McDonald's options?  Go here.
author: Amelia C.

description:
5 stars for the pho.  Still the best bowl of pho in SF.  Love the rich, warm broth and slippery noodles sliding down my throat...Mmmmm.

The SOMA location is much cleaner than the TL location, and service is better.  I prefer to come for dinner since lunch can be too crowded and chaotic.  Tried some of the 'new' dinner menu items...been hit or miss.  I'm sticking with the pho.  It's a cure-all for everything!
author: Karin V.

description:
Turtle tower just opened up a few weeks ago, and it's pretty close to work, so I thought it would be a great new option to add to my lunch routine. But I've come here 3 times, ordering various different items each time, and I've left disappointed for the most part.  Maybe I just don't like northern style Vietnamese food.

Spring rolls - This was actually pretty good, and came with a tasty peanuty dipping sauce. My only complain was that one of the pieces of lettuce was tinged brown because it was slightly wilted.  

Beef Stew in Wine Sauce - The flavor is ok, but it's sooo salty. 

Vermicelli - It's Northern style, so it's not mixed for you.  Instead of grilled pork, you get meat patties.  And there isn't as much of a mix of veggies.  

Combination Beef Pho - The broth wasn't as flavorful as I had hoped.  Also, the beef I got looked like  it had been grounded and it didn't taste very good.  It was still pink after soaking in the pho, which was warm rather than hot.  I didn't finish my dish because I didn't like it very much.

And the final note is that the prices here are kinda high for Vietnamese food.  You can get similar or better quality Vietnamese food for much cheaper in SF.  Just go to Sunset or Tenderloin.
author: Tyler C.

description:
Love Turtle tower.

Love that its now within crawling distance from my house.

The corner of 6th and Bryant has been in need of some good food for quite some time now.  The Quiznos was, well, a quiznos, and I don't think I really gave it much thought when it shut down. It was then replaced by a terrible korean place.  I'm not going to sugar coat it, this restaurant was truly bad and what was up with that name?  When I heard that the next occupent was going to be Turtle Tower I was immediately giddy with excitement.  No longer must I brave the feces-ridden and urine-flooded streets of little saigon to get my Pho fix. 

Several weeks later I've been to the new location at least twice.  Its small and there is definitely a rush at lunch time so make sure to get there early (or late).  I've very happy to see that they have begun doing business on the weekend which will come quite in handy the next morning after a friday or saturday night full of merriment (i.e. drinking).  They are still going through some "getting started" pains and service has not been as smooth as I might hope, but the people that work there are great, the food is delicious, and I'm sure it will get smoother with time.  Highly recommended if you live or work in the SOMA area!
author: jacob l.

description: Didn't realize this was Ha Noi style pho, being Vietnamese myself I have never had this. It was good, though I prefer the regular style pho. My GF really enjoyed it though so there is another perspective for you. She has the chicken pho and the chicken was juicy. I had the beef and there was a good amount of beef but waaay too much noodles for me. I guess thats not a bad thing. Give this place a try.
author: Dang L.

description:
Turtle Tower on Larkin street is awesome. They have some of the best Pho I've had in the city. I especially like the Ph St Vang (Beef Stewed in Wine Sauce Noodle Soup).

Turtle Tower on 6th street?...not so much. I got all happy that they opened up a new Turtle Tower that was closer to my house but after coming here 3 times now, I have to say I'm kinda disappointed with the quality of the food. It's still decent but just not nearly as good as the one on Larkin street. 

There's usually a line to be seated but once you're in, the service is generally pretty good and fast. 

Bottom line...if you love Pho, you gotta check out Turtle Tower but if you have the choice, go to the other branch on Larkin street instead.
author: Ali A.

description: Sub-par pho, bland broth, and bad service; I'd much rather go to Miss Saigon a couple of blocks away. I hear the one in the TL is better, I'll have to give that one a try.
author: Kevi L.

description:
Pho is not chicken soup. The broth is supposed to be a magic elixir. But here the pho is just chicken soup with curly noodles...no magic.  
But we went back and it got worse.
OK, so they just opened this location, but really the customer service isn't just bad because the folks are new, there is a passive aggressive element to the service...or lack thereof. 
We wanted rice instead of noodles under one of the dishes. The counter person walked to the back, checked the rice cooker, confirmed that there was plenty of rice and then refused to give us any because...the dish is supposed to be served with noodles. wtf? 
Check my reviews, I am a pushover, but this place was truly a two star experience and freefalling.......
Went to the guy across the street at "Grab and Go". Terrible name for a little Vietnamese hole in the wall, but he is friendly, works hard and cranks out three star cuisine every day.
author: Miss F.

description:
Update, went again today for lunch.  Had the #1: beef brisket and well done beef noodle soup.  I love that they use wide, flat noodles in some of their soups.  It was tasty and there was plenty of it.  Served with a small plate of lemon and jalepenos.  I put some red chili sauce and white vinegar in it.  Strange they don't have Sriracha (Rooster sauce) on every table.  Had the Thai Iced tea, as well, which was tasty.

At the end of the meal, the waiter refused to let us split the check between two credit cards.  He claimed the system wouldn't let them.  I've seen other waiters admit this is always a lie.  Minor annoyance as I had cash.

Nice waiter, though, good service, fresh food, will be back.
author: Lauren J.

description: I like their pho very much. Their soup is more clear and tasteful than most other pho places in the Bay Area. But there is one thing that makes me give them a two star. They don't stick to their published opening hours! I came here twice on Sunday evenings and they weren't open. Came here once Monday evening, closed again. They really need to respect their customers by operating to their business hours, otherwise don't say you are open on Monday/Sunday evenings!
author: Stephanie C.

description:
hanoi-style vietnamese food is what they tell me. i asked for hoisin sauce for my pho the first time i went, and the server shook their head in shame.

fine, i get it. hoisin sauce probably just fucks up the taste and authenticity of the broth, so i went ahead and kept the goin' going. i ordered the combo pho dish with rare beef, brisket and tripe, and all was well. 

to top it off, the breaded and deep-fried cuttlefish for $2+ was delicious; the vinegar and fish sauce made up for the missing hoisin.  i had to let go...
author: Dennis D.

description:
Let's face it. The TT in the TL is not in the most desirable part of town. Once you see how dirty the side alley and streets are, you sort of lose your appetite. Lucky for them, the noodles are good but over the years the hype has gone up, the place has gotten dirtier, the staff has become less friendly and more importantly, they started to phase out the sriracha. I've found myself going less frequently.

... That is until Turtle Tower opened up a shop at a smaller but cleaner location! They serve the same good chicken pho I love, they don't give me attitude when I ask for sriracha sauce and the staff is much much much nicer here. I hope it stays this way.

If you can't afford to spend $6.75 on a bowl of noodles, you probably shouldn't eat in SF.

NOTE: I've only come here for lunch but I do know this location is closed on Sundays.
author: Natalie N.

description: I went here because I heard it was good but this is the wrong location.  I didn't know they have another T.T on Larkin.  Anyway, I rather have KFC or Micky D rather then eating here.  The soup is not edible.  Both the chicken broth and the beef broth is too salty and blend at the same time (if that is possible)as if you put salt in just water.  I'll say instant cup noodle tasted better.    I talked to my Vietnamese friend who said if you want T.T noodle just go to Larkin and only order the chicken soup.  OK thanks for the tip!
author: Mar H.

description: Like a hidden gem. The grilled pork noodles dip 'bun cha', chicken pho 'pho ga', rice silk crepe with ground pork and mushroom 'banh cuon' and 'pho ap chao' are really done in the Hanoian way (my hometown).
author: Anh N.

description: I'm a big phan of the pho-like rice noodles with tripe, beef and pork. You will not be dissapointed.
author: Ben P.

description: Ahh.. was craving a hot bowl of pho for over a month now and today I finally got a bowl.. I came here at 8:15pm and there was two other table. A table of 4 that was already eating and someone that was eating by themselves.. I'm usually not a fan of eating alone but I said screw it I'll do it anyways (that's how badly I wanted a bowl of pho). The gentlemen at the counter ask me how how many and I said one he told me to take a seat anywhere so I sat down. The moment I sat down I think he for caught up with other things and forgot I was sitting there.. thought to myself really there's only two tables.. ugh no menu no water until someone else walked into the store before he realized I was still waiting for a menu.. I knew exactly what I wanted but I wanted to check out their menu so I told him to give me a min before I order in case I wanted some appetizer. Ordered the pho ga and I asked him if they have the thick noodles and he said yes and I told him I wanted the thick noodles.. when he brought me my bowl I was a little disappointed because those "thick" noodles isn't really the thick 'hoa fun' noodles that I expected it to be.. regardless was still looking forward to having something soupy.
