First bite into the noodles and I was pretty pleased with the texture but my next bite with the soup was a bit salty. I thought maybe cause it wasn't mixed correctly or something so I tossed the noodles around and just took a scoop of the broth the next bite. Omg the soup was still so salty.. I couldn't bare it. Waited for the waiter to come back and I asked him for a cup of hot water. Really heavy on the hands today with the salt.. I literally poured the whole glass of water into the bowl of soup before I could eat the noodles again.. cravings not satisfied.. I still ate all the noodles though because it tasted better after I added a whole glass of water. Walked up to the counter and ask for my check paid and left to McDonald's to get some ice cream because my mouth felt salty still.. pretty disappointed because this is my second time here but I don't remember it being this bad the first time (I haven't been back since two years ago even though I'm in the neighborhood all the time)
author: Lily Y.

description: Got the chicken noodle soup.. was not anything special.. would not go back there. it was plain and boring.
author: C A.

description: I ordered the #19 - grilled pork with rice.  The pork was tough, chewy and dry.  The grilled pork was not grilled, it was microwaved.  Better off with my frozen Stouffer dinner.
author: susan g.

description: I don't know why this location has such a bad average rating. The other one might slightly taste better, but the parking is easier here and there is no wait. The staff seems friendlier as well. The menu is exactly same as the other location.
author: Vanessa W.

description: This restaurant is a lot bigger than the one in the TL and my favorite, the #6 Panfried Pho here is tastier!  It's also closer to downtown and easier to get to.  Will be going to this location from now on.
author: Erica D.

description: Was in the neigborhood and decided to try this restaurant.  bad decision.  i mean bad bad decision.  ordered rare beef noodle soup and beef stew with rice.  beef stew in wine sauce that is. the ugly -   what i got was beef in red dye number 2 with plenty of cornstarch.  no wine, no vegetables (not one piece), no taste  Rare beef noodle soup - the meat is rare (or at least pink).  Well done was what we got.
author: Bill L.

description:
my go-to place when it's chilly and i'm in need of something soupy...oh wait, that's like every night in SF :D  what's even more awesome is that the 6th st. location is only 2 blocks away from me!

the pho ga broth is AH-MAAAAAA-ZZZZZING:  clear, flavorful, and fresh-tasting.

the Pho Sot Vang (Beef Stewed in Wine Sauce Noodle Soup) is one of the most unique soups i've ever had, with super tender pieces of beef.

we've even mixed it up and gotten the banh mi a few times.  TASTY! (albeit no contest with saigon sammies)

not sure why TT gets a bad rap sometimes.  it is what it is, and it doesn't pretend to be something it's not.  i'm always satisfied when i walk out of there and counting down the hours until it's appropriate to go back for another bowl of hot steamy delicious soup ^_^
author: Susan L.

description:
Whenever I come to Turtle Tower I always get the large Chicken Pho.  It's my go to dish, and when I'm craving pho, Turtle Tower always comes to mind.  The service has always been great, but just a bit slow.  They're known for their Chicken Pho, so if you order anything else, sorry but you may be disappointed.  

Just a few things to keep in mind:
*If you don't want the skin you have to ask for skinless chicken, but they do charge extra for that.
*If they only give you cilantro and NOT basil for your pho, they probably think you don't know the difference, so definitely ask for it.
*It's a really small spot, so if you're heading there for lunch, expect to wait 20-30 minutes to be seated.
author: Rachel L.

description: Northen vietnamese vs southern vietnamese? I don't know about all of that, but the pho here is not what you would expect. Not a big fan of their beef pho. I mean it's ok, but not awesome. The pho ga is also not an awesome pho, but as a chicken soup it rocks! If you are feeling sick come go here and harness the healing power of pho! Er, chicken soup!
author: J D.

description: If I can give it no star, I would grant it.  The soup:  what can I say was too salty and too oily as big as an oil spill at the refinery! There was enough salt to kill an elephant.  Some little bird must have been listening to the yelp reviews, which repeats the theme of bland.    Attention turtles,. putting salt in the bland soup doesn't make it more tasty.   With that many Vietnamese restaurants around, this turtle soup sucks! I've never been to the other one but I'll definitely try the other one before coming to this one.
author: Lantz G.

description: What noodle place runs out of noodles on a Friday night? This place. It sucks. Getting worse too. I'm a big fan of the #9 but sorry I cannot frequent this location any longer. I'm giving them 2 stars because the waitress working last Friday night kept her composure.
author: Jerry H.

description: Parking sucks here but the soups are excellent... clean and refreshing, not oily like the other pho places.  I prefer this Northern style pho.
author: L T.

description:
Great new place - have been waiting for them to open, and it did not disappoint.  

Very fresh ingredients, generous portions, fast service, willing to do a custom accommodation, very friendly staff, reasonable prices.  They are promising to stay open all week soon - which will be great for people who live around here, like me.  

There are a few fast food places around here, but their approach to cooking is not anywhere near as healthy at the Turtle Tower.

Will come back a few times next week to see if the quality keeps up,
But for now - welcome to the neighborhood!
author: Michael V.

description: Chicken Pho is good here, do NOT order any of the rice dishes. Cash only, there is an ATM inside.
author: Daniel K.

description:
My credit card statement for the last month had Turtle Tower on it 4 times.  I guess that make me a regular?

This is a go-to take out place for me when I don't feel like cooking.  The flat rice noodles reheat well, they give a good sized portion of meat, and I like that they dice up the jalapeños for you.  They do a nice job of packing up your takeout so it's easy to reheat in a couple of minutes.  The broth errs on the salty side, but that's ok -- just add water!
author: Steven Y.

description: I grew up in San Jose and have been fortunate to experience some very good Vietnamese food.  This Turtle Tower location hasn't impressed me after two visits.  The meat wasn't very fresh and everything seemed soggy.  Some people love this place, so your mileage may vary.
author: Robin S.

description: I eat a whole lot of PHO. I rarely have the Pho Ga but since this is what the speciality is here I thought I would have some. It was awesome!!!!! I loved it, Ill be back.
author: Jill T.

description: Yummy!! Love, Love, Love the chicken pho. It is that good!!
author: Amanda T.

description: I got take out from the place a couple weeks ago and sadly the food ended up in the garbage bin due to contamination. I don't think I'd go back ever. I should have paid better attention to their health score.
author: Mehmet G.

description: Chicken Pho is alright... don't love it nor do i hate it. But maybe if i was hungover, I'd give it another star.
author: Lana L.

description:
By birth, or at least by having an amazing cook of a mom, I have pretty high standards for pho and banh mi. Enough that I shouldn't make the mistake of ordering a sandwich at a pho restaurant. Well, on a warm day ill suited to hot soup, I learned from my mistake -- and discovered that this pho restaurant makes a wicked delicious banh mi. Pick three ingredients: mine were pâté, pork, and a fried egg. Each element (naturally, golden bread and veggies included) was sublime. Kilometers better than any banh mi I've had visiting relatives in the enormous enclave of SoCal's Little Saigon. And on my top 3 outside of Vietnam (and the Tenderloin). 

Go. Try it.

Mom might flinch at the idea of her son ordering banh mi at a noodle shop. But she'd be happy about him learning such delightful lessons from his mistakes.
author: Tom N.

description:
reading reviews on this TT location just solidifies my opinion that 75% of all yelpers are provincial retards without a clue about cultural cuisine...

"oh why no accompanying herbs and sprouts?"
"why no bean sauce?"
"2 stars because the meat was ground and looked cheap!"

why none of the above?!
its northern Vietnamese cuisine...THATS WHY.

seriously.  head on over there to pho hoa, order a #3 and while you're there, pick up some authentic orange chinese chicken from panda express, you god damned hacks.
author: J puff marshmellowman C.

description: Just came home from their soft opening and i've got to say HELLLS YAHHHH!!! One more turtle tower in sf is just one step closer to saving the world. Not only that, they've added new items to the menu and you can only get them at this location!! what is it?? we'll you'll just have to go there and see for youself!! ;)
author: Kristen C.

description:
i love pho, and i have been to both of the other turtle tower locations on numerous occasions.  my husband is vegetarian and does not eat pho, so i was psyched to find out that this location has banh mi w/ fried egg...something to satiate the veg palate! 

i have had a serious pho craving for the last few weeks, and i wanted to fulfill it before moving to london for 6 months.  i ordered the pho ga for myself and the banh mi w/ fried egg for my husband.  the waiter asked me what other meats he wanted (you have a choice of up to 3 for only $4.50), and i said just egg, b/c he's vegetarian.  

when the sandwich came, it looked great, and my husband ate half and loved it.  for the second half, he opened up the sandwich to put on some hot sauce when he saw something that looked like shredded chicken on top of the egg.  he told me to taste it, and it tasted like chicken.  we called over a waitress and asked her if it was chicken, and she said, "yes, it's part of the house dressing," which comes w/ the sandwich.  never in my right mind did i think that the house dressing would include meat!!!  i was very disappointed, and the waitress asked if we wanted a new sandwich w/o the house dressing.  by this point, my husband had lost his appetite, and he didn't finish the 2nd half of his sandwich.  

the waitress was nice enough to take 20% off my bill, but at the same time, i think they should warn people that "dressing" includes chicken.  her reasoning was that their menu does not include any vegetarian food, so you would have to actually say "no meat" if you wanted the sandwich w/o meat, but how was i supposed to know?
author: Helen T.

description: Sorry to say that this place almost made me sick.  I know that the North Vietnamese cooking is different, but is it supposed to leave a taste in your mouth like you just ate raw beef?  The beef in the Pho wasn't cooked all the way and was flavorless.  Other dishes that had pork in it didn't seem like it was cooked as well.  Is all North Vietnamese food like this or is it just me?
author: Mitch A.

description: This is my favorite Vietnamese place in the city along with Out the Door.  The Pho is aaaamazing, and whenever I have a hard workout, all I can think about is their Bahn Mi sandwiches.  They are so friendly and nice here -- expect a wait if it's after 12pm sharp.  I could eat here every day if it were just sliiightly healthier.  Expect minimal veggies.
author: Michelle T.

description: Love Turtle Tower.  My favorite is the rare beef Pho.  Everything I've had there thus far has been good.  Great authentic northern style Vietnamese food.
author: Trey C.

description:
In a word-WEAK....ordered the "Beef stew" and what came was a small bowl of some relatively bland reddish sauce w/some chunks of low quality meat.No attempt to gussy it up at all w/some cilantro,pieces of onion etc....pretty lame.And service is non-existent.Maybe there Pho is the better thing to order but I wont know cuz I wont return...
ps-Grab n Go across the street is a much better choice and the owner Steve is a great guy
author: james m.

description: I had #11 (Bún Thang - Chicken, Finely Sliced Egg, Ground Pork, & Shrimp Paste Vermicelli Noodle Soup) and my bf had #5 (Pho Sot Vang - Beef Stewed in Wine Sauce Noodle Soup). Both were great. I loved my soup! The flavors were superb and  I felt full afterwards. Too bad they didn't accept cards and the atm was broken... had to walk a few blocks to the ATM.
author: Yanika S.

description: I been to Turtle Tower for 8 years already, it getting worst and worst, they used to only use free ranch chicken and now they mix it with reg. frozen  chicken, They try to serve dinner on TT location, but their food is terrible , their sizzling beef taste like oyster beef it is so blend and the portion is so small, it is so pricey , I'll never return again.
author: Antonio L.

description: YUM! So glad this is near my house. Already been there twice before their grand opening.  It was already semi-crowded, so beware of lines in the future.  I'm not sure if they are just focusing on lunch or what their deal is, but the pho is YUMMMMMY
author: Skye W.

description: My friend told me they were giving out free pho again on Scoutmob so here we come!!!!! :D WOOT! We came here for dinner so there was actually not much of a wait. The broth was a bit too salty in my opinion but it was overall pretty good.
author: Sharon G.

description: I did not enjoy Turtle Towers.  The noodles were soggy and breaking apart in the soup (I prefer firm noodles) and it tasted a little funky.  The meat was tough and sinewy.  This place was very crowded, so, many people must  like this style of pho, but I did not.
author: Christen W.

description:
Having been in the area because of jury duty, I was craving pho and this was the closest place, but let me tell you, I would've walked farther if it meant better food and overall experience..

I've had my fair share of Vietnamese food, especially pho and I've got to say that this place is NOT good. Although the service was "okay", it is also nothing to rave about. This is why:

1) I don't know ANY vietnamese place that cooks pho with the wide noodles, similar to chow fun in Chinese food. So that was already turnoff number 1.

2) Vietnamese hot coffee - did not come in the dripping filter that I'd expected as the full authentic experience. It came a pre-mixed glass. For $3+ coffee, I'd expect a little more. The taste was "okay", once again.

3) AND PROBABLY THE MOST DISTURBING POINT: THIS PLACE DOES NOT HAVE HOISIN SAUCE! I don't know maybe it's my Chinese side or just my experience with multiple Vietnamese restaurants. What kind of Vietnamese restaurant that serves PHO doesn't have hoisin sauce??? And I'm not even sure the hot sauce in the container was sriracha. The worst part is that the waiter knew very well what I was talking about since he repeated it perfect in prounciation back to me, and just said "No we do not have hoisin sauce" WOW... really? WOW!

4) Cash only - this is a bit of a minus point since most places accept credit card but it's also not too surprising. There is an ATM on-site but be prepared to pay a $2 ATM fee plus whatever your bank charges you. 

So all in all. with a $7 bowl of pho + $3 "vietnamese" coffee + $2 ATM fee (which I understand it's kinda my fault for not carrying cash on me) + $2.50 bank fee (also my fault), my whole lunch experience with pho not really being like pho, turns out to cost about $18 with minimal (yes, MINIMAL) tip. Pretty pricey for Vietnamese food, if you ask me.

Needless to say, I will never come to this restaurant again and maybe after reading this, you won't either. And if you do try, beware...and bring cash.
author: V W.

description: Location is much better than Larkin and parking is easier.  This location also accepts credit cards if you make a minimum order.  I was disappointed with the Pho Ga here because the chicken didn't taste as fresh and the soup wasn't piping hot like the other location.
author: Yvonne N.

description: Bad service + bad food. If you like Turtle Towers go to the one in the TL and AVOID this branch. The TL gets you in, gets you fed and gets you out all with good efficiency and great service. Here you have to assert yourself to get things going and you really shouldn't have to do that anywhere. The broth on the pho was also pretty weak again compared to the other branch.
author: Tony G.

description: I had the egg noodle with chicken soup here yesterday for lunch, during my jury duty service. Let me say that it wasn't the best pho I ever had. The noodles was clumpy as it was undercooked. There were like 7 pieces of chicken, at least the Broth was different. The food pickings are definitely slim around  the Bryant street courthouse.
author: Lawrence F.

description: The pho ga here is really simple but so good! Perfect for brunch or lunch. I was left craving for more. I dint know what to say except that you have to try it for yourself. Be warned, cash only here.
author: Kim P.

description: Ok I really don't get it. This is the 2nd time I've had turtle tower and I don't see the hype. I got the sauteed beef with vegetables, I didn't like it, I don't consider vegetables to be green scallions and celery yuck. But ok I will give to the them broth was pretty clean tasty. Service was very good too.
author: Karen T.

description:
In a word: unimpressive.  In several words:

There is a reason that this the the bay areas "only authentic northern vietnamese" restaurant.  If this is is truly what northern vietnamese is supposed to be, then I will never bother trying it again.  What a disappointment - we were expecting the pho we are used to and instead got what looked like a poor man's pho.

When they brought me my much acclaimed pho ga (side note: wtf 7x7 mag?  Should not be on the top 100 things to eat before you die - should be on the 100 things to eat that make you want to die of disappointment list instead) and said, "Here's your chicken noodle soup".  Sorry, my what?  The broth was salty and tasted lemony, no flavor or substance really.  I basically got a heaping bowl of soggy noodles (not the kind I am used to with southern), bland broth, some slivers low-grade chicken (lots of fat and skin), and a side of mild jalapenos to dump in.  Oh, and a lemon wedge. No hoisin, no bean sprouts, no veggies unless you count slivers of green onions.  If I wanted chicken noodle soup, I would have went to Safeway - Campbells is like $2 I am sure.  I wanted tasty pho ga.  This may partly be because its authentic northern as opposed to southern, but if this is what northern is, I do need to try it again.

People, there is a reason it is so cheap - because you are not getting much.  In fact,  I think it might be over priced for what it is.  Oh, and the building is an old Quiznos, which they somehow found a way to make even dumpier.  And there was a TV blaring E! the whole time.  Whoever said it was like a spa for the stomach must be used to going to the scary cut rate ones in the tenderloin.

Avoid at all costs.  I will never go back.
author: Adrienne C.

description:
Been here numerous times because I live in the neighborhood, but had to write a review after my visit tonight.  Had the chicken egg noodle soup and a banh sandwich.  

Both were mostly underpar, but what I really wanted to call out was how freakin' salty the soup was.  It was like the kitchen accidently knocked over the whole salt container into the soup.  Undrinkable to say the least.  Very disappointed.

As for the sandwich, pretty dry and the bread wasn't even toasted.

Maybe they had a bad night, but just felt compelled to share my terrible experience there tonight.
author: David H.

description: Thanks Scoutmob for 100% off a small pho ga. Pho ga is pretty much the only thing I order at TT. On a cold windy day, it warms the soul. It's my comfort food. I got a pretty decent serving for a small bowl. I like the free range chicken strips and the tasty soup. I can't complain, it was free! Service was good and no wait to be seated. This place is smaller than the TL location but there's an adequate amount of tables. I wouldn't normally come to this location since its in a questionable neighborhood but good for those serving jury duty at in courthouse just up the block.
author: Candace F.

description: Amazingly good Imperial Roll order. Have to go there and try the Pho. Love Vietnamese coffee too. Had a nice vibe. Glad I came.
author: Polynesian m.

description: WOW! I just returned from Hanoi, and this place is BETTER! The Pho is classic traditional with fresh ingredients. The Banh cuoi was delish! The Bun Cha was cooked to perfection. Even though it is the opening week I felt service was very good and attentive. I will be coming back again and again!
author: glenn w.

description: Awesome chicken noodle soup and gotta try the Vietnamese coffee!
author: Alan M.

description: Love this place, the fresh spring rolls and the Chicken Pho are the best in town.
author: Sarah F.

description: This Review is ONLY for their pork rice plate dish & sticky rice....NOT VERY GOOD AT ALL.....Probably should have ordered the Chicken PHO.
author: Cathy D.

description: maybe i just don't love northern style pho, but turtle  tower provided me with a just a barely decent bowl of pho. sometimes pho just hits the spot when everything is just right. flavorful broth, noodles with the right amount of chew, and the right fixins. but somehow here, my bowl didn't hit the spot. while the beef is nice, the noodles, thicker in width and flat were almost mushy. there just wasn't anything about it that would make me want to spend my time purposely in that area of the city for pho.
author: Regina C.

description:
Turtle Tower: Hype machine?

Whenever I asked my Vietnamese friends about pho, my left ear would be falling off from the barrage of praise for Turtle Tower. I've always been skeptical, though. I've been more of a Kevin's Noodle House kind of guy, like as in the "I've gone to Kevin's since middle school" kind of guy. Was Turtle Tower worth the trip?

Randomly being in the neighborhood, I dropped in to this new location and grabbed the pho ga, which many say is the definitive dish at Turtle Tower, and a banh mi with pate, fried egg, and grilled chicken. The service was a bit slow considering how empty the restaurant was at 11AM on a weekday, but the food arrived in honestly under a minute so I wasn't mad about it. So...about that pho ga. I'll be blunt: it wasn't the dish that was sold to me. Sure, the broth was balanced and the noodles were supple and well-cooked, but everything was just average. I wasn't blown away. The pho ga is good for a quick bite and a warm dish on a cold SF night, but that's about it. As for the banh mi, it was generously loaded with the meats and eggs, but almost too generously loaded. The pickled vegetables and cilantro were really afterthoughts in this sandwich, causing it to be very heavy and laden with fat. Sure, the banh mi was good, but I could barely stomach a half before calling it quits.

All in all, Turtle Tower was just another dining experience, nothing noted positively or negatively. It was just a forgettable meal, for better or worse.
author: Frank Y.

description: I would say this place is quite interesting... small and quick service. I had to go for the beef pho with tripe, rare beef and beef brisket. The beef was a little interesting, I guess it just wasn't what I was expecting from other pho I've had. The noodle was also the flat rice noodles and not the pho noodles I was expecting.
author: Stephanie Y.

description: My friend and I came here to take advantage of the free bowl of pho ga from scoutmob. Though there were people waiting, the wait was fairly short (maybe 10 mins) for free food. I felt the pho ga though it came with a decent amount of chicken strips was a bit too bland for my liking. I don't mind bland food but I felt if the broth were just a little bit more flavorful it would have tasted better. At least I now know that their pho must be MSG free.
author: Helen L.

description: Edible, but inconsistent with its original counterpart in the Tenderloin. The Pho Ga was bland, not the rich chicken broth at the Larkin location. The banh cuon was ok, but I've never seen pink, bacon looking meat in my banh cuon ever before. The texture of the banh cuon was ok, a little too thick... I've had better. The beef stew was bland (literally like beef stewed in water), although the meat was tender. I won't be coming here ever again. When I crave chicken pho, I'll be going to the Turtle Tower in the TL.
author: Kimling L.

description: Ate here for the first time due to the Free Pho' Scoutmob deal. It's actually genuinely good, simple, fresh, clean and tasty food. The flavors were subtle and blended really well together, a generous amount of chicken and perfect noodles. I'll be back for sure, can't wait to try their sandwiches.
author: Antony M.

description: I don't know why this place only gets 3 stars. I'm a lifetime Pho eater from Vancouver and I thought the food here was fantastic.
author: Eric W.

description: Visited this place as a result of a coupon I received. I usually stay away from anything on 6th street because of all the transients, but this place was in a fine area. It was near the SFPD, and the crowd was "clean." The place was also clean, new and welcoming. There was a line out the door, but that is not saying much considering how small the place is. The staff was friendly, and the Pho, which I am no expert on, was great! I would definitely recommend this place as a quick lunch stop during work.
author: Michael C.

description: Disgusting! One bite and I threw it away.
author: Carlos M.

description: After hearing the good and the bad, I decided to try Turtle Tower.  Unfortunately, I'm not too crazy about it.  I had the grilled pork with steamed rice and it was not what I expected.  There wasn't enough meat nor veggies (there was a lettuce leaf and maybe one slice of tomato).  The fish sauce also tasted strange to me.. I guess I'm used to the garlic/chili packed fish sauce.  I've tried so many different Vietnamese restaurants and different Com Thit Nuongs in my life (in LA and SD particularly) and this place was not up to par.
author: Lynnie T.

description: I've been to the other Turtle Tower locations before. I visited this location this past weekend. I liked their pho ga like the other locations, but will probably not return, because the area we were seated at literally smelled like the restroom (our table was the closest to their restroom). Pretty much ruined my appetite.
author: Cherry C.

description: First Time seeing PINK color Beef Stew laced w/ MSG ...this place is TERRIBLE!!!
author: trung m.

description: So I mostly joined Yelp to find wedding vendors, but I am already getting sucked in to reviewing my favorite places.  I heart this place I heart it so much.  I always think that I am going to try something else, but then I walk in, sit down and order the number 6 (pan fried noodles in the broth with veggies and meat), small.  Generous portions and there is something about pan-fried noodles that is... *drool* oops! 'Scuse me.  I want to go to there.
author: Gaia M.

description:
This place isn't bad per se...but I'm guessing there are better places for pho in San Francisco :)
Had the chicken pho - it was ok.  Surprisingly didn't come with any limes, basil, or mint or any of that yummy brown sauce (whatever that is :)
Broth was ok - kind of salty.  Chicken pieces had random pieces of fat / bone.  Noodles were soft and yummy.  My friend got vegetables in hers - would highly recommend that.
Had a fried roll and that was ok.
author: Cathy L.

description:
I was surprised with my subpar experience at the 6th street location considering the original Larkin Street location's reputation. For a small venue, they seemed understaffed and bit overwhelmed by an average lunchtime flow. I waited for about 20 mins to be seated even though tables were available, they couldn't clean and set with any predictability. I would recommend you NOT order the rice porridge. For all the chicken bits, skin and fat I found in the porridge none of it registered any taste or flavor. At the risk of hyperbole, it reminded me of gruel from Oliver Twist. I might suggest Turtle remove it from the menu altogether and continue to focus on the pho. The last bit of my experience was humorous, but should serve as a caveat to diners looking to order off menu and snack on imperial rolls. I asked if I could place an imperial roll order to which the cheerful waiter said okay. I didn't realize he was going to bring out a single imperial roll the size of my thumb. And needless to say, the roll came after I was done with the porridge. I asked, "Is that all?" Thinking surely a dog must of swiped the other imperial rolls on the way to the table. Without an iota of hesitation, he replied, "It's what you ordered, right..? One imperial roll" Sheepishly, I had to chuckle aloud and channel more Twist, Please Sir, I want some more.
Something was certainly lost in translation
author: Aaron Y.

description: Average Banh Mi in flavor, above average in price ($3.40). Drip coffee is $3.20. About 10 min wait for to go orders and a bit of a wait for table service. The menu was confusing - menu on a half sheet = menu behind the register. Fold out menu did not have clear sections. Strange comment, but I like things a little more straight forward.
author: Mary R.

description: Service was good, small place best time to go around 2-4 pm but watch out for 3pm towaway on 6th st. Chicken pho was tasty, spring rolls were fresh as well as imperial rolls,  could be a little bit cheaper.
author: Li L.

description: Hands down, best pho ga in the city! But on the down side, they don't have my favorite seafood sauce.
author: Annie Y.

description: I love this new spot. They give more meat, it's right off the freeway and I never have a hard time finding parking. Downside no waiting area. If they are busy you would have to stand outside and wait. My bf and I had put our names on the waiting list but when they erase the names that were already called they fail to move our names to the top, and others that came after us were called first. I order the 3 color bean drink ( pink one) and the server gave me the green one. He had the nerve to argue with me saying they taste the same so I should just take that one. FYI they don't taste the same. After a minute or so he then takes it back and complain to his co-worker in Vietnamese. I don't think he knew that I can speak vietnamese.  Overall great food as always bad customer service
author: Hoa T.

description: Yo! These noodles are fuckin garbage! They got some fettuccine style pho nonsense going on here! What's up with that!
author: Thomas P.

description: this place is smaller, newer and a bit more clean than its counterpart in the tenderloin.  its convenient and the pho ga is pretty good.  if i order anything else with my phogo then i cant finish everything.  we tried the steamed pork rice roll and i thought that was pretty good too. when we first tried to come here, it was for dinner and they didnt serve pho but i heard thats changed
author: claudia y.

description:
OK I would give it another star but  I like the TL shop better. Sure this one is cleaner and has better parking but the food didn't live up to TL locale. All in all the chicken pho was still pretty darn good. The eggrolls were as good as I remembered from TL store. 
Nothing beat hot brothy pho on cold SF day...huh
author: Michelle Y.

description: I wasn't really suspecting this restaurant in this location, but overall it was a decent place, and a good informal dining experience.  The staff was very nice; but it is certainly no frills with open seating and a limited menu.
author: Jon S.

description: no intro really needed here, it's only the most popular vietnamese chicken noodle soup in the city! i say the food is solid, but not the best. the broth is tasty and not too greasy. portions are average with good amount of meat. worth a visit to see what the fuss is all about.
author: Melissa Y.

description: don't order the banh mi. the boy got the "special bahn mi" and i got the pork only. we both had the worst food poisoning of our lives within ten minutes of leaving. STAY AWAY!!!
author: Miquela S.

description: OK, I am not sure why I was dragged there, but Yuk Yuk Yuk. What kind of food is that? I have had Vietnamese food before and it is by far tastier. I ordered the Beef sautéed in red wine (#17?), and what a bad choice I have made. First the meat was served in a small bowl that has "wine sauce", which is far from it. I think the way it cooked, is after boiling the meat, they added some red wine and cooked for couple of minutes and poured it in the bowl. Second the meat had a lot of fat on it more than the lean, it was like treasure hunt to find beef. The soup that came with the order was OK, since all of them taste the same, some made up broth (nothing special). I also tasted the Chicken Noodle soup that my friend was having, and it's the same as everywhere else, Broth, Noodles and pieces of chicken (with skin - yuk). We also ordered the Imperial Rolls and they were aaaaay, barely ok, nothing special. So save your money and look for a better Vietnamese restaurant, there are a lot of them in the SF. The restaurant accepts cash only which usually tells a lot about a place. Can't complain to credit Card Company and they have a lot to hide, besides cash, which is not my business - but just saying.
author: Tongue-Me e.

description:
i'm rating this place base on one dish and one dish only. 

let's just say i've had better pho ga in my lifetime. i'm not sure why 7x7 included it on their big eat list. but whatever their reason, i don't get it. maybe they had a good reason... who knows?! all i can say is i've definitely had better. or it could just be that i'm very much used to my pho with lots of sprouts, basil and sauces added. their pho ga had none of these. i asked one of the waitresses for hoisin sauce after i added a bunch of sriracha (i had to ask for sriracha too) to my bowl and discovered that this type of pho was of northern vietnamese cuisine and they don't put that in their pho. so the restaurant doesn't carry it. i was left with a bowl full of sriracha-sauced noodle soup and nothing else to balance out the flavor. i managed to eat most of it though. i guess you can't complain too much if you're getting a free bowl of pho courtesy of their current scoutmob deal (which ends today! 6/1). 

would i go back there again for another bowl of pho ga? probably not. how about other things on their menu? hmmm... not sure. i'll have to think about that one. at the moment, probably not.
author: mai c.

description: Meh. I've experienced better sums it up. The Pho Ga was extremely salty. Tasty enough, but nothing mind-blowing.
author: Y S.

description: I ordered a bahn mi with pork and chicken to go.  It was full of burnt grizzle - disgusting.  Even if it was only $4.50 I'd rather go across the street to Little Vietnam Cafe or walk a few blocks to Sunrise Cafe.
author: Anonymous S.

description: great food! #6 is awesome. tastes soooo fresh. first time to their new 6th street location.  smaller digs, but same great food.
author: Aaron R.

description: The lady says, "this is a different kind of Vietnamese" restaurant.  So am I being stereotypical when I expect hoisin sauce at this Vietnamese spot?  I don't care what tribe your from, how hard is it to have that sauce on the table.  I mean, they offer everything else the same.  Sandwiches, spring rolls and even coconut juice.  Alright, so I'm thinking, perhaps the broth must be hella amazing, that it doesn't need sauce to flavor it up.  Here's the verdict,  it was bland as muck and my friend says, its probably good for old people, because old people like bland.  The noodles were the thicker kind too, like sliced chow fun.  They didn't even offer sprouts or basil either too.  Aren't they economical.  So I wanted to give them the benefit and thought, maybe their sandwich is good at least.  It had to come with 3 choices of meat, so I went with whatever, and took one bite, wrapped it up and took it home.  Where is it now, its in the compose.  Should of saved it for a homeless person.  So I wouldn't say they are Gawd awful, because the service was still decent, but I wouldn't go back for the food.
author: Janice F.

description: Delicious pho ga, friendly and efficient staff and clean environment. A welcome addition to the neighborhood!
author: Geoffrey U.

description: Wowza, just had braised beef over noodles - one of the 6 or so dishes on their wall - and was not impressed. I didn't taste their Pho, but after the experience I just had I'm not sure I'd risk going back for a second visit.
author: Mat J.

description: there were 5 of us going for lunch, we've gone there before and were never treated so rudely as this day. everyone usually orders the number 6  pho , but some of us wanted to try different pho's so we asked the waiter for suggestions . It seemed the waiter did not have time to answer our questions and seemed irritated . He actually said that we were confusing him and told us make up our mind! we were not his only victims that day ...he was rude to the group next to us.  Overall it made our  food  there very sour and tasteless. We highly recommend to go to the turtle tower on Larkin st. better noodles and kinder service.
author: francisco a.

description: We came to have the free pho offer today, and we were all very happy with the quality of the food.  The brooth of the pho is very clear and tasty.  I like that they don't serve the bean sprout and basil on the side, because you can really appreciate the broth more. Besides the pho, we also tried the three-co;or drink, and roll, and the cuttle fish patty.  The cuttle fish patty had great texture and flavor.  They are also very accommodating and make the spring roll without pork for us.  Good food and friendly staffs, clean restaurant, definitely will come back when we are in the area.  Thank you for the free pho.
author: Tim R.

description: This place is awful.  The staff is unfriendly and inefficient.  After a meh meal a few months back, we tried again last week.  Although there were 4 empty tables, after repeatedly asking the disinterested host if we could sit, he finally told us to put our name on the list (along with 4 other tables).  No one greeted us, and in fact some of the staff went outside to smoke/drink tea while we waited  to be sat at one of the many open tables.  I live in the neighborhood and was excited for some new food options, but wont be back to this place ever again.
author: Bitzz B.

description:
I'm not going to be judgmental towards the people who wrote bad reviews or wrote that this place doesn't really serve Pho.  I've gone to this place 3 or 4 times since they've opened.  In the beginning, there were some opening pains with handling the crowds and the quality wasn't up to the one on Larkin St, but I went there today, and the quality was excellent.  I think it takes awhile before a new location gets its footing if it ever does.  For a restaurant that gets so much traffic, I cannot figure out why they didn't rent a larger space.  I will give the complainers that.

I can tell anyone who hasn't been to Vietnam that this is indeed real Pho.  Like any food, such as pizza or gumbo, there are many variations of Pho.  Most people have only experienced the southern flavor that is more aromatic and served with a side of herbs.  TT serves the northern style, the original version.  If you go to Vietnam, the northern style is the most favored version, even in the south.  It's actually harder to make good northern style Pho, and I wouldn't say TT has achieved the goal of matching northern style Pho that I've had in Vietnam.  With southern style, the herbs and spices sometimes cover up for mediocre soup.  Having eaten at the best Pho place on the planet many times, I can honestly say TT doesn't measure up, but it's pretty good for Pho in the USA, and it's the only northern style place I know of in America.  Also, Pho Ga isn't just the Vietnamese version of the chicken noodle soup.  They've been eating it for hundreds of years.  As for the best Pho on the planet, it's a northern style place in Saigon, which I won't name since it's already too popular among the locals in Saigon.  The flavor of that Pho is so vastly different and better than any Pho I've tasted across the USA.  It's really hard to describe.

Anyway, I like this location because it's in a better neighborhood and forces me to walk 6 blocks to get my meal.  A healthy tasty meal after a nice walk, how can you beat that?  I love the chicken version.  After finishing the noodles, I just sit there and sip on the soup base.  A very good meal for the winter weather.  When it comes to their other food, I have little experience.  I had a rice dish once at the Larkin location and left hungry so I never order anything but Pho at TT.
author: Loc N.

description: a welcome addition to the neighborhood! both the pho chin (beef) and pho ga (chicken) were solid - tasty broth, fresh noodles, generous portions of beef/chicken to top it off. we'll be back to try the non-pho dishes... overall pleased to have an inexpensive and very pleasant eatery join the area
author: lois j.

description: using real shark fin for shark fin soup because the chef wants tradition is one reason to stay out of the place. the second reason is the food is pedestrian at best and the service so pushy and syrupy as to make you run out. but the real reason to run out is shark hunting for soup.
author: susan w.

description: I came here because of Scoutmob.  There's a Turtle Tower in the Richmond District that I dig and frequent.  This location is a little out of the way for me, but I'm willing to trek out here for free food.  I ordered a pho ga with no skin, spring rolls, and hot tea.  I got pho ga with skin, spring rolls, and water.  I was going to bug someone for tea, but the people who worked here seemed annoyed and I didn't want to exacerbate that.  I still don't like the fact that they don't roll the ends of their spring rolls and they fall apart too easily because of this.  However, they were still yummy.  The pho ga would have been a million times better without skin, but I can't complain too much because it was free 99.  A small is the perfect size.  The interior is pretty small and I wouldn't recommend coming here with a huge group.  It's also kind of a sketchy area, despite a police station being nearby.
author: k h.

description: We were very excited to see a new Vietnamese restaurant opening right across from our building. We tried it today. Unfortunately, it will be the last time. We ordered the vermicelli bowl with pork and the vermicelli bowl with spring rolls, our staple order. Portions of meat and spring rolls were small for the price ($8-something). Tu Lan up 6th street and Market charges $7 for a bowl containing both a more substantial portion of grilled pork and one huge spring roll. We were disappointed to see one of the cooks reheat the pork in a microwave, and we were even more disappointed when the food finally arrived to our table: overcooked rice noodles, off-putting sauce...It was honestly the worse vermicelli bowls we had ever had. I don't know how the rest of the food on the menu is, but unfortunately for Turtle Tower, we'll keep going to Tu Lan for our vermicelli bowl fixes, even if it means walking up 4-5 blocks!
author: Remy L.

description: I don't recommend coming here for any sandwich. They do not know how to make a proper sandwich. I ordered a few pork sandwiches without jalepenos and ended up getting sandwiches with lots of jalapenos. Basically, my sandwich included cucumber, carrots, and grilled pork on an ordinary bun (nothing like a baguette) and a lot of unwanted jalapenos. I ask the girl taking the order how you can eat a sandwich without any spread or sauce in it and she says the sandwiches are not like anywhere else and they don't put anything in it. Really? I'd be okay if the grilled pork was dripping with sauce to help coat the bread, but it was dried as well. WTF! I think they should just stick to the pho which they are will known for and stay clear of sandwiches and everything else. Should have learned my lesson the first time I came here when they first opened and failed miserably at their take on dinner menus.
author: Matt V.

description: worse vietnamese restaurant I ever been to. very different from other vietnamese restaurant and pretty small portion and very expensive. only 3 piece of  imperial rolls cost up to 7 dollars.
author: Mary T.

description: raw grey beef chunks floating, enough said. it was so bad that i will never have pho again.
author: Devang S.

description: wtf they opened another place. all i gotta say is the food sucks stay away.
author: Art N.
